descriptions.value: Northwest Athens: Academy: General bibliography: Travlos, J. 1971, 42-51, figs. 52-64; LIMC I, 1981, 433-435 s.v. Akademos; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1985, 686-711; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 693-789 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Northwest Athens: Academy Area: General bibliography: Billot, M.-F. 1989, 693-789 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Rough area athwart the major roads to the Academy (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Akropolis is bounded by the circuit wall and by the 3rd c. A.C. outwork with the Beulé Gate  at the west.  (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Akropolis East Slope is bounded by Stratonos St. from Thespidos St. at the south as far as Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou (Plan 1 zeta—7, no. 107) at the north. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

East and northeast of the Akropolis (the eastern part of Plaka), the boundaries going clockwise as follows: Thrasyllou St. → Stratonos St. as far as Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou (Plan 1 zeta—7, no. 107), a line drawn from Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou to Mitropoleos St. → Voulis St. → Navarchou Nikodimou St. → Philellinon St. → Amalias Ave. → Dion. Areopagitou Ave. as far as Thrasyllou St. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

The Akropolis Lower North Slope is bounded on the south by Theorias St. → Prytaneiou St. → Stratonos St. as far as Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou (Plan 1 zeta -7, no. 107), a line drawn from Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou as far as Mitropoleos St. → Monastiraki → Areos St. → Dioskouron St. → Theorias St. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

The Akropolis Lower South Slope is bounded by Dion. Areopagitou Ave. on the north → Syngrou Blvd. → Drakou St. → Garibaldi St. (Plan 2 eta/theta 4-5). Some of the area here defined for convenience as the Akropolis Lower South Slope is in fact the Philopappos east slope; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Akropolis Upper North Slope is bounded by Theorias St. → Prytaneiou St. → Stratonos St. as far as Hag. Giorgios tou Vrachou (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Akropolis Upper South Slope is bounded by the west side of the Odeion of Herodes Atticus , Dion. Areopagitou Ave., Thrasyllou St. as far as Thespidos St.  (point accuracy ca. 10m)

The Akropolis West Slope is bounded at the west by the Odeion of Herodes Atticus  and does not include Dörpfeldʼs so-called West Slope excavations which are entered under the heading Areopagus-Pnyx Valley (point accuracy ca. 10m)

The Agora Excavations , conducted by the American School of Classical Studies from May 25th, 1931, onward, are treated as a unit in the belief that readers will find it convenient to have the monuments and sites without clear-cut names from the Agora Excavations  together in one place. The Agora Excavations  include not only the ancient civic center but also areas well outside the ancient civic centre in all directions so that this unit, expanding and continuously changing its boundaries over the years, overlaps with other topographical sections, i.e. Akropolis Upper North Slope , Akropolis Lower North Slope, Areopagus Hill, Areopagus-Pnyx Valley, the Pnyx Range, and Agora Surroundings. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Agora Surroundings. The northwestern section is the area between the Kerameikos Excavations and the Agora Excavations; the northeastern section is bounded at the east by Dioskouron and Areos Sts., at the north by Ermou St. from Monastiraki to the church of Hag. Asomaton. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

The Areopagus Hill  has not been properly studied for its own sake. Although the north slope extends all the way down to the Eridanos River , nowadays only the upper slope is perceived as the Areopagus Hill . The best published plan to date, giving the contour lines and in particular the huge masses of fallen rock near Hag. Dionysios Areopagites, is by J. Travlos in Hesperia 9 (1940) pl. I (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Early excavation reports refer to much of this area as the Akropolis West Slope.  General plan: AM 30 (1905) pl. I by Friedrich Graeber (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Rough outline of the area used for public burials (point accuracy ca. 10m)
General area of ancient Athens within which unlocated sites and monuments could be looked for. (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Hill of the Nymphs (Asteroskopeio/Observatory hill) (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Ilissos Left Bank from Northeast to Southwest (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Ilissos right bank from northeast to southwest, including the Zappeion Garden and the Olympieion  area (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Northwest Athens: Kerameikos Excavations. General plans: Hoepfner, W. 1970, 287-290, Beil. 4-5; Knigge, U. 1991, fig.165 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Northwest Athens: Kolonos Hippios Area: Nos. 462-474 set forth the topography of Hippios Kolonos  and surroundings (including Skouze Hill) as [imaginatively] reconstructed by Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 387-418, figs. 199-205, pls. 123-125. In arbitrarily assigning locations to the monuments and sites mentioned in Sophoclesʼ Oedipus Coloneus and in Pausaniasʼ account, Svoronos had no evidence to work with, no finds, no walls, no foundations, no rock-cut beddings. [Svoronos had plenty of nothing and nothing was plenty for him.] (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Philopappos hill (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Northeast Athens is bounded on the west by the east side of Aiolou St. and on the south by an east-west line drawn through the Parthenon  and the Zappeion Bldg. (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Northwest Athens is bounded on the south by an east-west line drawn through the Parthenon  and is bounded on the east by the east side of Aiolou St. (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Pnyx hill assembly place (point accuracy ca. 10m)
The Pnyx Range has three hills: Mouseion Hill  (Philopappos), Pnyx Hill and the Hill of the Nymphs (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Rough outline of the area athwart the Sacred Way to Eleusis, the modern Iera Odos. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

[Polygon of Themistoclean wall's approximately trace] The gates are in clockwise order. Unless otherwise stated the gates are in the Themistoklean City Wall. Under the heading for each gate, the roads starting inside the City Wall going towards the gate are given first, followed by the roads from the gate towards destinations outside the City Wall (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Achilles: Achilles at Skyros, picture by Polygnotos in the Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.6; LIMC I, 1981, 57, no. 95, s.v. Achilleus (A. Kossatz-Deissmann) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Achilles: Statue of the hero Achilles in a small shrine in front of the statue of Athena in the Parthenon, set up by a hierophant Nestorios ca. 375 A.D.: Zos. 4.18.2-3; Clinton, K. 1974, 43; T. M. Banchich, “Nestorius ιεροφαντειν τεταγμένος,” Historia XLVII (1998) 360-374  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Adonis: cult: Plu. Alc. 18.2-3; LIMC I, 1981, 222-223, nos. 45-49, s.v. Adonis (B. Servais-Soyez); Simms, R. R. 1985, 209-263 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Aegis of gilded bronze with a head of Medusa the gorgon, on the Akropolis south wall above the Theatre, dedicated by Antiochos IV; Paus. 1.21.3, Paus. 5.12.4; represented on coins, O. Morkholm, Studies in the Coinage of Antiochus IV of Syria, Copenhagen, 1963, 14, 23; Chr. Habicht, “Athen und die Seleukiden,” Chiron 19 (1989) 11-12; Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 53-54; P. Themelis, “Macedonian Dedications on the Akropolis,” in Macedonians in Athens 2003, 168-172 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aesop: large statue set up by the Athenians (not necessarily in Athens): Phaedr. 2.9.1; Richter, G. M. A. 1984, 80 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Agathe Tyche: Statue at the Prytaneion: Ael. VH 9.39 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aglauros: Sanctuary of Aglauros near the place in front of the Akropolis, but behind the gates and the road up, whence the Persians got into the Akropolis: Hdt. 8.53.1; alongside of the Propylaia of the Akropolis, FGrHist III B 328 Philochoros 105; temenos of Aglauros above the sanctuary of the Dioskouroi, Paus. 1.18.2.; place where the ephebes swore their oath, Plu. Ale. 14.4; for a rich collection of testimonia in an article whose conclusions the author has retracted, see M. Ervin, “The Sanctuary of Aglauros on the south slope of the Akropolis . . .,” ΑΡΧΕΙΟΝ ΠΟΝΤΟΥ 22 (1958) 133-136 and passim (an offprint of this article is in the Library of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens); although no ancient source attests a cave of Aglauros, the sanctuary is [mistakenly] located in the Akropolis North Slope cleft (Part II no. 198), dubbed “Cave of Aglauros,” Travlos, J. 1971, 1,2,52,72, 228, 578, fig. 5 no. 11, fig. 91 no. 136, fig. 93, fig. 722 Q; [the temenos was probably on the Akropolis North Slope at Cave Gamma ]; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Agora: place name: Paus. 1.17.1 + 2; Agora_III, passim (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Agora, Old: (the Archaia Agora) near Aphrodite Pandemos: Harp. s.v. Πάνδημος Άφροδίτη; Wycherley, R. E. 1966, 285-293; [mistakenly] located on the Akropolis northwest slope below the Peripatos near the Roman Agora, Travlos, J. 1971, 1,28 (“the Roman Agora ... is situated near the Old Agora founded by Theseus” ), 198 “the Eleusinion was founded in the Old Agora”), 210 (earlier Eponymous Hero Monument); [mistakenly] located east of the Akropolis, Dontas, G. S. 1983, 62-63; [mistakenly] located on the eastern part of the Akropolis North Slope, Miller, S. G. 1994, 202-203, 211-212, 214, 215, 219, fig. 1 AA; Schnurr, C. 1995a, 131-138, plans 1-2; Papadopoulos, J. K. 2003, 280-284, 288, fig. 5:15; [as Harpokration tells us the sanctuary of Aphrodite Pandemos is intimately associated with the Old Agora] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Agora Kekropia: adorned by Kimon: Melanthius cited by Plu. Cim. 4.7; Schnurr, C. 1995a, 132 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Agora of the Kerkopes: where stolen goods were sold, near the Heliaia: Eust. Od. 2.7; Agora_III, nos. 669-673 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Agrai: district on the Ilissos left bank: Paus. 1.19.6; Judeich, W. 1931, 45 with note 2, 165, 176 note 6, 416 with note 6; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 121, 128-129, 131, 139-141; R. Simms, “Agra and Agrai,” GRBS 43 (2002/3) 219-229; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

A. 1950, 31-141, figs. 1-21, pls. 16-20; Travlos, J. 1971, 365-371, figs. 34 no. 65, 469-491; Agora_Guide 1990, 28, 118 ff., 196 f., figs. 7, 19, 70-75 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Aiakeion: ca. 506 B.C., temenos of the Aiginetan hero Aiakos in the Agora built in accordance with a Delphic oracle: Hdt. 5.89; POxy 2087 lines 16-18; Kearns, E. 1989, 47; the Aiakeion made watertight and provided with a door to serve as a public granary, Agora_I 7557, lines 14-16; Stroud, R. S. 1998, 51-53, 54, 85-108, 111, figs. 6-7; SEG 48 (1998) nos. 69, 96; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Aias of Salamis: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2; Kron, U. 1976, 30, 171-176; LIMC I, 1981, 315 no. 2, s.v. Aias I (O. Touchefeu) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aidos: Altar: seen “in the Agora,” Paus. 1.17.1; [probably in the Roman Agora] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aigeus: Aigeusʼ gate, east of the Delphinion: Plu. Thes. 12.3; Kron, U. 1976, 125-126 note 574; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aigeus: Heroon: Paus. 1.22.5; Kron, U. 1976, 124-127; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Aigeus: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aigeus: Aigeusʼ observation post at the Athena Nike temple site: Paus. 1.22.4-5; G. S. Dontas, «Άνασκαφή είς τους  νοτίους πρόποδας τής Άκροπόλεως,» Praktika, 1960,6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aischines: the orator, house in Kollytos: Aeschin. Ep. 5.6; Davies, J. K. 1971, 547 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

descriptions.value: Aischylos: SEG_49 162 (1999); Bronze statue in the Theatre: Paus. 1.21.2; Gauer W. 1968b,132-134 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Akademia, Hekademeia: Hekademeia, the original place-name, after the hero Hekademos: D.L. 3.7-8; Kron, U. 1979, 55-58; Threatte, L. 1980, 128 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Akademia, Hekademeia: Akademia: Pl. Ly. 203 A (Sokrates' walk from the Academy directly to the Lykeion on the ring road circling the City Wall); Paus. 1.29.2 + 1.30.1-3 (large district containing gymnasium and sanctuaries); Plu. A.C., IG II² 2776 lines 89, 149, 186; for a republication of this inscription with commentary, see Miller, S. G. 1972, 67-95 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Akamas: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Akestion: daughter of Xenokles and descendant of Themistokles, grave mon., 1st c. B.C., on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.1; Clinton, K. 1974, 54-55 nos. 13-14, 58 Table 1 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Akratos: mask built into a wall in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; Kearns, E. 1989, 144 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Alexander of Pherai: bronze statue: Plu. Pel. 31.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Alexander the Great: Three hundred Persian panoplies or 300 shields dedicated to Athena on the Akropolis after the battle of Granikos, 334 B.C., with an inscription proclaiming the dedicators as Alexander, the son of Philip, and the Hellenes excepting the Lakedaimonians: Arr. An. 1.16.7 (panoplies); Plu. Alex. 16.17 (shields); Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 17-18 and Part II, vol. 1, 2000, 57-58 and vol. 2, 2000, 86-87, 89-90 with figs. 26-27, 232 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Alexander the Great: Alexander and Hephaistion, cult: Hyp. Epit. 21; cf. Habicht, Chr. 1970, 28-36, 216-221, 246-250 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Alkibiades: House with wall paintings by Agatharchos: Plu. Ale. 16.4 + Plu. Ale. 22.3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Alkibiades: Statue relabelled Ahenobarbus: D. Chr. 37.40; Richter, G. M. A. 1984, 2, 82 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Alkibiades: Alkibiades celebrating his chariot race victory at Nemea, Propylaia: Paus. 1.22.6-7; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 147 with note 27 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Alkibiades: Alkibiades crowned by Olympias and Pythias painted by Aglaophon: Ath. 12.47 (534d); Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 467-469 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Alkmene: altar in the sanctuary of Herakles at Kynosarges: Paus. 1.19.3; Kearns, E. 1989, 145 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

All the Gods: Sanctuary founded by Hadrian, the so-called Pantheon: Paus. 1.5.5 + Paus. 1.18.9; cf. Paus. 8.37.10; J. Beaujeu, La religion romaine a l'apogee de l'Empire, I: La politique religieuse des Antonins (96-102), Paris, 1955, Index s.v. Pantheon d'Athenes; [mistakenly] located in the Library of Hadrian, Karivieri, A. 1994a, 90-93, 112; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Alopeke: Deme south of the City Wall: Hdt. 5.63; Traill, J. S. 1986, 139 with Map; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 120, 128 with note 30, 133, 143, 144, 152-153 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Amazon's Grave Stele: near the Itonian Gate: Pl. Ax. 364 D-365 A; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 37; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 121; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Amazoneion: sanctuary established by the Amazons on the Areopagus at the site of their encampment: A. Eu. 685-690; FGRHIST III B, 56, Kleidemos 323 F 18 with suppl. vol. I, 77; Judeich, W. 1931, 62 note 1, 300 note 6; Kearns, E. 1989, 146 s.v. Amazons; Conwell, D. H. 1993, 222-224, 523 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Amazonomachia: Graves of those fallen in battle lining the road to the Peiraeus Gate: Plu. Thes. 27.3-4; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 77-78 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Amazonomachia: Picture by Mikon in the Stoa Poikile, Athenians and Theseus fighting Amazons: Paus. 1.15.2; Agora_III, nos. 55-6, 59,80; T. Holscher, Griechische Historienbilder des 5. und 4. Jahrhunderts v. Chr., Wurzburg, 1973, 50, 68, 71-73 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Amazonomachia: Picture in the Theseion of the Athenians battling Amazons: Paus. 1.17.2, cf. Paus. 5.11.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Amphiaraos: Statue next to the Eponymous Heroes: Paus. 1.8.2; LIMC I, 1981, 701 no. 57, s.v. Amphiaraos (I. Krauskopf); probably shown on New Style silver tetradrachms, 135/4 B.C., Herzog, H. 1996, 22-26 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Amphiktyon: king of the Athenians, feasting Dionysos and the Gods, terracotta sculpture in an oikema next to the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; cf. Paus. 10.8.1; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 164 under frag. 58; Kearns, E. 1989, 147 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Amphilochos: son of Amphiaraos, altar: Paus. 1.34.3; Kearns E. 1989, 148  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Anaideia: Anaideias Lithos ('Rock of Unforgiveness, where the prosecutor stood”) on the Areopagus: Paus. 1.28.5; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vols. I 635-6 and II, 512-3; Agora_XXVIII, 46 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Anako: Isokratesʼ aunt, statue on the Akropolis: Plu. Moralia 839 D; Blanck, H. 1969, 15 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Anakreon: Statue of Anakreon singing while intoxicated, on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.25.1; Gauer, W. 1968b,141-142 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Anchesmos: name of a hill: Paus. 1.32.2; probably present-day Tourkovouni (q.v.) about 1 1/2 km. north of Lykabettos: Langdon, Μ. K. 1976, 101-102 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Anchimolios: of Sparta, grave stele, 512 B.C., in Alopeke near the Herakleion at Kynosarges: Hdt. 5.63; Pritchett, W. K. 1985, 163-164; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 120, 125, 154 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Andokides: the orator: House on the Akropolis north slope with the “Andokides' herm” in front: Plu. Nic. 13.2; Agora_XI, 119-120; see Herms Her8*; Symbolon (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Andokides: Choregic victory tripod: Plu. Moralia 835 B; Amandry, P. 1977,175 note 17 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Anthemion: son of Diphilos, standing beside a mare, sculpture on the Akropolis: Arist.Ath. 7.4; Rhodes, P. J. 1981, 143-145; Further Greek Epigrams 1981, 415-417 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Anthemokritos: Statue voted by decree of the people: D. 12.4; Knigge, U. 1960, 74 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Antigonos I (Monophthalmos) and Demetrios Poliorketes: As Soteres, cult with altars instituted in 307 B.C.: Plu. Demetr. 10.4, 12.3, 46.1; Habicht, Chr. 1970, 44-48, 53, 54, 132, 134-135, 138, 142, 143, 144, 146 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Antisthenesʼ School: in the Kynosarges Gymnasium: D.L. 6.13; FGRHIST CONTINUED, Part IV A, fascicle 1, 94 (J. Engels) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Antonius M.f.M.n.: Statues of Mark Antony and Cleopatra as gods set up on the Akropolis by the Athenians, 32 B.C., thrown down into the Theatre by thunderbolts in 31 B.C.: D.C. 50.15.2; T. Aphrodite: Statue by Kalamis dedicated by Kallias on the Akropolis, ca. 450 B.C.?: - - - IG I³ 876; Agora_I 5128; Paus. 1.23.2; Delivorrias, A. et al. 1984, 23 no. 146 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite: Two statues at the Ares temple: Paus. 1.8.4; E. B. Harrison, op. cit. (no. Aph8* above), 374; Delivorrias, A. et al. 1984, 35-36 no. 242, ph. (= Agora_S 37) and 42 no. 293, ph. (= Agora_S 378) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite: Temple founded by Phaidra: E. Hipp. 30-34 with schol.; W. S. Barrett, ed., Euripides, Hippolytos, Oxford, 1978, 1-10, 13-15, 27-28, 32-34, 44-45, 159-162; cf. Isis, naiskos facing south, Akropolis South Slope, west of the Asklepieion. (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Aphrodite: Burial mound of Hippolytos in front of the temple of Themis: Paus. 1.22.1; La Rocca, E. 1975, 447 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Aphrodite in the Gardens, sanctuary (Paus. 1.19.2, Paus. 1.27.3)

descriptions.value: Aphrodite in the Gardens: Temple seen by Pausanias after Apollo Delphinios and before he saw Kynosarges: Paus. 1.19.2 + Paus. 1.27.3 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Aphrodite in the Gardens: Temple statue by Alkamenes: Paus. 1.19.2; Delivorrias, A. 1984, 31 no. 193; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 65, 252 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite Ourania: Aphrodite Ourania, sanctuary founded by Aigeus, near the Hephaisteion: Paus. 1.14.7; Shear Jr., T. L. 1984, 24-33, figs.1-4, 10, 13-16, pls. 1, 5:b, 6-7, 8:a, 9; C. M. Edwards, “Aphrodite on a Ladder,” Hesperia 53 (1984) 59-72; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Aphrodite Ourania: Statue of Parian marble by Pheidias: Paus. 1.14.7; Delivorrias et al. 1984, 27 no. 175 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite Ourania: Herm of Aphrodite Ourania, oldest of the Moirai, at Aphrodite in the Gardens: Paus. 1.19.2; Agora_XI, 138-9,168; Delivorrias et al. 1984, 10-11 no. 10 and 31 no. 193 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite Pandemos: Aphrodite Pandemos, sanctuary south and southwest of the Nike Bastion: cult established by Theseus, Paus. 1.22.3; IG II² 659 lines 11-12; Daux, G., 1961, 607, figs. 10-11; Johrens, G. 1981, 126-127; for a reconstructed drawing of the Akropolis by M. Korres showing the sanctuary below the Nike Bastion, see Parthenon 1994, 350-351 no. 18; [imaginary] site in the saddle between the Areopagus and the Akropolis, Travlos, J. 1971, 1, 2, fig. 5 no. 6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aphrodite Pandemos: Cult statues: IG II² 659 line 26; the original cult statue and the replacement: Paus. 1.22.3; G. S. Dontas, “Ein verkanntes Meisterwerk im Nationalmuseum von Athen,” in Festschrift fur N. Himmelmann 1989, 144-145; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aphrodite Psithyros: Aphrodite Psithyros and Eros Psithyros, sanctuary: Eust.Od. 20.8; FGRHIST III B, 188, Zopyros 336 F 2 with commentary (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Apollo: Altar in the Agora gilded by Neoptolemos, son of Antikles, in accordance with an oracle, ca. 330 B.C.: Plu. Moralia 843 F; Agora_III, 52 no. 113; [altar of Apollo Patroos?] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Caves of Apollo, Pan, Zeus (Athens Acropolis) (Paus. 1.28.4)

names.toponym: Caves of Apollo, Pan, Zeus (Athens Acropolis)

descriptions.value: Apollo: Cave sanctuary of Apollo Hypoakraios with rock-cut niches for votive plaques dedicated by archons to Apollo with various epithets (Apollo Apo5*-7* below), Augustan period - 3rd c. A.C., Akropolis North Slope, Cave Beta IG II² 2891-2930 +; Paus. 1.28.4; Kavvadias, P. 1897, 1-27, pls.1-4; [mistakenly] identified as the Pythion, Travlos, J. 1971, 91, 422, figs. 116, 540 no. 134; cf. E. Meyer, RE XXIV, 1963, col. 554-558 (Pythion no. 2); SEG_50 190 (2000); Nulton, P. E. 2000, 71-74 cat. no. 4, ph.; see Thesmothetai (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Apollo: Statue made and dedicated by Euboulides in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Apollo: Statue by Leochares in front of the temple of Apollo Patroos: Paus. 1.3.4; usually linked to Apollo Belvedere, LIMC II, 1984, 198 no. 179, s.v. Apollon (O. Palagia) and 381-382, s.v. Apollon-Apollo (E. Simon) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo: Statue by Peisias in the Bouleuterion: Paus. 1.3.5 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Alexikakos: Apollo Alexikakos, statue by Kalamis in front of the temple of Apollo Patroos: Paus. 1.3.4, Paus. 8.41.8; Hedrick Jr., C. W. 1988, 195-198 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Anadoumenos: Apollo Anadoumenos, statue in Ares temple precinct: Paus. 1.8.4; LIMC II, 1984, 242 nos. 467-468, s.v. Apollon (W. Lambrinudakis) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Apollo Delphinios: Apollo Delphinios, sanctuary between the sanctuary of Apollo Pythios and the Gardens: Paus. 1.19.1; often called the Delphinion, Plu. Thes. 18 (twice); called sanctuary of Artemis and Apollo Delphinios founded by Aigeus, schol. D. 23.74; F. Graf, “Apollo Delphinios,” MH 36 (1979) 12-19 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Apollo Delphinios: Temple of Apollo Delphinios built in Theseusʼ lifetime: Paus. 1.19.1 (thrice); (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Apollo Delphinios: Enclosure in the Delphinion on the site of Aigeusʼ house, where Medeaʼs poison for Theseus spilled; Plu. Thes. 12.3; Kron, U. 1976, 115, 125, 128-134 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Delphinios: Lawcourt in the Delphinion where Theseus was put on trial: Paus. 1.28.10; Agora_XXVIII, 48-49, 91, 135-139 and Index s.v. Delphinion; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Apollo Hekatombaios: Apollo Hekatombaios, cult: EM s.v. Έκατομβαιών; J. D. Mikalson, The Sacred and Civil Calendar of the Athenian Year, Princeton, 1975, 26 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Apollo Lykeios: Apollo Lykeios, sanctuary with a gymnasium in northeast Athens, the Lykeion: place named for Lykos son of Pandion, Paus. 1.19.3 + 4; Wycherley, R. E. 1978, 226-229; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1989, 251-260; Kearns, E. 1989, 182 s.v. Lykos; (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Apollo Lykeios: Statue of Apollo Lykeios leaning on a column supporting a tripod, 350-325 B.C.: Lucian Anach. 7; E. J. Milleker, The Statue of Apollo Lykeios in Athens, University Microfilms, 1988, 1-351; the statue may have stood in the palaestra, op. cit., 7. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Lykeios: Gymnasium of Apollo Lykeios: Paus. 1.29.16; Frazer; J. G. 1913, 196-198; Delorme, J. 1960, 523 s.v. Athenes (Lycee); Kyle, D. J. 1987, 77-84 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Lykeios: Bath used by Sokrates: Pl. Smp. 223 D (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Apollo Lykeios: Palaestra built by Lykourgos: Plu. Moralia 841 D, 843 F; Delorme, D. J. 1960, 56-57. A large complex, late 4th c. B.C. - late 4th c. A.C. on the Ilissos right bank east of Rigillis St. and north of Vas. Georgiou B' St. has been [doubtably] identified as the palaestra in the Lykeion gymnasium, E. Lygouri-Tolia, “Excavating an ancient palaestra in Athens,” in Stamatopoulou and Yerolanou 2002, 203-212, figs. 1-2, pls. 45-48. The theater tickets, cited as “particularly important” for the identification because they were issued to ephebes (ibid. 206, pl. 48c) are in fact dicasts tokens; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Apollo Lykeios: Peripatos: D.L. 5.2; Lynch, J. P. 1972, 68-69, 73-75 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Lykeios: Plane tree by a water channel: Thphr. HP 1.7.1; Delorme, J. P. 1960, 56 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Metageitnion: Apollo Metageitnion, cult: Harp. s.v. μεταγειτνιών; B. gr. Kruse, REXV, 1932, col. 1318-1319 (Metageitnios) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Apollo Parnopios: Apollo Parnopios, bronze statue by Pheidias, east of the Parthenon: Paus. 1.24.8; located south of the Parthenon, Stevens, G. P. 1946a, 15-16; possibly transfered to Constantinople, Agora_XXIV, 75-76 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Apollo Patroos: Temple, 350-325 B.C., south of the Stoa of Zeus Eleutherios: Paus. 1.3.4; Hedrick Jr., C. W. 1988, 185-210, figs. 1-3; Agora_Guide 1990, 74-77, 274 no. 74, figs. 5-7, 18, 19 no. 42, 38 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Apollo Patroos: Temple statue by Euphranor, colossal statue of Apollo Kitharoidos, ca. 330 B.C., found ca. 20 m. south of the temple of Apollo Patroos in the north room of the Metroon - - - Agora_S 2154, ex-NM 3573; Paus. 1.3.4; Palagia, O. 1980, 3-4 no. 18, 13-19, 65, figs. 6-17. The five kithara fragments (Agora_A 41) found along the north side of the temple do not belong to this statue. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Apollo Pythios Oracles: Oracles kept on the Akropolis: Hdt. 5.90 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Apollo Pythios: Sanctuary of Apollo Pythios, southwest of the Olympieion, the Pythion, on the Ilissos right bank in the area bounded by Kallirrois Blvd., Vourvachi St., Syngrou Boulevard and Athan. Diakou St.: Th. 2.15.4; Travlos, J. 1971, 100-103, fig. 130 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Apollo Pythios: Statue near the temple of Zeus Olympios: Paus. 1.19.1; C. Gasparri, “Osservazione sul tipo di Apollo detto ‘Ariadne',” Studi Miscellanei 22 (1974-75) 96 -98. The context of Paus. 1.19.1 clearly indicates that Pausanias saw the statue in a sanctuary of Apollo Pythios (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Apollo Pythios: Temple built by Peisistratos, disliked by the Athenians: Hsch. s.v. ἐν Πυθίῳ χέσαι; J. P. Lynch, “Hipparchos' Wall in the Academy at Athens,” in Studies Sterling Dow 1984, 175-176, 177-179 (testimonia); M. F. Arnush, “The Career of Peisistratos Son of Hippias,” Hesperia 64 (1995) 144-145 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Apollodoros: grave monument, after 340 B.C., on the Road to the Academy: “Apollodoros, a captain of the mercenaries, but a native Athenian, who being sent by Arsites, satrap of Hellespontine Phrygia, successfully defended the city of Perinthus when Philip invaded its territory,” Paus. 1.29.10 (transl. by Frazer); Frazer J. G. 1913, 382-383; [a state-financed monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Apollonios: sophist and hierophant, late 2nd-early 3rd c. A.C., grave at Hiera Syke: Philostr. VS 2.20.3; Clinton, K. 1974, 40-42 no. 29 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Archeia: term applied both to government offices and to the place around the Tholos, where most of them were: Phot. s.v. θολος; Agora_III, 126 and nos. 487, 573, 579, 594, 598; Agora_XIV, General Index (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Archon: Theatre throne - - - IG II² 5036; Maass, M. 1972, 15,16, 117-119, pl. 10; Archonsʼ building (oikema): D. 21.85; Agora_III, 4, 177, no. 583 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Ardettos: Lawcourt where dikasts were sworn in according to Pollux 8.122; called lawcourt by mistake, Agora_XXVIII, 91,186-187 nos. 171-175 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Areopagus: Hill named after Ares: Paus. 1.28.5 + Paus. 1.29.1; Paus. 7.25.1 + 2; cf. Paus. 1.21.4; on present-day plans the name Areopagus refers only to the peak of this large sprawling hill which in fact slopes down all the way to the Eridanos River on the north and down to the Areopagus-Pnyx Valley on the west; the Areopagus south slope has been overlooked because it merges with the Akropolis west slope (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Areopagus: Meeting-place of the Council of the Areopagus acting as a homicide court, near the walled sanctuary of the Semnai: A. Eu. lines 684, 704 (called Bouleuterion); Paus. 1.28.5 + 6 (Ares tried for the murder of Halirrhothios), Paus. 8.34.4; Agora_XXVIII, testimonia nos. 1-3, 8-28, 34, and Index s.v. Areopagus, Areopagus Council; formerly [mistakenly] located at the site of the church of Dionysios Areopagites (Chr. Mon. CM60*), E. Vanderpool, op. cit., 34-37; perhaps under the fallen boulders below the peak, Agora_XXVIII, 44; [probably east of the fallen boulders]; see Demos and Demokratia, Law against Tyranny; Kornelius Onomarchos; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Ares: sanctuary with a temple, south of the Altar of the Twelve Gods: Paus. 1.8.4. Temple of Ares, 430s B.C., originally dedicated to Athena Pallenis at Pallene, moved to the Agora in the early 1st c. A.C. Agora_A 64+; W. B. Dinsmoor, “The Temple of Ares at Athens,” Hesperia 9 (1940) 1-52, figs. 1-18; Μ. H. McAllister, “The Temple of Ares at Athens,” Hesperia 28 (1959) 1-64, figs. 1-24, pls. A, 1-17; original site [mistakenly] located at Acharnai, Travlos, J. 1971, 104 with figs. 34 no. 67, 138-145; Agora_Guide 1990, 114-115, 276 no. 114, figs. 7, 67; probably repaired after 267 A.D., Agora_XXIV, 97 note 9, 109; M. Platonos-Yota, “The Sanctuary of Athena Pallenis,” Archaiologia 65 (Oct.-Dec. 1997) 92-97 with photos and drawings; M. Korres, “Από τον Σταυρό στην Αγορά,” Horos 10-12 (1992-1998) 83-104, pls. 15-20; the temple of Ares linked to the building of the temple of Mars Ultor in Rome, F. E. Romer, “A Numismatic Date for the Departure of C. Caesar?,” ΤΑΡΑ 108 (1978) 201-202 note 35 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Ares: Temple statue by Alkamenes: Paus. 1.8.4; usually associated with the Ares Borghese, LIMC II, 1984, 480-481 no. 23, s.v. Ares (P. Bruneau) and 512-513 no. 21, Ares-Mars (E. Simon); Ares Borghese type representing Mars Ultor, an Augustan creation, mistakenly attributed to Alkamenes by Pausanias, Hartswick, K. J. 1990, 227-283, figs. 1-13; [perhaps together with Athena Ath34*] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Aristeides: son of Lysimachos, Choregic tripods, anciently attributed to Aristeides, son of Lysimachos: Plu. Arist. 1; Al. N. Oikonomides, “Attic Choregic-lnscriptions I: Aristeides and Cyriacus of Ancona,” Ancient World 3 (1980) 17-19 concerning Agora_I 3398 and IG II² 3027; SEG 30 (1980) nos. 124-125; Wilson, P. 200U, 205 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Aristeides: House: D. 3.26 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Aristonikos: of Karystos, statue: Ath. 1.19 (A); S. Dow, “The Athenian Honors for Aristonikos of Karystos, “Alexanderʼs ΣΦΑΙΡΙΣΤΗΣ,” HSCP 67 (1963) 78-92 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Aristotle of Stageira: Statue in Theophrastosʼ Garden: D.L. 5.51; Frischer, B. 1982, 94 with note 20 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Arrhephoroi: Sphairistra (open air court for ball games) on the Akropolis, used by the Arrhephoroi: Plu. Moralia 839 C; G. Roux, “Les Gymnases de Delphes et de Delos,” 8CH 104 (1980) 138 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Arrhephoroi: Dwelling on the Akropolis not far from the Polias temple: Paus. 1.27.3; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Arrhephoroi: Route taken by the Arrhephoroi from the Akropolis to a nameless enclosure (peribolos) not far from Aphrodite in the Gardens, via an underground passage: Paus. 1.27.3; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 191 on Paus. 1.19.2; K. Jeppesen, “Where Was the So-called Erechtheion?,” AJA 83 (1979) 392; cf. Eros and Aphrodite; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Arsinoe II: of Egypt, queen of Ptolemy II Philadelphos, statue in front of the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.8.6; Richter, G. M. A. 1972, II, 232 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Artemis: Artemis Agrotera, Ionic temple on the Ilissos left bank, ca. 435 B.C., southern edge of Ardittou Blvd. west of Thomopoulou St.: Paus. 1.19.6; Travlos, J. 1971, 112-120, figs. 154 no. 151, 156-163; E. Lygouri-Tolia, «Ανασκαφικη έρευνα στο χώρο του ναου' της Αρτέμιδος Αγροτέρας (οδοί Αρδηττού-Κούτουλα-Κεφάλου-Θωμοπούλου στο Μετζ),» Deltion 49 (1994) B1 Chr., 36-38; Childs, W. A. P. 1985, 207-251 with figs. 2, 5 and pls. 43-45; Mark, I. S. 1993, 82-83 with note 64, 84, 119-120; see Chr. Mon. CM34*; cf. Mother of the Gods (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Artemis: Temple statue with bow: Paus. 1.19.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Artemis: Artemis Agrotera and Enyalios, altar or altars at which the polemarch offers sacrifices: Arist.Ath. 58.1; Rhodes, P. J. 1981, 650 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Artemis Aristoboule: Artemis Aristoboule in Melite, sanctuary founded by Themistokles, west of Plateia Thissiou at 1 Irakleidon St.: Plu. Them. 22.1-2; Threpsiades, J. and E. Vanderpool 1964, 26-36, plans 1-2, pls. 16-21; SEG_22 116 (1967) (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Artemis Brauronia: Artemis Brauronia, sanctuary on the Akropolis, southeast of the Propylaia: Paus. 1.23.7; Travlos, J. 1971, 124-125, figs. 168-169; R. F. Rhodes and J. J. Dobbins, “The Sanctuary of Artemis Brauronia on the Athenian Akropolis,” Hesperia 1948 (1979) 325-341, pls. 81-86; L. Kahil, “Le ‘craterisque' d'Artemis et le Brauronion de l'Acropole,” Hesperia 50 (1981) 253-263, figs. 1-4, pl. 62; Despinis, G. 1997, 209-217, figs. 1-6 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Artemis Brauronia: Statue by Praxiteles: Paus. 1.23.7; LIMC II, 1984, 620, 640-641 no. 190, s.v. Artemis (L. Kahil) and 801-802 no. 16, s.v. Artemis-Diana (E. Simon); identified as Acr. 1352 (= Acr. 13601), a head badly mutilated by Christians, G. Despinis, “Neues zu einem alten Fund,” AM 109 (1994) 173-198, pls. 31-45; Despinis, G. 1997, 209-217, figs. 1-6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Artemis: Artemis Kelkaia, cult statue (edos) taken by Xerxes, returned to Athens by Alexander the Great: Arr. An. 7.19.2, cf. Arr. An. 3.16.8; A. Adler, RE IX, 1921, 147 (Kelkaia); Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 395 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Artemis Leukophryene: Artemis Leukophryene, held in honour by the Magnesians, bronze statue dedicated on the Akropolis by Themistoklesʼ sons, near the statue of Olympiodoros: Paus. 1.26.4, cf. Paus. 3.18.9; F. Fleischer, Artemis von Ephesos und verwandte Kultstatuen aus Anatolien und Syrien, Leiden, 1973, 140-146; Keesling, C. M. 2003, 139 with note 46 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Artemis: Artemis Lysizonos, sanctuary: schol. A.R. l.288 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Artemis Orthosia: Artemis Orthosia, sanctuary in the Kerameikos: schol. Pindari. Οl. 3.54; B. gr. Kruse, RE XVIII 2, 1942, col 1435 (Orthia) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Artemis: Artemis Pheraia, cult in Athens with the statue brought from Pherai: Paus. 2.23.5 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Artemon Periphoretos: statue by Polykleitos; Plin. Nat. 34.56; T. Lorenz, Polyklet, Wiesbaden, 1972., 54 with note 245; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 76 note 42 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Asklepios: Asklepios, sanctuary on the Akropolis South Slope: Paus. 1.21.4-5, Paus. 1.22.1 and Paus. 2.26.8; Aleshire, S. B. 1989, 1-385; Forsen, B. 1996, 2-25 passim, 31-54, nos. 1.1-1.49, figs. 3-39; Riethmüller, J. W. 1999, 123-143, figs. 1-4; Beschi, L. 2002, 19-29, 38-41 (bibliography) (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Asklepios: Pictures: Paus. 1.21.4 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Asklepios: Asklepios and his children, statues: Paus. 1.21.4; Beschi, L. 1969/1970, 117 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Asklepios: New-born Asklepios ( not on the preserved portion of the relief) found by Aresthanas (?) on a mountain with palm tree, dogs and snake, and, above, god and goddess, relief, ca. 350 B.C., Asklepieion - - - NM 1351, cf. Paus. 2.26.4-5; LIMC II, 1984, 721 no. 1279, ph., s.v. Artemis (L. Kahil); Holtzmann, B. 1984, 868 no. 5; Apollo is shown above at the right, Kaltsas, N. 2002, 214 no. 440 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Asklepios: Spring House in a round cave, mostly natural, partly rock-cut: IG II² 4464; R. Martin and H. Metzger, “Recherches d'architecture et de topographie a l'Asclepieon d'Athenes,” BCH 73 (1949) 321-323, pl. 16; the place where Halirrhothios the son of Poseidon attacked Alkippe the daughter of Ares, Paus. 1.21.4; Kearns, E. 1989, 144-145 s.v. Halirrothios and 145 s.v. Alkippe; [probably a cave of Pan and the Nymphs incorporated into the Asklepieion]; see Chr. Mon. CM5*, CM38**; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Asklepios: Altar set up by Sophokles: EM s.v. Δέξιον; Ferguson, W. S. 1944, 90-91; Sophokles 'evidently' set up the altar in the Amyneion, according to Travlos, J. 1971, 76, [but no evidence indicates that the Amyneion was founded as early as the 5th c. B.C., the altar was probably in Sophoklesʼ house]; cf. Riethmüller, J. W. 1999, 135-136 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Asty: the town of Athens: IG I³ 1023; SEG_50 42 (2000); Paus. 1.20.5, Paus. 1.25.8; IG I³ 1111; Milestones marking distances from the Asty (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Hipparchosʼ herm, before 514 B.C., marking the half-way point between the Asty and Kephale - - - IG I³ 1023 = IG I² 837; Pl. Hipparch. 228D-229B; Guarducci, M. 1967-1978, II, 440-441, fig. 97; Agora_XI, 112-113,114; SEG_50 82 (2000); Billot, M.-F. 1989, 722 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Astydamas: son of Astydamas, base of an honorary bronze statue in the Theatre - - - IG II² 3775 (= IG II² 5168); D.L. 2.43; RE Suppl. X, 1965, 46, s.v. Astydamas (F. Stoessel); the literary testimonia for the statue presented and its date reviewed by H. R. Gotte, “Die Basis des Astydamas im sogenannten lykurgischen Dionysos-Theatre zu Athen,”, Antike Kunst 42 (1999) 21-25, fig. 1; pl. 5:1-2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena: Altar in the Academy: Paus. 1.30.2; in the precinct of Athena in the Academy, schol. S. OC 56; Billot, M.- F. 1989, 735-736; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Athena: Inscription copied in antiquity: AP 13.13 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena: Sanctuary of Athena: referring to the Akropolis where Sulla committed sacrilege: Paus. 1.20.7 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Athena, Temples on the Akropolis: Adyton approached by Kleomenes: Hdt. 5.72; J. Pouilloux, “A propos d'une etude sur l'Erechtheion (1),” BCH 74 (1950) 269-270 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Athena, Temples on the Akropolis: Shield taken down from the temple by Kimon before the battle of Salamis: Plu. Cim. 5.3; Preisshofen, F. 1977, 83; [perhaps a shield captured in 506 B.C.] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Athena, Temples on the Akropolis, seat

names.toponym: Athena, Temples on the Akropolis, seat

descriptions.value: Athena, Temples on the Akropolis: Throne of the priestess who spoke to Kleomenes on the Akropolis: Hdt. 5.72 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Athena, Temples on the Akropolis: Ancient statues blackened by Persian fire: Paus. 1.27.6; Keesling, C. M. 2003, 128; [perhaps a memorial display at the Akropolis north wall] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena on the Akropolis: Seated statue by Endoios, dedicated by Kallias, ca. 525 B.C., in the vicinity of the Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.4, probably = Acr. 625; P. A. Marx, “Acropolis 625 (Endoios Athena) and the Rediscovery of Its Findspot,” Hesperia 70 (2001), 221-254, figs. 1-16 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena, Temples on the Akropolis: Statue by Lokros in the temple of Ares: Paus. 1.8.4; Agora_XIV, 164; Hartswick, K. J. 1990, 258 note 99 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena: Xoanon brought to Daulis from Athens by Prokne: Paus. 10.4.9; J. McK. Camp, “Before Democracy: Alkmaionidai and Peisistratidai,” in Coulson et al. 1994, 8 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena Archegetis: Statue of Athena Archegetis: schol. Ar. Av. 516; identical with the old image of Athena Polias, Kroll, J. H. 1982, 69-70 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena Areia: Athena Areia, altar dedicated by Orestes on the Areopagus: Paus. 1.28.5; Johrens, G. 1981, 153-154 with note 828 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Athena Ergane: Athena Ergane, Thea Ergane: precinct (?) on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.3, Paus. 3.17.4, Paus. 5.14.5; Johrens, G. 1981, 176-178 esp. notes 934-935 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Athena Hygieia: Altar: Plu. Per. 13.8; Kavvadias-Kawerau, 1906, 146, pl. eta at altitude 145.70 m. (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Athena Hygieia: Base of statue by Pyrrhos, ca. 432 B.C., in situ east of the southernmost column of the Propylaia east porch - - - IG I³ 506 = IG I² 395; Paus. 1.23.4; Raubitschek, A. E. 1949, no. 166, 2 ph.; SEG_49 62 (1999) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena: Athena Kleidouchos, statue by Pheidias, Plin. Nat. 34.54 (location not specified); Schattner, T. G. 1990, 206; [probably in Athens] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena: Athena Lemnia, statue by Pheidias on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.28.2; perhaps east of the northernmost column of the Propylaia east porch, G. P. Stevens, “The Periclean Entrance Court of the Acropolis of Athens,” Hesperia 5 (1936) 454-455, 514-515, figs. 7, 63; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 63, 250-251; K. J. Hartswick, “The Athena Lemnia: A Response,” in ΣΤΕΦΑΝΟΣ 1998, 105-114; cf. commentary to IG I³ 514 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena Nike: Xoanon of Athena Nike (sometimes called Athena Apteros) holding a pomegranate and a helmet: IG I³ 1330 lines 11-13; Paus. 3.15.7, (made of wood) Paus. 5.26.6; Gulaki, A. 1981, 128-9; Romano, I. B. 1981, 58-69; Mark, I. S. 1993, 3-4, 24-29. 93-98 (testimonia), 108-110, 123-129, fig.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena Nike: Temple of Wingless Victory, the marble temple: IG I³ 64 with addenda; SEG_44 4 (1994); Paus. 1.22.4, Paus. 2.30.2; B. Wesenberg, “Zur Baugeschichte des Niketempels, Jahrbuch 96 (1981) 28-54, figs. 1-3, 8-9; Mark, I. S. 1993, 72-75, 82-92 (frieze dated ca. 420-418 B.C.), fig. 17, pls. 11, 14-21 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Athena Paionia: Sanctuary or statue in Melanthiosʼ Garden, on the Road to the Academy opposite the grave mon. of Lykourgos and his descendants: Plu. Moralia 842 E (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Athena Paionia: Statue in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; sometimes identified with NM 234, the so-called Euboulides Athena found on Ermou St. west of the church of Hag. Asomaton, Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 51-53; Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 541; dated to the Augustan period, Karanastassis, P. 1987, 416-420 B III 1, pl. 47:1-2; cf. Despinis, G. 1995, 322-323, 326, pl. 66; Kaltsas, N. 2002, 299 no. 625, ph. (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Athena Parthenos sculpture (Paus. 1.17.2 + Paus. 1.25.7, Paus. 5.11.10, Paus. 7.27.2)

descriptions.value: Athena Parthenos: First chryselephantine statue by Pheidias originally called the Golden Statue, 438/437 B.C.: IG I³ 453-460; Paus. 1.17.2 + Paus. 1.25.7, Paus. 5.11.10, Paus. 7.27.2; 10.34.8; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 53-58, 249-250; Harris, D. 1995, 263-265 (testimonia and select bibliography); represented on New Style silver tetradrachms of 55/54 B.C, Herzog, H. 1996, 145-147; [destroyed by fire during Hadrianʼs reign, before Pausaniasʼ visit]; cf. A. Frantz, “Did Julian the Apostate Rebuild the Parthenon?” AJA 83 (1979) 395-6, 401 note 54 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Athena Parthenos, birth of Pandora sculpture (Paus. 1.24.7)

names.toponym: Athena Parthenos, birth of Pandora sculpture

descriptions.value: Athena Parthenos: Birth of Pandora represented on the base: Paus. 1.24.7 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena Parthenos: Second chryselephantine statue: Paus. 1.24.5-7; represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins, 2nd c. A.C., Agora_XXVI, 128 nos. 169-171, pl. 16; G. P. Stevens, op. cit., 270-276; idem, “How the Parthenos was Made,” Hesperia 26 (1957) 361 (suggesting that “the well finished statue, which had served as a model for the colossal statue” had been preserved and used for the new Parthenos); idem, “Concerning the Parthenos,” Hesperia 30 (1961) 1-7, fig. 1, pl. 1; cf. Athena Ath99*; [Athena Parthenos II was dedicated during the reign of Antoninus Pius] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena Parthenos: Small statue of Athena Parthenos made by Pheidias before he made the large Parthenos: Him. Or. 28.8; Giovanni Becatti, Problemi fidiaci, Milan,1951, 81-82 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena Polias: Cult statue with golden owl, golden aegis, golden gorgoneion and golden phiale: IG II² 1424 A lines 362-326; Paus. 1.26.6 (indirectly alluding to the epithet Polias); xoanon set up by Erichthonios, Apollod. 3.14.6; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 340-341, 570-580; Kroll, J. H. 1982, 65-76, pl. 11; early 8th c. B.C., Romano, I. B. 1981, 42-57 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena Polias: Athena Polias and Erechtheus, cult: Hdt. 5.82; Kron, U. 1976, 40-42; probably = Ath118* below (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Athena Promachos: Athena Promachos on the Akropolis, ca. 450 B.C.?: IG I³ 435 with addendum; SEG_51 39 (2005); Paus. 1.28.2, Paus. 9.4.1; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 62-63, 250; represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins, Price, J. M. and B. L. Trell 1977, 68 fig. 130, 76 figs. 130-131, 77; Gauer, W. 1968, 38-9, 103-5; Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1980, 58; removal to Constantinople perhaps in 465-470 A.D., Agora_XXIV, 76-77 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Athena Polias: Ancient names for the statue: Called the great bronze Athena in the earliest mention: D. 19.272 Called the bronze statue of Athena by Pheidias: Paus. 1.28.2; Called Promachos, 5th c. A.C.: IG II² 4225 line 4; SEG_29 183 (1979)  (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena: Athena, Herakles, Demos, document relief, 350-325 B.C., between Philopappos and Pnyx hills at Hag.Dimitrios Loumbardiaris (Plan 1 theta -1, no. 112) - - - NM 2407, IG II² 4630; Kron, U. 1979, 49-63, pl. 7; Lawton, C. L. 1995, 139 no. 133, pl. 71; Herakles Alexikakos crowning Athena, Tagalidou, E. 1993, 51-54, 213-215 no. 20, pl. 11 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena and Marsyas: Sculpture by Myron, mid-5th c. B.C., on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.1; represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins, G. Daltrop, Gruppo mironiano di Atena e Marsia nei Musei Vaticani, Vatican City, 1980, 13-14, figs. 1-2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athena and Poseidon: Cult in the sanctuary of Demeter and Kore on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.2; S. Dow and R. F. Healey, S. J. 1965, 39-40 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Athena: Athena and Poseidon peacefully displaying the “tokens”, sculpture group on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.3; near the altar of Zeus Polieus, Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 301-302; perhaps opposite to the 2nd column from the east on the Parthenon north side, Stevens, G. P. 1946a, 11-12, fig. 3 no. 9, fig. 15; versions of the group represented on bronze imperial coins, Thompson, M. 1982, 166, 167, pl. 28 nos. 11, 13 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Athena and Zeus: Athena arising from Zeusʼ head, sculpture, Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.2; R. Thomas, “Die ‘schwebende Athena' in Basel. Bemerkungen zur Darstellung der Athenageburt im 5. Jahrhundert v. Chr.,” Jahrbuch 97 (1982) 62-63 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Athenai: place-name: Iliad 2.546, 549; Od. 3.278, 307; Od. 7.80; Od. 11.323; Paus. 1.1.5 et passim; see Neai Athenai; Novae Athenae; Setines (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Athenais: State burial monument inside the walls, before 157 A.D.: Philostr. VS 11.1.10; Ameling, W. 1983, I, 97 and II, 18-19, 141 no. 137 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Attalos I and Attalos II of Pergamon: Attalid dedication at the Akropolis south wall, sculpture groups representing the Gigantomachia, the battle of the Amazons and Athenians, the battle with the Medes at Marathon, the destruction of the Galatians in Mysia: Paus. 1.25.2; IG II² 1035 lines 25-26; “doubtless dedicated by Attalos I,” Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 322; Chr. Habicht, “Athens and the Attalids in the Second Century B.C.,” Hesperia 59 (1990) 562-563 with notes 8-9; Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part 1, 1995, 66-68 and Part II, vol. 2, 2000, 232-244 with figs. 73-84, 258; A. Stewart, Attalos, Athens and the Akropolis: The Pergamene Little Barbarians,” and their Roman and Renaissance Legacy,” with an Essay on the Pedestals and the Akropolis South Wall by Manolis Korres, Cambridge, 2004 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Attalos I and Attalos II of Pergamon sculpture

names.toponym: Attalos I and Attalos II of Pergamon sculpture

descriptions.value: Attalos I and Attalos II of Pergamon: Dionysos in the Gigantomachia group linked to Mark Antony as New Dionysos: Plu. Ant. 60.2; T. Holscher, “Die Geschlagenen und Ausgelieferten in der Kunst des Hellenismus,” Antike Kunst 28 (1985) 123-128 cf. Athena Ath45* (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Attalos of Pergamon, eponymous hero (Paus. 1.5.5 + Paus. 1.8.1)

descriptions.value: Attalos I and Attalos II of Pergamon: Attalos I, statue as Eponymous Hero, 200 B.C.: Paus. 1.5.5 + Paus. 1.8.1; Habicht, Chr. 1982, 109-110, 145 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Atticus: House near the Theater: Philostr. VS 2.1.2, cf. Philostr. VS 1.21.7: W. Ameling, op. cit., I, 18-19, 21-22; Trianti, I 2002, 166 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Atticus: House not far from the place at the Ilissos where Boreas seized Oreithyia: Cic. Leg. 1.3 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Atticus: Statues: Nep. Att. 3.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Autolykos: the pancratiast, statue in the Prytaneion: Paus. 1.18.3, Paus. 9.32.8; Claude Vatin, ' Un athlete athenien a Delphes: Autolycus,” in Hommages a Lucien Lerat, Paris, 1984, 842-843 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Axiochos: Alkibiadesʼ uncle, house near the Itonian Gate by the stele of the Amazon: Pl. Ax. 364-5; Delorme, J. 1960, 47 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Barathron: place-name (from the generic term), cleft on the Hill of the Nymphs west slope into which criminals were thrown: Hdt. 7.133; Milchhöfer, A. 1891, 1-11 s.v. Barathron; Judeich, W. 1931, 126 note 3, 140 notes 2-3, 168 note 5, 390, 425 notes 2-5, Plan I B/C-5; according to Judeichʼs plan the barathron was approximately at the junction of Kymaion and Demophontos Sts. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Basileion: meeting-place of the Phylobasileis, beside the Boukoleion: Poll. 8.111; Judeich, W. 1931, 63, 296, 298-299 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Batrachioun: lawcourt: FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 165 and II, 146, frg. 59 note 1; Paus. 1.28.8; possibly one of the structures under the Square Peristyle (Part II no. 346), Agora_XXVIII, 92 and Index s.v. Batrachioun (Green Court) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Berossos of Babylon: priest-historian, 4th-3rd c. B.C., statue in a gymnasium: Plin. Nat. 7.123; cf. Paus. 10.12.9; P. Schnabel, Berossos, Berlin, 1923, 250 (testimonia) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Blaute: place-name: Hsch. s.v. Βλαύτη; Beschi, L. 1967/1968b, 519-520; see Heroes Hro12* (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Boreas: Sanctuary on the Ilissos [right bank] with an altar at the crossing to Agra mentioned by Sokrates: Pl. Phdr. 229 B-C; A. Jacquemin, «ΒΟΡΕΑΣ Ο ΘΟΥΡΙΟΣ,» BCH 103 (1979) 190; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Boreas: Place at the Ilissos where Boreas seized Oreithyia: Paus. 1.19.5; Neuser, K. 1982, 32 note 71, testimonia (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Boukoleion: early headquarters of the Basileus, near the Prytaneion: Arist.Ath. 3.5; Agora_III, nos. 582,588; Judeich, W. 1931, 63, 286, 296, 297 note 1, 298; conjecturally located on the Akropolis North Slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 16; cf. Bull, architectural relief (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Bouleuterion: 1) “First Bouleuterion” founded by Theseus in the asty: Plu. Thes. 24.3; probably on the Eleusinion site, Travlos, J. 1971, 198. Testimonia for meetings of the Council in the Eleusinion, Agora_III, nos. 191, 211-213 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Bouleuterion: 3) “Old Bouleuterion”, built after 479 B.C., in which the state cult of the Mother of the Gods was incorporated ca. 410-400 B.C.: Agora_III, 128-137; Athenian Agora 1986, 52-53, figs. 32-33, 27-31; T. L. Shear, Jr., “The Persian Destruction of Athens: Evidence from Agora Deposits,” Hesperia 62 (1993) 418-427, figs. 1-4; Shear Jr., T. L., 1995, 15-171, figs. 1-5; [implausibly] restored as an early octastyle temple of the Mother of the Gods, Miller, S. G. 1995, 133-156, figs. 1-6; [the Old Bouleuterion” continued functioning as the Council House (see Arist.Ath. 53.4) until ca. 140 B.C. when it was torn down to make way for the Metroon] (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Bouleuterion: 4) “New Bouleuterion”, built 410-400 B.C.: Paus. 1.3.5, Paus. 1.5.1, 10.19.5; Thompson, H. A. 1937,140-160, figs. 77-87,89-94, pls. 6-8; Shear Jr., T. L. 1995, 178-189, fig. 5; [the “New Bouleuterion” functioned as an annex for storing archives until ca. 140 B.C. when, the Old Bouleuterion” having been torn down to make way for the Metroon, it was fitted out with benches to serve as the Bouleuterion] (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Boutadai: deme name: Plu. Moralia 841 B; along the Sacred Way near Lakiadai, Traill, J. S. 1986, 133 with Map; Siewert, P. 1982, 40 note 22, 41; see Eteoboutad priests (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Boutes: Altar for the hero Boutes in the Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.5; H. von Geisau, KP 1, 1964, 974-975 ( s.v. Butes 1); conjecturally [rightly] located in the Erechtheion east chamber [but the cylindrical form restored in fig. 281 is highly improbable], Travlos, J. 1971, 213, fig. 281 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Bouzyges and Bouzygion: Bouzygesʼ plough dedicated on the Akropolis: schol. Aeschin. 2.78; Johrens, G. 1981, 113 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Boxmakers: or chest makers, name of a street or district through which Sokrates walked when his daimonion saved him from colliding with a herd of pigs: Plu. Moralia 580 E; [the context indicates that Sokrates was walking down the western side of the Akropolis lower north slope] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Brazen Threshold: descent to the underworld: S. OC 57 with schol. S. OC 1590 and schol. S. OC 1592; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, no. 325, 195, lines 6-11; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Brutus and Cassius: M. Iunius Brutus (RE Iunius 53) and C. Cassius Longinus, bronze statues in the Agora flanking Harmodios and Aristogeiton: D.C. 47.20.4; Holscher, T. 1975, 188 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Bulls: Bull dedicated by the Council of the Areopagus on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.2; Judeich, W. 1931, 241 note 1; Stevens, G. P. 1940, 19-24, figs. 1, 15Q, 16, 17, 20 Q; [ if Pausanias hadn't told us, who would ever have guessed that they had dedicated a bull?] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Bulls: Bronze bull led to sacrifice, in front of the temple of Triptolemos: Paus. 1.14.4; H. A. Shapiro,, “The Marathonian Bull on the Athenian Akropolis,” AJA 92 (1988) 376 no. 1; Agora_XXXI, 52 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Calydonian (?) Boar: sculpture on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.27.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Centaurs: Centaur family, copy of a picture by Zeuxis: Lucian, Zeux. 3-7, 12; Geschwantler, K. 1978, 1482-1483 no. 6; LIMC VIII, 1997, 698-699 no. 326, s.v. Kentauroi et Kentaurides (L. Palaiokrassa) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Centaurs: Centauromachy, picture of the fight between the centaurs and the Lapiths in the Theseion: 'Theseus has already killed a centaur,” Paus. 1.17.2; Brommer, F. 1982, 109 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Chabrias: State-financed burial monument costing a thousand drachmas, 357/6 B.C., on the Road to the Academy: Ath. 4.165 (F); Paus. 1.29.3; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Chalkodon: of Euboia, father of Elephenor, heroon at the Peiraic Gate: Plu. Thes. 27.3 + Plu. Thes. 35.3; cf. Paus. 8.15.6, Paus. 9.19.3; LIMC III, 1986, 187-188, Chalkodon (E. Simon); Kearns, E. 1989, 206 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Chalkosthenesʼ Workshop: for terracotta statuary, in the Kerameikos: Plin. Nat. 35.155; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. 1, 269 with note 9 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Chariot and Fetters: Renewed ca. 455 B.C. with an inscribed Pentelic marble base — IG I³ 501 = IG I² 394 I; seen on the left as you enter the Propylaia, Hdt. 5.77; seen near Athena Promachos, Paus. 1.28.2; no reason to date the replacement as late as 455 B.C., Keesling, C. M. 1995, 27-28 with note 62; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Chariot and Fetters: The fetters, suspended from walls burnt by the Medes, opposite the megaron facing west.: Hdt. 5.77; Bancroft, S. 1980, 5-7, 15 with note 30; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Charites: Sanctuary at the Akropolis entrance: schol. Ar. Nu. 773; [doubtably] associated with Athena Nike, Beschi, L. 1967/1968b, 535-536; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Charites: Three draped Charites by Sokrates son of Sophroniskos seen by Pausanias after he saw the Propylaia northwest wing: Paus. 1.22.8, Paus. 9.35.2-3 + 7; Agora_XI, 122-3; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 74-75; possibly on New Style silver tetradrachms, 122/1 B.C., Herzog, H. 1996, 36-39 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Charites: Statues in the sanctuary of the Muses at the Academy: D.L. 4.1; FGRHIST III B, 159, Philochoros 328 F 224 with suppl. vol. I., 589-591; Billot. M.-F. 1989, 742-744 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Charmides: house beside the Olympieion where Alkibiades profaned the Mysteries: And. 1.16; W. K. Pritchett, “The Attic Stelai, Part I,” Hesperia 22 (1953) 230 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Chrysa: sanctuary (?) on Pnyx Hill: Plu. Thes. 27.3; FGRHIST III B, 56-7, Kleidemos 323 F 18, with suppl. vol. 1.77; LIMC III, 1986, 279-281, s.v. Chryse I (H. Froning) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Chrysippos: Grave on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.15; probably a state-financed burial, Stupperich, R. 1977, 21 note 4, 263 note 4 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Chrysippos: Statue in the Kerameikos, almost hidden by an equestrian statue: Cic. Fin. 1.11.39 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Chrysippos: Statue in the Ptolemaion: Paus. 1.17.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Chrysous Stenopos: (Χρυσους στενοπόυς), name of an alley: Alciphr. 3.5.1, Paus. 4.14.7 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

City Wall, Pre-Persian: Hdt. 9.13, cf. Paus. 7.25.2; R. G. A. Weir, “The lost Archaic Wall around Athens,” Phoenix 49 (1995) 247-258; conjectural version of the line of the wall, Travlos, J. 1971, 158, 261, fig. 5 no. 20 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Claudius Marcellus, M.: Grave monument commissioned by Cicero in nobilissima orbis terrarum gymnasio Academiae, 45 B.C.: Servius Sulpicius Rufus in Cic. Fam. 4.12.3; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 729 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Comic Poets: picture or pictures in the Pompeion: Plin. Nat. 35.140 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Constantine: statue as strategos with epigram set up by the Athenians: Jul. Or. 1.8.CD; Agora_XXIV, 16 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Court Beside the Walls: lawcourt: Ar. V. 1107 ff.; a topic eliciting [confusing] conjectures, Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v Walls, Court by the (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Court Near Lykos: lawcourt: Poll. 8.121; suggested location at the poros limestone benches (Part II no. 176) set into the east slope of Kolonos Agoraios, Agora 1995, 14, 188-191 and Index s.v. Lykos; cf. Heroes Hro20*; Part II no. 276; [this lawcourt was probably on the east side of the Agora with the other dikasteria] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Court of Metiochos: lawcourt: Pollux 8.121; FGRHIST III B, 74, Androtion 324 F 59 with suppl. vols. I, 164,7 and II, 148, 150, 152-3; Davies, J. K. 1971, 308; Agora_XXVIII, 177-178 and Index s.v. Metiocheion, Metiochos (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Cow: bronze sculpture by Myron on the Akropolis: Tz. H. 8.370-374; G. Lippold, RE XVI, 1933, col. 1126-1127 (Myron); Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 50-51 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Daidalos: Folding stool made by Daidalos in the Temple of the Polias: Paus. 1.27.1; Ole Wanscher, Sella Curulis, Copenhagen, 1980, 86-87; Kearns, E. 1989, 184, Daidalos (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Dekeleiansʼ: meeting-place at the barbershop near the Herms: Lys. 23.2-3; Agora_III, no. 306; Hedrick Jr., C. W., 1990, 46-47, 54-55 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Demades: son of Demeas, bronze statue in the Agora, ca. 335 B.C.: Din. 1.101; Wolfgang Will, Athen und Alexander, München, 1983, 59 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Demeter: Temple near the Pompeion: Paus. 1.2.4 (twice); Kerameikos X, 171 note 369 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Demeter: Sanctuary on the Sacred Way to Eleusis: Paus. 1.37.2; S. Dow and R. F. Healey, S. J. 1965, 39-41; see Athena Ath130* (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Demeter: Temple of Demeter and Kore in the Eleusinion: “above the Enneakrounos”, Paus. 1.14.1; Agora_I 5165 line 12; Agora_XXXI, 43, 44, 49 with note 35, 51, 198 no. 35 (= Agora_I 5165); (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Demeter: Demeter and Kore and Iakchos, statues by Praxiteles according to the inscription on the wall in a temple near the Pompeion: Paus. 1.2.4; LIMC IV, 1988, 879 no. 415, s.v. Demeter (L. Beschi); for the inscr., see H. Whittaker, “Pausanias and his Use of Inscriptions” Symbolae Osloensis 66 (1991) 183-186 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Demeter Achaia: Sanctuary of the Gephyraioi: Hdt. 5.61; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. II, 500 note 16 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Demeter Chloe: sanctuary at the entrance to the Akropolis: Paus. 1.22.3; Milchhöfer, A. 1891, 25; Wycherley, R. E. 1966, 290-291; conjecturally located on the Akropolis upper west slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 8 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Demetrios of Phaleron: Bronze statue on the Akropolis, (317-307 B.C.), the only statue of Demetrios not destroyed: D.L. 5.77; R. von den Hoff, “Tradition and innovation: portraits and dedications on the early Hellenistic Akropolis,” in Macedonians in Athens 2003, 175

Demosion Sema: State Burial Ground for those fallen in battle by sea or land, on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.4-16; SEG_25 56 (1971); Stupperich, R. 1977, 26-33; Pritchett, W. K. 1985, 95, 103-104, 105-124, 139-140, 145-151, 153-241 passim; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1985, 770-786; Pritchett W. K. 1998, 1-60; SEG 51 (2005) nos. 49-50. For photographs of the Demosion Sema inscriptions, see C. W. Clairmont, Patria Nomos, 1983
[The Demosion Sema was between two roads to the Academy, the Dipylon-Academy Road (Part II no. 565) and the road through the Leokoriou St. Gate (Part II no. 566). Most of the stelai were illegally excavated from ca. 1850 onwards and broken up to be reused as building material. The records of the Archaeological Society and the Agora Excavation field notebooks show that no fragment of a Demosion Sema inscription was ever found in the Post-Herulian Wall pace S. Alipheri, «Τά διεσπαρμένα μνημεία ως πηγές για την καταστροφή τού Δημοσίου Σήματος,» Horos 10-12 (1992-1998) 183-203, pl. 35 = SEG_46 73 (1996)] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eleos: (Philanthropia, “Pity” ), altar mentioned by Pausanias, after he described the Stoa Poikile and before he saw the Gymnasium of Ptolemy: Paus. 1.17.1; Agora_III, 67-74, nos. 163-190; an [imaginary] Altar of Pity [supposedly] seen by Pausanias by the Altar of the Twelve Gods, Travlos, J. 1971, 458; on the Akropolis Lower North Slope east of the Agora, E. Vanderpool, “The ‘Agora' of Pausanias Paus. 1.17.1-2,” Hesperia 43 (1974) 308-310 Called altar of Misericordia: Sen. Con. 10.5.10 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eleos: Called altar of Clementia dedicated to none of the powerful gods, set in a laurel and olive tree grove: Stat. Th. 481-482, 491-492; cf. Agora_XIV, 134-136 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Eleusinion: Akropolis northwest slope on the Panathenaic Way: Paus. 1.14.3; Agora_III, 1 74-85; Agora_Guide 1990, 152-153, 194, 277 no. 152, figs. 8, 19, 98; Agora_XXXI, The City Eleusinion, 1998 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Eleusinion: Precinct wall, 5th c. B.C.: Th. 2.17.1 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eleusinion: Altar: And. 1.110 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eleusinion: Bronze horse with reliefs on the base made by Demetrios of Alopeke, 5th-4th c. B.C., set up at the Eleusinion by Simon, author of a work on horsemanship: X. Eq. 1.1; Plin. Nat. 34.76; Agora_III, no. 204; H. R. Breitenbach, KP 5, 1975, 202 (s.v. Simon no. 1); Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 89-90; most probably Simon the hipparch of 425/4 B.C., Bugh, G. R. 1988, 91 with note 35, 227 no. 447; [mistakenly] described as an equestrian statue, T. Schafer, “Ein Schlachtfries von der Akropolis,” AM 115 (2000) 312-313 with notes 56-58 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Elpiasʼ School: where Aischinesʼ father taught letters, beside the Theseion: D. 18.129; Agora_III, no. 347 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Empedo: earlier name for the Klepsydra spring: schol. Ar. Lys. 913; Parsons, A. W. 1943, 201-207, 265-266; an [unattested imaginary] “shrine of Empedo” at the Klepsydra site, Travlos, J. 1971, 323; cf. Nymphaion, boundary stone (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Enneakrounos: Fountain house at Kallirrhoe spring: Th. 2.15.4-5; at the Ilissos northeast of Haghia Photini, Judeich, W. 1931, 49, 55 note 4, 59, 65, 141 note 1,193-201, 420, Plan I at H-7; Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1986, 55-73 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Enyo: statue in the temple of Ares, by the sons of Praxiteles: Paus. 1.8.4; LIMC III, 1986, 746-747, no. 1, s.v. Enyo I (R. M. Gais); Hartswick, K. J. 1990, 258-259; see Ares Enyalios (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Ephialtes: state-financed grave mon. on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.15; Stupperich, R. 1977, 249-250; Taylor, M. W. 1991,12 note 21, 96 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Epicharinos: the hoplite runner, inscribed base of statue by Kritios and Nesiotes, ca. 470 B.C., between the Propylaia and the Parthenon - - - IG I³ 847 = IG I² 531; Acr. 13248; Paus. 1.23.9 (naming Kritias as the sculptor, seen after he saw the Trojan horse); Raubitschek, A. E. 1949, no. 20, ph.; SEG_33 25 (1983); Keesling, C. M. 2000, 15, 29, 66, 170, 171-172, 196 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Epicurus: Garden between the Dipylon Gate and the Academy: Cic. Fin. 5.1.3; G. S. Dontas, «Εικονιστικά Β',» Deltion 26 (1971) A, 18-33, 319; [although all of the diagnostic finds turned up at or near 61 Marathonos St. along an ancient street (Part II no. 608) connecting the two roads to the Academy, the excavator did not accept the site as Epicurusʼ Garden]; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Epicurus: Inscription at the entrance to the Garden: Sen. Ep. 21.10 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Epicurus: House in Melite: Cic. Att. 5.19.3, Fam. 13.1.3; D.L. 10.17; G. S. Dontas, op. cit., 22-23 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Epilykeion: the Polemarcheion renamed after Epilykos the polemarch who rebuilt it: Arist.Ath. 3.5; Agora_III, 177-178 no. 582; Develin, R. 1989, 34; conjectural location on the Akropolis North Slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 17 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Epimenides of Knossos: seated statue in the Eleusinion: Paus. 1.14.4; Agora_XXXI, 3, 52 note 48, 53; cf. FGRHIST III B, no. 457, Epimenides von Kreta, 388 lines 7-12 with commentary, 319 (d) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eponymoi: 1st monument, 5th c. B.C.; Ar. Pax 1183-4; conjectural location beneath the western end of the Middle Stoa, T. L. Shear, Jr., “The Monument of the Eponymous Heroes in the Athenian Agora,” Hesperia 39 (1970) 203-222, figs. 16-17; conjectural location near the Prytaneion, Travlos, J. 1971, 210; location beneath the Middle Stoa western end rejected, Kron, U. 1976, 229-232; cf. the 1998 plan of the remains under the west end of the Middle Stoa, J. McK. Camp, Hesperia 68 (1999) 256 fig. 1 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Eponymous Heroes (Athens Agora) (Paus. 1.5.1-5 + Paus. 1.8.2, cf. Paus. 1.29.6)

descriptions.value: Eponymoi: 2nd monument, originally ten statues with a tripod at either end, enclosed by a fence, 350-325 B.C., east of the Metroon: Paus. 1.5.1-5 + Paus. 1.8.2, cf. Paus. 1.29.6; Agora_Guide 1990, 69-72, 274 no. 79, figs. 7, 19 no. 30, 20a, 33-34; C. Vatin, “La base des Heros eponymes a Athenes au temps de Pausanias,” Ostraka IV (1995) 33-41, figs. 1-8; [in view of the Samos horos (Agora_III, 90), the tripods and the fence, this must be a temenos] (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Erechtheion: 421 B.C. (construction may have started as early as ca. 431 B.C.) - 406/405 B.C., modern name for the building comprising the classical temple of Athena Polias and the Erechtheion (in ancient times the name for part of the building, never the whole building): IG I³ 474-479 (building accounts 409/8-405 B.C.); SEG_51 39 bis (2005); IG II² 1654; Paus. 1.26.5 - Paus. 1.27.2; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927; Hurwit, J. M. 1999, 380 Erechtheum; shown on Athenian imperial bronzes, Price, J. M. and B. L. Trell 1977, 68 fig. 130, 76 figs. 130-131, 77; [extensively rebuilt in the 2nd c. A.C.]; cf. A. Frantz, “Did Julian the Apostate Rebuild the Parthenon,” AJA 83 (1979) 396 note 9; see Chr. Mon. CM9* (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Erechtheion: The classical temple of Athena Polias, ancient names:
Temple on the Akropolis in which is the Old Statue: IG I³ 474 line 1; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 298-299
Old Temple of the Polias: Str. 9.1.16, C 396; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 475-476 Temple of Athena: Paus. 1.27.2 + 4
Temple of the Polias: Paus. 1.27.1 + 3; according to J. H. Oliverʼs reading of IG II² 1076 lines 21-22, the temple was probably rededicated to Julia Domna as Athena Polias: J. H. Oliver, “Julia Domna as Athena Polias,” HSCP Suppl. Vol. I, 1940, 525-6
Temple of Pallas Minerva: Vitr. 4.8.4; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 476-477
The Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.5, referring to a two-level unit, twice called oikema, in the eastern part of the building; cf. Euphiletosʼ house (oikidion diploun), Erechtheus cuius Athenis et delubrum vidimus et sacerdotem: Cic. N.D. 3.49; cf. Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 480-492; Part II no.60 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Erechtheion Golden Lamp: with bronze palm tree chimney made for Athena by Kallimachos: Paus. 1.26.6-7; O. Palagia, “A Niche for Kallimachosʼ Lamp?”, AJA 88 (1984) 516-521, figs. 1-3, pls. 66-67; W. Fuchs, “Paralipomena: II. Der Chrysos Lychnos im Erechtheion,” in Kotinos 1992, 201-203 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Erechtheus: Grave: E. Ion 281; ibid., 43-48 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Erechtheus: House on the Akropolis: Od. 7.81; Kron, U. 32-33; Mazarakis Ainian, A. 1997, 368, 392 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Erechtheus: Picture in the Erechtheion, E. driving a chariot: schol. Aristid. 13.107; LIMC IV, 1988, 936 no. 52, s.v. Erechtheus (U. Kron) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Erechtheus: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2; ibid., 942-943 no. 81 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Erechtheus: Statue by Myron in Athens: Paus. 9.30.1, possibly = Erechtheus fighting Eumolpos q.v. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Erechtheus: Temple (or sanctuary) on the Akropolis in which were the olive tree and the thalassa: Hdt. 8.55; Kron, U. 1976, 40-41 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Erechtheus: Erechtheus fighting Eumolpos (or Immarados), large bronze sculpture group on the Akropolis near the temple of Athena: Paus. 1.27.4, cf. Paus. 1.5.2; Kron, U. 1976, 50, 77; LIMC III, 1986, 269, s.v. Chione 1 (U. Kron); LIMC IV, 1988, 940 no. 69, s.v. Erechtheus (U. Kron); [doubtably] thought to be part of a 4-figure group with Tolmides and his seer, C. Ioakimidou, Die Statuenreihen griechischer Poleis und Bunde aus spatarchaischer und klassischer Zeit, Munchen, 1997, 99-100, 262-273 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eretria: earlier name for what was the Agora in Straboʼs time: Str. 10.1.10; thought to be the area of the Roman Agora, Travlos, J. 1971, 28 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Erichthonios: grave in the temple of the Polias: Clem. Al. Protr. 3.39; Agora_III, nos. 194-195; Kearns, E. 1989, 160 -161; “The appearance and definition of Erichthonius appeared in the 5th c. B.C.,” Mikalson, J. D. 1976, 141-142 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Eridanos River: Paus. 1.19.5; Camp, J. McK. 1980, 20, 289, 290, 293-294 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Eros at the Academy: Altar with epigram stating that Charmos was the first Athenian to dedicate an altar to Eros, at the Academy Gymnasium: Paus. 1.30.1; in Sokratesʼ dream, Apul. Pl. 1.1; Riginos, A. S. 1976, 21-24 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Eros at the Academy: Statue dedicated by Peisistratos in the Academy where those in the sacred torch race light their torches: Plu. Sol. 1.4; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 72; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 390-391 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eros: Eros wearing a wreath of roses, picture by Zeuxis in the temple of Aphrodite: schol. Ar. Ach. 992; Geschwantler, K. 1978, col. 1482 no. 2 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Eros: Statue by Praxiteles with an epigram by Praxiteles on the base, in the Theatre of Dionysos: Ath. 591 a-b; cf. Paus. 1.20.1-3 (the story about Phryne); H. Lauter, “Zur wirtschaftlichen Position der Praxiteles-Familie im spatklassischen Athen,”, AA 1980, 529-530; SEG 47 (1997) nos. 206, 518 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eros and Dionysos: sculpture by Thymilos: Paus. 1.20.2; A. H. Borbein, “Die griechische Statue des 4. Jahrhunderts v. Chr.,” Jahrbuch 88 (1973) 196-197 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Eteoboutad Priests of Poseidon: Wall paintings of the genos of the Boutadai: Paus. 1.26.5 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Eteoboutad Priests of Poseidon: Picture showing members of Lykourgosʼ family who were priests of Poseidon, including Habron handing the trident to his brother Lykophron, painted on wood by Ismenias of Chalkis, dedicated by Habron, son of Lykourgos [II] in the Erechtheion: Plu. Moralia 843 F (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Euboulides Monument: statue or statue group in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.4-5; Despinis, G. 1995, 321-337, pls. 62-68; Aneziri, S. 2000, 266-267, 276-279; see Apollo Apo12*-13* (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Euboulos: Grave [at public expense] on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.10; Habicht, Chr. 1979,9 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Eudanemoi: altar, opposite to the Metroon and not far from Harmodios and Aristogeiton in the Agora: Arr. An. 3.16.8; Agora_XIV, 157-158; Kearns, E. 1989, 163; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eukleia: Eukleia, temple in honour of the victory at Marathon, still farther off from the temple of Triptolemos: Paus. 1.14.5; Agora_III, 58-59; Freeden, J. von 1983, 12 with note 56; [the temple is on top of the Areopagus] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Eumenes II of Pergamon: Colossal statues of Eumenes and Attalos relabelled Antonius: Plu. Ant. 60.3; Chr. Habicht, “Athens and the Attalids in the Second Century B.C.,” Hesperia 59 (1990) 572 with notes 62-63 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eumenes II of Pergamon: Stoa of Eumenes, 197-160/59 B.C., Akropolis South Slope: Vitr. 5.9.1; Travlos, J. 1971, 523-526, figs. 660-664; Korres, M. 1983, 201-207, figs. 1-3; Chr. Habicht, op. cit., 563 with note 10; Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 62-63; see Dionysos Dio39* (reused geisa); (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Eumenides: at Kolonos Hippios, precinct: S. OC. 38-43, 84-101, 125-137, 155-165, 466-506; Apollod. 3.5.9; Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 389-395; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Euripides: Cenotaph on the Road from Peiraeus: Paus. 1.2.2; M. R. Lefkowitz, “The Euripides Vita”, GRBS 20 (1979) 190, 203; Further Greek Epigrams 1981, 307-308 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Euripides: Statue in the Theatre: Paus. 1.21.1; Gauer, W. 1968b,134-135 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Eurykleides: ventriloquist seer, statue in the Theatre: Ath. 1.19 the passage in Athenaeus refers to Eurykles of Athens, E. H. Musirillo, S. J., “The Problem of Lying and Deceit and the Two Voices of Euripidesʼ Hippolytus 925-31,” TAPA 104 (1974) 237-238 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Eurymedon: of Myrrhinos, one of Platoʼs executors, property or properties in Eiresidai, adjoining Platoʼs property, mentioned in Platoʼs will: D.L. 3.42; Davies, J. K. 1971, 334-5; Eurymedonʼs property perhaps adjoined Platoʼs Garden, Lynch, J. P. 1972, 126 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Eurysakes: son of Aias, temenos on Kolonos Agoraios in Melite: Harp. s.v. Μελίτη and Κολωνέτας; Agora_III, 90-93, 225; Ferguson, W. S. 1938, 15-16; Kron, U. 1976, 138, 172-174; Kearns, E. 1989, 70-71, 82, 107-108, 164 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Eurysakes: Altar: Paus. 1.35.3; Agora_III, no. 248 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Evagoras: king of Salamis in Cyprus, statue in front of the Stoa of Zeus, decreed in 393 B.C.: Paus. 1.3.2; D. M. Lewis and R. S. Stroud, “Athens Honors King Euagoras of Salamis,” Hesperia 48 (1979) 187, 192-193; Lawton, C. L. 1995, 122 no. 184 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Favorinus of Arles: bronze statue: Philostr. VS 1.8.3; Ameling, W. 1983,1,45-47 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Fides: temple: Plautus Aul. 583; E. Bernet, RE XX,1950, col. 1812 (Pistis) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Fountain House: “in the osiers” where Phrynichos was murdered: Lycurg. Leocr. 112; Agora_III, 132 under no. 405, 142 under no. 455; H. Thompson, H. A. 1937, 213 note 4; Agora_XIV, 201 note 48 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Gardens: place-name, seen by Pausanias between Apollo Delphinios and Kynosarges: Paus. 1.19.2; see Aphrodite Aph32* (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Ge: statue in the sanctuary of the Semnai: Paus. 1.28.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Ge Karpophoros: statue of Ge praying to Zeus to rain on her at a time of drought, with a rock-cut inscription which must predate Pausaniasʼ visit ca. 150 A.D., Akropolis — IG II² 4758; Paus. 1.24.3: Stevens, G. P. 1946a, 1-4, fig. 3 no. 1, fig. 4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Ge Kourotrophos: Altar established by Erichthonios: Suid. s.v. Κουρότροφος; W. Ferguson, W. S. 1938, 21; Mikalson, J. D. 1976, 144 note 12 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Ge Kourotrophos: Sanctuary between Aphrodite Pandemos and the Propylaia: Paus. 1.22.3; Beschi, L. 1967/1968b, 517-528; [mistaken] conjectural location on the Akropolis upper west slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 7 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Ge Olympia: temenos within the Olympieion precinct: Paus. 1.18.7; Thuc. 11.15.4 (sanct. of Ge without the epithet); Judeich, W. 1931, 58-59, 385-6; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Ge Olympia: Cleft inside the temenos where Deukalionʼs flood drained away: Paus. 1.18.7; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 400 with note 3; Wickens, J. M. 1986, 317-318; [implausibly] located in the temple of Zeus Olympios, Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1994, 91,122,123,129-130,159,167 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Geraistos: the Kyklops, grave where Hyakinthosʼ daughters were sacrificed in obedience to an oracle: Apollod. 3.15.8; Mikalson, J. D. 1976, 145; Petterson, M. 1992, 35; cf. Hyakinthos (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Glaukopion: old name for the Akropolis or for Athenaʼs sanctuary on the Akropolis: schol. E. Hipp. 33; Milchhöfer, A. 1891., 4 s.v. (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hadrian: Gymnasium: Paus. 1.18.9; Kokkou, A. 1970, 165-167, fig. 5, pl. 53b; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 134-143; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

relations.label: in or near Library of Hadrian

descriptions.value: Hadrian: Library, a peristyle court with rooms (oikemata) for books, bounded by Dexippou, Areos, Pandrosou, Aiolou and Adrianou Sts. ( Plan 1 beta/gamma—5/6, no. 73) Paus. 1.18.9; Eusebius, Hieronymi Chronicon, ed. Heim, 1956, 282,16; Travlos, J. 1971, 244-252, 579, figs. 314-324; housing the cadastral archives of the province of Achaia, P. Castren, “General Aspects of Life in Post-Herulian Athens,” in Castren, P., ed. 1994, 2-4, 12; [mis]interpreted as the “Forum of Hadrian,” A. Karivieri, “The Library of Hadrian and the Tetraconch Church,” in Castren, op. cit., 89-113, figs. 1-4, 10; Tinginanka, I. 2003, 285-326 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
