Hadrian: Res Gestae, inscription recording Hadrianʼs good deeds, in the sanctuary of All The Gods: Paus. 1.5.5; Benjamin, A. S. 1963, 59 note 19 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hadrian: Statues set up by colony-cities at the Olympieion IG II² 3289-3307+; Paus. 1.18.6; A. S. Benjamin, op. cit., 58-59; SEG 21 (1965) no. 704 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hadrian: Statue in the Parthenon: Paus. 1.24.7; [inside the Parthenon Pausanias reports only the Athena Parthenos and the portrait statue of Hadrian in contrast to the many antiquities he saw inside the Erechtheion] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hadrian: Four statues, two of Thasian and two of Egyptian stone, at the approach to the Olympieion: Paus. 1.18.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hadrian: Colossal statue behind the temple of Zeus Olympios dedicated by the Athenians: Paus. 1.18.6; cf. fragment of a colossal male statue, A. S. Rousopoulos, «Έπιγραφαι έλληνικαι και δσα άλλα αρχαία εύρέθησαν έν ταΐς περι τό Όλύμπιον άνασκαφαις,» ΑΕ 1862, 50 no. 8; Willers, D. 1990, 46, pl. 6:1-2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hadrian: Statue as Eponymous Hero, 124/125 A.D.: Paus. 1.5.5; T. L. Shear, Jr., “The Monument of the Eponymous Heroes in the Athenian Agora,” Hesperia 39 (1970) 181-186, 201-203, pl. 45; Willers, D. 1990, 68-69 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Hadrian: Statue with cuirass reliefs of Athena standing on the wolf suckling Romulus and Remus, found as a cover slab of the Great Drain near its original position in front of the Stoa of Zeus, Agora_S 166; Paus. 1.3.2; T. L. Shear, “The Sculpture,”, Hesperia 2 (1933) 178-183, figs. 8-10, pl. VI; Agora_vI, 71-74, pls. 36-37; Agora_Guide 1990, 66-67, 274 no. 66, fig. 31 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Harmodios and Aristogeiton: Grave on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.15; state burial monument, site of their hero cult, Michael W. Taylor, op. cit., 5-12,92 note 1, 96; [probably a cenotaph, perhaps established by Perikles] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Harmodios and Aristogeiton sculpture (Paus. 1.8.5, cf. Paus. 8.46.4)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Harmodios and Aristogeiton: Statue group by Antenor, between the temple of Ares and the Odeion of Agrippa: Paus. 1.8.5, cf. Paus. 8.46.4; S. Brunnsaker, The Tyrant-slayers of Kritios and Nesiotes, Stockholm, 1971, 39-40 (testimonia),40-45, 90-98, 110-112, 115-6, 121, 125 note 2, 131, 132, 135; the group removed by Xerxes was returned to Athens by Alexander the Great according to Arrian and Pliny, by Seleukos according to Valerius Maximus, by Antiochos [IV?] according to Pausanias (Agora_III, nos. 260,270, 272,277); Habicht, Chr. 1989, 7-8 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Harmodios and Aristogeiton: Statue group by Kritios and Nesiotes, 477/6 B.C.: Marmor Parium 70; Paus. 1.8.5; (as in the case of Epicharinos Pausanias names Kritias as the sole sculptor) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hebe: Altar in the sanctuary of Herakles called Kynosarges: Paus. 1.19.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hekataia, Hekate: Hekate Epipyrgidia, statue beside the Athena Nike temple: Paus. 2.30.2; Agora_XI, Index s.v. Alkamenes; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hekataia, Hekate: Hekate Triglanthine, statue at a place called Trigla; Ath. 7.323 (325 D); FAC II, 1959, 370, 634 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Helen: picture by Zeuxis in the Stoa Alphitopolis: Eust._Iliad 2.630; Geschwantler, K. 1978, col. 1484 lines 33-43 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Heliaia: lawcourt for trials heard by very large juries: Paus. 1.28.8; Agora_III, 145-146, 147-148, 201 no. 670, 202 no. 672; Μ. H. Hansen, “The Athenian Heliaia from Solon to Aristotle,” Cl et Med 33 (1981-82) 9-10, 115-127; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Heliaia; [mistaken] conjectural location north of the Eleusinion, Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 5 no. 19, fig. 28 (not labelled), fig. 219 (not labelled); (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Heliodoros  Halis (Halaieus?), grave monument on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.1; PAA, vol. 8, 1999, 186 no. 483200; [identified as the Epicurean philosopher close to Hadrian]; cf. SEG_3 226 (1929) and 43 (1993) no. 24; cf. A. R. Birley, Hadrian, London and New York, 1997, 375 s.v. Avidius Heliodorus, C. (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Heliodoros  Halis (Halaieus?), picture in the great temple of Athena [the Parthenon]: Paus. 1.37.1; PAA, vol. 8, 1999, 186 no. 483200; [identified as the Epicurean philosopher close to Hadrian]; cf. SEG_3 226 (1929) and 43 (1993) no. 24; cf. A. R. Birley, Hadrian, London and New York, 1997, 375 s.v. Avidius Heliodorus, C. (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Helios: Helios and The Horai, cult: Porph. Abst. 2.7; L. Deubner, Attische Feste, Berlin 1932, 190-192, 201; Helios and the Horai are listed in lines 12-13 of Acr. 13371, the honorary decree for the priestess of Aglauros, Dontas, G. S. 1983, 52 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hellespont Bridge Cables: dedicated in the sanctuaries: Hdt. 9.121; Gauer, G.1968, 37, 73; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hephaistos: Hephaistos on the Akropolis: Altar in the Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.5; conjecturally [rightly] located in the eastern chamber [but the cylindrical form is highly improbable], Travlos, J. 1971, 213, fig. 281 D (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hephaistos: Temple of Hephaistos: Paus. 1.14.6; Agora_Guide 1990, 39-45, 273 no. 39, with front and back covers and figs. 4-9, 12-19, 37; for a tentative chronology of the construction, see W. F. Wyatt, Jr. and C. N. Edmonson, “The Ceiling of the Hephaisteion,” AJA 88 (1984) 167; see Chr. Mon. CM10* (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Hephaistos: Temple statues of Hephaistos and Athena, 421/0-416/5 B.C.: IG I³ 472 = IG I² 370/1; SEG_44 12 (1994); Paus. 1.14.6; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 66, 251-252; Brommer, F. 1978, 75-90, 238, 243; UMC IV, 1988) 634 no. 67, 651 (A. Jacquemin); LIMC II, 1984, 979 no. 241 (restored drawing), 980 nos. 247, 251, s.v. Athena (P. Demargne); photo of part of the expense accounts, Agora_XIV, pl. 71 :c (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Heptachalkon: at the Themistoklean City Wall between the Peiraic and Sacred Gates: Plu. Sull. 14.1, Moralia 505 B (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hera: Temple burnt by Mardonios on the road to Phaleron: Paus. 1.1.5, Paus. 10.35.2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hera: Earlier temple statue implied by Pausanias: Paus. 1.1.5 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hera: Temple statue by Alkamenes: Paus. 1.1.5; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II.37 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hera Thelxinia: Hsch. s.v. θελξινία; SEG 50 (2000) nos. 19, 1071 sub(2) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Herakleidai: Picture of the Herakleidai supplicating the Athenians, by Pamphilos or Apollodoros: schol. Ar.Pl. 385; Agora_III, no. 58; LIMC IV, 1988, 725 no. 1, s.v. Herakleidai (M, Schmidt) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Herakles: Altar dedicated by Theseus after Herakles rescued him: Ael. VH 4.5 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Herakles: Altar at the Academy: Paus. 1.30.2; Kron, U. 1979, 57 note 41; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 740-741; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Herakles: Sanctuaries of Theseus given to Herakles by Theseus (Herakleia): Plu. Thes. 35.2; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 307-309 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Herakles: Temples and altars of Herakles established by the city of Athens after Herakles died: Aristid. Panath. 174 D (109.7); J. H. Oliver, The Civilizing Power, Philadelphia, 1968, 106 no. 48 (commentary), 157 (text) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Herakles: Herakles fighting Kyknos, Akropolis: Paus. 1.27.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herakles: Herakles strangling snakes, Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herakles: Statue in the Ares precinct: Paus. 1.8.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Herakles Alexikakos: Sanctuary in Melite with statue by Ageladas of Argos: schol. Ar. Ra. 501; [mistaken] location on the Areopagus southwest slope at the Bakcheion site, Travlos, J. 1971, 274-275, fig. 351; [Travlosʼ reconstruction is based on mutually supporting misinterpretations of three pieces of evidence: 1) an inscribed relief (Herakles Hrk43*), muddled up with 2) a cult table base (Part II no. 230), and 3) an inscription mentioning a road from the sanctuary of Herakles Alexikakos to the Agora (Part II no. 600)]; Kron, U. 62-63; Pollitt, J. J. 1990,33; LIMC IV, 1988, 746-747, 789 no. 1282, 791, s.v. Herakles (O. Palagia); Tagalidou, E. 1993, 7-41, 44-45; [doubtably] located “at the upper tier of the shrine of Zeus” on the east slope of the Hill of the Nymphs, Laionae, G. V. 2002, 297 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herakles in Kynosarges: IG I³ 369 line 87; Polemon in Ath. 234d (Herakleion in Kynosarges); Judeich, W. 1931, 422-424; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 120, 124, 129-142 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herakles in Kynosarges: Sanctuary of Herakles called Kynosarges with altar of Herakles: Paus. 1.19.3; the altar of Herakles is paired with that of Hebe q.v. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermaphroditos: Cult in Alopeke: Alciphr. 2.35; M. Delcourt, Hermaphrodite, London, 1961, 49-50; LIMC V, 1990, 269, s.v. Hermaphroditos (A. Ajootian) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hermcarvers: name of a street or district: Plu. Moralia 580 E; Young, R. S. 1951, 139, 151 note 36 [Hesperia 20 (1951) 139]  (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hermes: Altar at the Academy: Paus. 1.30.2; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 742 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hermes: Gymnasium of Hermes near Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; Delorme, J. 1960, 523 s.v. Athenes (g.d'Hermes) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hermes: Wooden statue in the temple of the Polias, concealed in myrtle branches, dedicated by Kekrops: Paus. 1.27.1; U. Kron, “Heilige Steine,” in Kotinos 1992, 57 with note 9 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes: Statue in the sanctuary of the Semnai: Paus. 1.28.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes Agoraios: Altar set up by the hipparch Kallistratos, 413 B.C. (?): Plu. Moralia 844 B; Agora_III, no. 300; Develin, R. 1989, 156 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hermes Agoraios: Bronze statue seen by Pausanias on his way from the sanctuary of Aphrodite Ourania to the Stoa Poikile: Paus. 1.15.1; Agora_XI, 112 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes Amyetos:  statue on the Akropolis: Hsch. s.v. Ἑρμῆς ἀμύητος; Judeich, W. 1931, 225 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes: Hermes Chthonios, cult: schol. Ar. Ach. 1076-7, schol. Ar. Pax 650; Pickard-Cambridge, A. 1968, 3 no. 5, 13-14 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hermes: Hermes Kataibates, cult: schol. Ar. Pax 650 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Hermes Propylaios, sculpture at the entrance to the Akropolis: Paus. 1.22.8; A. Hermary, “A propos de l'Hermes Propylaios de Delos,” BCH 103 (1979) 145-9; J. E. Francis, “Rewriting Attributions: Alkamenes and the Hermes Propylaos,” in ΣΤΕΦΑΝΟΣ 1988, 61-68, fig. 1,1-7; SEG_46 2376 (1996) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes Psithyristes, statue: D. 59.39; FGRHIST III B, Zopyros 336 F 2 with commentary (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermes: Hermes Tetrakephalos by Telesarchides in the Kerameikos: Eust._Iliad 24.336; Agora_III, nos. 314-316 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hermes: Hermes Trikephalos at a road fork in Ankyle: Harp. s.v. Τρικέφαλος; FGRHIST III B, 105, Philochoros 328 F 22 with suppl. vol. 1.313; I. Z. Tzifopoulos, “Hekate? Street: A Horos from Ηλιόκαστρo of Hermione,” Horos 10-12 (1992-1998) 257-258 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hermolykos: the pankratiast, son of Euthoinos, statue, Akropolis: seen on the way from the Propylaia to the Parthenon, Paus. 1.23.10; see Oinobios (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herms: Herms in the Ptolemaion: Paus. 1.17.2; Agora_XI, 109-110 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herms: Herm with hexameter on Agamemnon: Harp. s.v. Έρμαι; Agora_III, no. 305 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Herms: Herm at Aigeusʼ Gate, east of the Delphinion: Plu. Thes. 12.3; Kron, U. 1976, 125 with note 574 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Herms: Herm dedicated by the Aigeis tribe, known as the herm of Andokides, by the Phorbanteion and by Andokidesʼ ancestral house: And. 1.62; Agora_III, nos. 367, 382; [correctly] located southeast of the Agora near the Theseion [i.e. on the Akropolis North Slope], Agora_XI, 117-120 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Herodes Atticus.: Grave in the Panathenaic Stadium with an epitaph, state burial monument, 179 A.D.: Philostr. VS 11.1.15; Tobin, J. 1997, 181-185, figs. 34-35; cf. Welch, K. 1998, 136-141 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

relations.label: in or near Odeion of Herodes Atticus

descriptions.value: Herodes Atticus.: Odeion, memorial to Regilla, ca. 160s A.C., Akropolis South Slope: Paus. 7.20.6; Travlos, J. 1971, 378-386, figs. 492-500; Meinel, R. 1980, 80-117, 417-420, figs. 20-31 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Herodotos: Grave together with Thucydidesʼ grave: Marcellin. Vit. Thuc. 17; dubitandum, O. Luschat, RE Suppl. XII, 1970, 1105-1106 (Thukydides) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Heroes: Heros έπι Βλαυτη: Poll. 7.87; Beschi, L. 1967/68, 519-520; cf. Snake with dedicator Silon (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Heroes: Heros Kalamites, sanctuary: D. 18.129; R. E. Wycherley, “Lenaion”, Hesperia 34 (1965) 73-76; LIMC VIII, 1997, 663, s.v. Kalamites (K. Clinton) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Heroes: Heros Lykos, sanctuary at the lawcourts: Ar. V. 387-394; Agora_XXVIII, 95, 188-191, testimonia nos. 176-185; see Court near Lykos (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Hestia: Statue at the Prytaneion: Paus. 1.18.3; M Gianaiulio, “Edifici pubblici e culti nelle nuove iscrizhione da Entella,” ASNP Xll,3 (1982) 948-949, 959, 960; SEG_32 148 (1982) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hestia: Name of a street in Ankyle: Harp. s.v. τρικέφαλος; FGRHIST III B, 105, Philochoros 328 F 22 with suppl. vol. I, 313; I. Z. Tzifopoulos, “Hekate? Street: A Horos from Ήλιόκαστρο of Hermione,”, Horos 10-12 (1992-1998) 257-258; SEG_46 368 (1996) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Hesychos: hero of the genos Hesychidai who received a preliminary sacrifice of a ram at sacrifices for the Semnai, sanctuary outside of the Enneapylon: schol. S. OC 489; Iakovides, S. 1962, 236 nos. 33-34 (the testimonia); P. Friedlander, RE VIII, 1913, col. 1330-1331 (Hesychos); E. Wust, RE Suppl. VIII, 1956, col. 129 (Erinys) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hiera Syke: Suburb named for the tree, along the Sacred Way: Philostr. VS 2.20.3; Judeich, W. 1931, 177 note 3, 411 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Hikesios: (= Zeus Hikesios) in the sanctuary of Athena on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.20.7; cf. graffiti on vases from summit of Mt. Parnes, SEG_33 244 (1983) d-e (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hipparchos: son of Charmos (or Timarchos), bronze statue on the Akropolis, melted down in 487/6 B.C. to make a stele listing names of aliterioi and traitors including Hipparchos himself: Lycurg. Leocr. 117-118; A. E. Raubitschek, “Leagros,” Hesperia 8 (1939) 155; W. R. Connor, “The Razing of the House in Greek Society,” ΤΑΡΑ 115 (1985) 92 with note 39 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Hipparchsʼ Dedication: 2nd use, early 1st c. A.C., with the inscription copied upside down on the back of the base, on the anta by the Athena Nike terrace stair - - - IG I² 4001b; Paus. 1.22.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hippokratesʼ Palaestra: where Isokrates heard about the battle of Chaironeia: Plu. Moralia 837 E; Delorme, J. 1960, 60-61, 261 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hippolyta: the Amazon, grave stele by the sanctuary of Ge (Olympia): Plu. Thes. 27.4 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hippothoon: son of Poseidon and Alope, Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2; Kron, U. 1976, 177-187 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Homonia: Cult: Alexis fragment 244, in The Fragments of Attic Comedy, ed. J. M. Edmonds, Leiden, 1959, II, 490 = Ath. 11.502b; Theriault, G. 1996, 118-122; SEG_46 2292 (1996) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Horai: sanctuary: Ath. 2.38 C; Ath. 14.72 (656 A); FGRHIST III B,99, 148, Philochoros 328 F 5 and F 173 with suppl. vol. I, 268-271, 546; cf. Paus. 9.35.2; see Helios and Horai (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Hordeonius Lollianus, P.: Statue in the Agora and another statue in a grove which he planted: Philostr. VS 1.23.2; Agora_III, 703 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Horkomosion: where Theseus and the Amazons made a pact, beside the Theseion: Plu. Thes. 27.5; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 78 LL. 30-31; [on the Akropolis North Slope] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Horme: personification of zeal or effort, altar: Paus. 1.17.1, possibly = IG II² 4734, small round altar (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Hybris: stone of, ('Rock of Outrage . . . where the defendant stood') on the Areopagus: Paus. 1.28.5; H. von Geisau, RE Suppl. IX, 1962, col. 1898-1899, (Hybris); Agora_XXVIII, 46 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Hydrophoros: bronze kore dedicated in Athens by Themistokles as epistates of the water supply in Athens before 480 B.C. and rededicated by the Lydians in the Metroon at Sardis: Plu. Them. 31.1; Η. T. Wade-Gery, “Themistoklesʼ Archonship,” BSA 37 (1936-7) 264; Keesling, C. M. 2003, 113 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hygieia: Statue of Hygieia, daughter of Asklepios, on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.23.4, seen by Pausanias together with Athena Hygieia (Athena Ath68*) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Hypereides: Grave in which H. was secretly buried in the family plot outside of the Hippades Gate: Plu. Moralia 849 C-D (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Iakchos: Iakcheion: Plu. Arist. 27.3; F. Graf, Eleusis und die orphische Dichtung Athens ..., Berlin, 1974, 49 note 43, 55 note 22 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Ilissos River: Paus. 1.19.5-6 (6 mentions); Judeich, W. 1931, 48-49, 127 note 2, 205; Camp, J. McK. 1980, testimonia nos. 4, 18, 26, 29, 32, 37; Conwell, D. H. 1993, 209-213 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Ilissos River: Place where Pausanias crossed the Ilissos into Agrai: Paus. 1.19.6; [since Pausanias did not mention Kallirrhoe spring and placed the Enneakrounos in the Agora, he probably crossed the Ilissos some distance upstream from Kallirrhoe which, possibly, had temporarily ceased to deliver water during a drought; cf. Ge Karpophoros] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Immaros: (= Immarados), son of Eumolpos, grave in the Eleusinion: Clem. Al. Protr. 3.39; Agora_III, nos. 194-5; Kearns, E. 1989,114-115, 172; Agora_XXXI, 3, 51-52; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Io: the daughter of Inachos, statue by Deinomenes on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.25.1; LIMC V, 1990, 671 no. 83, s.v. Ιο I (N. Yalouris) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Iolaos: altar in Heraklesʼ sanctuary called Kynosarges: Paus. 1.19.3; Kearns, E. 1989, 172-173 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Iphikrates: Statue at the Parthenon entrance, ca. 389 B.C.: Paus. 1.24.7; Gauthier, Ph. 1985, 26, 97-98, 125, 177-180; cf. Agora_III, nos. 693,702 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Isokrates: Grave precinct of Isokrates and his family outside the Diomeian Gate near Kynosarges on the hill to the left: Plu. Moralia 838 B-D; Scholl, A. 1994, 240-252; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 120, 129, 131
Isokratesʼ grave marked by a siren on a column ca. 9 m. high, and a trapeza with reliefs of Isokrates, Gorgias, poets and teachers
Six trapezai for members of Isokratesʼ family (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Isokrates: Painted portrait in the Pompeion: Plu. Moralia 839 C (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Isokrates: Statue in the Olympieion precinct: Paus. 1.18.8; dedicated to Zeus by Isokratesʼ adopted son, the tragedian Aphareus, Plu. Moralia 839 B; Further Greek Epigrams 1981,16 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Isokrates: Bronze equestrian statue on the Akropolis: Plu. Moralia 839 C (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Isokrates: Bronze statue by Leochares dedicated by Timotheos either in the Eleusinion at Athens or in Eleusis: Plu. Moralia 838 D; Further Greek Epigrams 1981,429 no.123 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Isokratesʼ Mother, Hedyto: statue later relabelled, on the Akropolis near Hygieia: Plu. Moralia 839 D; Blanck, H. 1969,15, 24 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Itonian Gate: in the Themistoklean City Wall, not far from Kallirrhoe: Pl. Ax. 364 D; Judeich, W. 1931, 126, 141-2, 386, 422, Plan I G-7, Plan IV; Gate (?) at 8 Iosiph ton Rogon St., east of Lembesi St., identified as both the Itonian Gate and the gate through which the road to Isthmonikosʼ Bath passed, Travlos, J. 1971, 160 Gate XI, figs, 219, 379, 380, 435; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 121, 123, 143, 145; cf. Conwell, D. H. 1993, 222, 248, 523-524 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Jason: and those sailing with him to Colchis including Akastos with his horses, picture by Mikon in the sanctuary of the Dioskouroi: Paus. 1.18.1; LIMC II, 1984, 596 no. 25, s.v. Argonautai (R. Blatter) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Juba II: king of Mauretania, statue in the Ptolemaion: Paus. 1.17.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kainon: place-name and lawcourt: schol. Ar. V. 120; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 164-167; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Kainon (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kalades: statue at the temple of Ares: Paus. 1.8.4; O. Walter, RE Suppl. VII, 940, col. 317 (Kalades); Pausanias refers to the musician Sakadas of Argos, Pritchett, W. K. 1998, 56-57 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kallias: Statue in the Agora near the statue of Eirene: Paus. 1.8.2; Holscher, T. 1975, 192 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kallion: lawcourt: Poll. 8.121; perhaps built by Kallias, son of Hipponikos, FGRHIST III B, suppl., vol. I, 164-167; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Kallion (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kallippos: son of Moirokles, commander at Thermopylai against the Galatians, 279 B.C., picture by Olbiades in the Bouleuterion: Paus. 1.3.5; Habicht, Chr. 1985, 84-85 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kallirrhoe: spring in the Ilissos river bed near the church of Haghia Photini: Th. 2.15.5-6; Agora_III, nos. 435, 438-440, 442, 444, 448-450, 452-455; Judeich, W. 1931, 194-196, 419-420; Travlos, J. 1971, 204-205, 340, 361, figs. 130, 154, 267-268, 379, 441; LIMC V, 1990, 937, s.v. Kallirrhoe II (A. Spetsieri-Choremi); (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kalliste: sanctuary, on the Road to the Academy Gymnasium, at 11 Plataion St. opposite Granikou St.: walled precinct of Artemis with xoana of Ariste and Kalliste on the way to the Academy, Paus. 1.29.2; precinct of Hekate, whom some call Artemis, in the Kerameikos according to Hsch. s.v. Καλλίστη; IG II² 788 line 28; A. Philadelpheus, “Le sanctuaire d'Artemis Kalliste et l'ancienne rue de l' Academie,” BCH 51 (1927) 155-163, figs. 2-4, pl. 8; Travlos, J. 1971, 301, figs. 417 no. 178, 423-424, Forsen, B. 1996, 57-58, figs. 47-49 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kallisto: daughter of Lykaon, statue by Deinomenes on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.25.1, cf. Paus. 10.9.5; LIMCV, 1990, 941 no. 2, s.v. Kallisto (I. McPhee) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kalos: Daidalosʼ nephew, grave on the Akropolis South Slope between the Theater and the Asklepieion: Paus. 1.21.4, Paus. 1.26.4; suggested location at the site of the 'cisterna paleocristiana', Beschi, L. 1967/68a, 393-396, 512, fig. 1 monument B. Other ancient authors call Daidalosʼ nephew Talos or Perdix, LIMC VII, 1994, 837, s.v. Talos II, 837 (I. Leventi); Beschi, L. 2002, 21, 25 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Karneades: Exedra in the Academy: Cic. Fin. 5.2.4 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kassander: bronze statue destroyed by the Athenians: Plu. Moralia 559 D (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kassandra, Lokrian Aias, Laodike: (portrait of Elpinike) and other captive Trojan women in the presence of the Greek kings, picture by Polygnotos ca. 460 B.C. in the Stoa Poikile: Plu. Cim. 4, 5-6; Paus. 1.15.2, cf. Paus. 10.26.1; Agora_III, 31, nos. 80,86; Kron, U. 1976, 157-158. The account of Polygnotosʼ painting of the same scene in Delphi (Paus. 10.26.1,3,7) provides clues to the content of the picture in the Stoa Poikile [which will also have pictured Kassandra holding the desecrated cult statue of Athena and Laodike as a philhellene; Menestheus was surely pictured among the Greek kings] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Katharsios: cult: Poll. 8.142; Cook, A. B. 1914-1940, II, 1093 note 1, 1100 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Kekrops: Statue as Eponymous Hero: Paus. 1.5.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kephisodoros: Grave monument, 195 B.C., on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.36.5 + Paus. 1.37.1; J. P. V. D. Baldson, “Rome and Macedon, 205-200 B.C., JRS 44 (1954) 36; [probably a state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kephisos River: Paus. 1.37.3 + 4; F. Bolte, REX I, 1921, 244-247 (Kephisos) Siewert, P. 1982, 40 with note 20 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Kephisos River: Precinct implied by the mention of a dedication to Kephisos: Paus. 1.37.3 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kerameikai Gate: in the Themistoklean City Wall: Philostr. VS 2.8.2; another name for the Dipylon Gate, Judeich, W. 1931, 136 note 2; see Themistoklean City Wall Wal6* (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Kerameikos area (Athens) (Paus. 1.2.4, Paus. 1.3.1, Paus. 1.14.6, Paus. 1.20.6, Paus. 8.9.8)

descriptions.value: Kerameikos: name of a district: Paus. 1.2.4, Paus. 1.3.1, Paus. 1.14.6, Paus. 1.20.6, Paus. 8.9.8; Agora_III, 221-224; Siewert, P. 1982, 29 note 140, 31 note 150, 42; J. W. Flick - G. C. Mandl - P. Siewert - I. Steffelbauer, “Aristophanesʼ Nachrichten liber den Athenischen Kerameikos,” AM 115 (2000) 217-235; Papadopoulos, J. K. 2003, 271-197; Kerameikos as a street name is not attested in the ancient sources (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Kerykos Lithos: stone on which Solon stood when he recited his poem on Salamis: Plu. Sol. 8.2; Agora_XIV, 48 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kimon: Grave in the family burial ground, later known as the 'Kimonian Remains' outside the Melitides Gate in Koile: Plu. Cim. 4.2; Cratinus frg. 151 in The Fragments of Attic Comedy, ed. J. M. Edmonds, I, Leiden, 1957, 70; O. Luschnat, RE Suppl. XII, 1970, col. 1090-1091 (Thukydides); Davies, J. K. 1971, 310; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kimon: Well-watered grove planted in the Academy: Plu. Cim. 13.8; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 717, 722-723, 727-728 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kimon: Plane trees planted in the Agora: Plu. Cim. 13.8; Agora_III, nos. 717-718 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kimon: son of Stesagoras, grave in the family plot in Koile outside the Melitides Gate in Koile: Hdt. 6.103; Judeich, W. 1931, 140 note 4, 400, 409-10 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Kleisthenes: grave mon. on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.6; a state burial monument, Stupperich, R. 1977, 1, 223-224; R. D. Cromey, “Kleisthenesʼ Fate,” Historia 28 (1979) 130-131, 133 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kleon: son of Kleainetos, tannery in Kydathenaion: schol. Ar. Eq. 44; U. Kahrstedt, RE XI, 1921, 714 lines 28-30, testimonia (Kleon) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Klepsydra: 1) Spring house, 475-450 B.C., partly rock-cut, set deep in a cave on the Akropolis North Slope: Paus. 1.28.4 (unnamed spring below the Propylaia); tentatively [and convincingly] assigned to Kimon, Parsons, A. W. 1943, 191-267, testimonia 264-267, figs. 1-42; Travlos, J. 1971, 323-331, figs. 116G, 426-434; for the Late Mycenean predecessor, see Smithson, E. L. 1982, 141-154, fig. 1; (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Kodros: Statue with inscribed base, Augustan period, set up at the spot on the Ilissos, seen by Pausanias, where Kodros fell. IG II² 4258; Paus. 1.19.5, cf. Paus. 7.25.2. Perhaps within the sanctuary of Kodros, Neleus and Basile, N. Robertson, op. cit., 225-226 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kodros: Sanctuary of Basile: Pl. Chrm. 153A; assuming that Plato does not refer to a separate sanctuary of Basile, Wheeler, J. R. 1887, 45 note 19, 46-47  (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Koile: Road through Koile: Hdt. 6.103 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Kollytos: Deme named after Kollytos father of Diomos, southwest of the Agora, south of the Areopagus: Str. 1.4.7; E. Honigmann, REX I, 1921, 1106-1107 (Kollytos); Traill, J. S. 1986, 126, 128 note 18, Map; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 125, 128; Stroud, R. S. 1998, 17, 88-89; see Agathe Tyche, sanctuary; Zeus Zeu1* (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kollytos: Στενοπός Κολλυτός, a narrow street in the heart of the city that served as an agora in 359/360 A.D. when the district was restored by Ampelius, proconsul of Achaia: Phot. Bibl. 375 B; probably the ancient northwest-southeast street running through the Areopagus-Pnyx Valley, Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1985, 737; Agora_XXIV, 21, 35-36 with notes 135-137 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kolonos: Deme at Kolonos Hippios: Harp. s.v. Κολωνέτας; Traill, J. S. 1986, 126, Map (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kolonos: Eponymous hero (archegos) of Kolonos, equestrian (?) statue: S. OC 58-65; Whitehead, D. 1986, 211; Kearns, E. 1989, 95, 125, 178 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kolonos Agoraios: name of the low hill west of the Agora: Harp. s.v. κολωνέτας; Agora_III, nos. 246-248, 250-251, 286, 290; summit of the hill levelled down in 1862, Travlos, J. 1971, 261 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Kolonos Hippios: hill near the Academy: Paus. 1.30.4; Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 387-414, figs. 202-203, pls. 123-125; E. Meyer, KP 3, 1969, 276 (s.v. Kolonos 2) For imaginary monuments and sites in the Kolonos Hippios area, see Part II nos. 462-474 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Konnidas: Theseusʼ paidagogos, honoured as a hero by the Athenians: Plu. Thes. 4.1; Kearns, E. 1989, 178-179 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Konon (II): Kononʼs house with a 20-kline dining room taken over by the peripatetic Lykon for his receptions: Ath. 12.69b (548 A-B); the house more likely belonged to Konon (III), the grandson of Konon (II), Davies, J. K. 1971, 509, 512 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Konon (II): Grave monuments on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.15; [state burial monuments ] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Konon (II): Statues in front of the Stoa of Zeus: Paus. 1.3.2; Agora_III, nos. 16, 29, 261, 702, 712; Gauer, W. 1968b, 118-24 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Konon (II): Statues opposite the 10th column from the east on the Parthenon north side - - - IG II² 3774; Paus. 1.24.3; Stevens, G. P. 1946a, 4-10, fig. 3 no. 2, figs. 4-11; A. H. Borbein, “Die griechische Statue des 4. Jahrhunderts v. Chr.,” Jahrbuch 88 (1973) 66 with note 102; SEG_36 246 (1986); see Chr. Mon. CM11*, Ambo (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kranaa Polis: old name for the Akropolis: Ar. Lys. 480-481; BullEpig 1965 no. 155; M. S. Jensen, “A Note on Homerʼs Use of the Word κραναός,” Cl et Med 33 (1981-82) 5-8 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kronion: Altar of Kronos and Rhea founded by Kekrops: Philochoros in Macr. Sat. 1.10.22; FGRHIST III B, 127-8, Philochoros 328 F 97 with suppl. vol. I, 401-404 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kronion: Temple in the precinct of Zeus Olympios: Paus. 1.18.7; [probably the classical Doric temple south of the Olympieion (Part II no. 549)]; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kykloboros: brook: schol. Ar. Eq. 137; Judeich, W. 1931, 48-49; according to Pappas, A. A. 1999, 26, sections iii-iv, Kykloboros started northwest of the church of Hag. Stylianos in northeast Athens, ran along Evelpidon → Kodringtonos Sts., and along the north side of the OTE Bldg.; Bousgou St. was formerly called Kykloborou St. (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Kylon: bronze statue on the Akropolis: preceding the description of Athena Promachos, Paus. 1.28.1; M. Jameson, “Notes on the Sacrificial Calendar from Erchia,” BCH 89 (1965) 170-171 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Kyloneion: (or Kydonion, unemended) outside the Enneapylon: schol. S. OC 489; cf. FGRHIST III B, 385-7, Epimenides T 1 lines 12-13, T 2 lines 24-25, T 4 lines 16 ff. with commentary; M. Jameson, op. cit. 171 note 1; conjectural [arbitrarily chosen] location on the Akropolis West Slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 9 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Kynosarges: Place-name: Plu. Moralia 838 B; Billot, M.-F. 1992, 120 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Kynosarges: Gymnasium: Liv. 31.24; Delorme, J. 1960, 523 s.v. Athenes (Cynosarges); Billot, M.-F. 1992, 119 note 1, 120, 124, 129-144; (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Lakedaimonian Shield: one of those captured at Sphakteria, 425/4 B.C.  IG I³ 522, Agora_B 262; SEG_10 325 (1949); Paus. 1.15.4; Agora_Guide, 1990,105-106, 254-255, 284 no. 254, figs. 60-61 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Lakedaimonians: burial monument at state expense, 403 B.C., in back of the 2nd Kerameikos horos, on the southwest edge of the Road to the Academy IG II²  11678; SEG_37 157 (1987); X. HG 2.4.33; Knigge, U. 1991,11,12, 38, 42, 161-161,162, fig. 156-157, 165 no. 63; [this tomb was not in the Demosion Sema] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Lakiadai: Lakiadai, deme on the Sacred Way east of the Kephisos: Paus. 1.37.2; Traill, J. S.1986, 133 with Map (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Lakios: Lakios the Hero, precinct on the Sacred Way in the deme of Lakiadai: Paus. 1.37.2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Lakydeion: garden in the Academy where Lakydes taught, a gift from Attalos I: D.L. 4.60; Chr. Habicht, “Athens and the Attalids in the Second Century B.C.,” Hesperia 59 (1990) 562 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Leaina: monument, bronze lioness on the Akropolis beside a statue of Aphrodite: Paus. 1.23.2; G. P. Stevens, “The Periclean Entrance Court of the Acropolis of Athens,”, Hesperia 5 (1936) 451-454, 456 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Leokorion: heroon of Leosʼ daughters, on the Panathenaic Way inside a gate in the archaic City Wall: Th. 1.20.2, 6.57.1-3; Agora_III, 108-113, nos. 317-338, Kron, U. 1976, 195-200; located to the south of a conjectural site of the archaic City Wall gate in question, Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 5 no. 20; SEG_48 272 (1998); (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Leokritos: State burial monument implied by Paus. 1.26.2, honours paid to him after he fell in battle (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Leos: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2; Kron, U. 1976, 200-201, 280 line 3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Leschai: 360 in Athens: schol. Hes. Op. 493-495; SEG_46 2388 (1996) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Lethe: altar in the Erechtheion: Plu. Moralia 74i B  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Limnai: 1) Marshy place with sanctuary of Dionysos: Th. 2.15.4; FGRHIST III B, 160, 328. Philochoros F 229, 744 lines 26-29 and suppl. vols. I, 594-595 and II, 486 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Limnai: 2) Deme in Attica, where Artemis is revered: Call. Dian. 172; Callimachus, ed. R Pfeiffer, Oxford, 1953, II, 63; hence Dörpfeldʼs sanctuary of Artemis in Limnai preceding a sanctuary of Artemis in the Bakcheion, W. Dörpfeld, “Die Ausgrabungen an der Enneakrounos. II.,” AM 19 (1894) 150 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Limou Pedion: (Field of Famine), field behind the prytaneion given to Famine in accordance with an oracle: Zen. 4.93; J. McK. Camp II, “A Drought in the Late Eighth Century B.C.,” Hesperia 48 (1979) 402-403 with note 24; cf. Leimon (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Lions: Krenophylax, bronze fountain house lion: Poll. 8.113; Camp, J. McK. II 1980, 296-298 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Lithos: Archonʼs stone in front of the Stoa Basileios: Arist.Ath. 7.1, Arist.Ath. 55.5; Shear Jr., T. L. 1971, 259-260, fig. 1, pls. 47, 50:d; as an altar, Kuhn, G. 1985, 222-226, figs. 7, 12 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Lithos: Stone on the Akropolis where the Silen sat when Dionysos first came: Paus. 1.23.5; cf. E. Pfuhl, Malerei und Zeichnung der Griechen (München, 1923) vol. Ill, pl. 282 no. 665 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Logisteria: offices of the logistai: Harp. s.v. λογισταί; Agora_III, 126 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Long Walls: Paus. 1.2.2, Paus. 1.25.5; Maier, F. G. 1959,16-17, 21-67 nos. 1-11 and II, 1961, 117-118 no. 9:a; Judeich, W. 1931, 2, 75-76 note 1, 81, 83, 93 note 1, 111, 126, 155 note 1 testimonial 55-160, 162; Conwell, D. H. 1993, 1-701 (with testimonia 447-491 and bibliography 548-608), figs. 1-60 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Long Walls: Phaleric Wall, from Athens to Phaleron, built with the Northern Wall: Th. 2.13.7 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Long Walls: Middle Wall, from Athens to Munichyia, begun after ca. 445 B.C., finished before 431 B:C. First called Middle Wall: Pl. Grg. 455E with schol. Called Southern Wall after the Phaleric Wall went out of use: Harp. s.v. Διά μέσου τείχους (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Lykabettos: hill in northeast Athens: Antig. Mir. 12; Milchhöfer, A. 1891, 6; Judeich, W. 1931, 44, 45 note 1, 49 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Lykomedes: greatgrandfather of Lykourgos [II] the statesman and first priest of Poseidon on the Akropolis, ca. 450 B.C., state burial monument in the Kerameikos: Plu. Moralia 843 E, 852 A; Matthaiou, A. P. 1987, 38-39 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Lykon: from Alexandria Troas, head of the Peripatetic School from ca. 270-226 B.C., statue specified in Lykonʼs will: D.L. 5.71; Frischer, B. 1982, 94 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Lykourgos [I]: son of Lykomedes and grandfather of Lykourgos [II] the statesman, state burial monument in the Kerameikos: Plu. Moralia 843 E; Matthaiou, A. P. 1987, 38-40 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Lykourgos [II]: Armamentarium: Rut. Lup. 1.7 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Lykourgos [II]: Base for a bronze statue decreed in 307/6 B.C., near the Eponymous Heroes - - - IG II² 3776; Paus. 1.8.2; Agora_III, 213-4; Richter, G. M. A. 1965, II, 1965, 212, fig. 1365 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Lykourgos [II]: Stele recording Lykourgosʼ deeds in the palaestra built by Lykourgos in the Lykeion: Plu. Moralia 843 F; Delorme, J. 1960, 56 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Lykourgos [II]: State burial monuments for Lykourgos and his sons (Habron, Lykourgos and Lykophron), inscribed trapezai in the garden of the philosopher Melanthios opposite Athena Paionia: Plu. Moralia 842 E and 852 A; Paus. 1.29.15 mentions only Lykourgosʼ grave mon. on the Road to the Academy; Matthaiou, A. P. 1987, 31-43; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 788-789 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Lykourgos [II]: Wooden statues of Lykourgos and his sons, Habron, Lykourgos and Lykophron, by Timarchos and Kephisodotos, sons of Praxiteles, in the Erechtheion, probably set up after 307 B.C.: Plu. Moralia 843 F; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 478 with note 3; R. von den Hoff, op. cit. (under Demetrios of Phaleron), 179-180 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Lysikrates: choregic monument with frieze representing Dionysos and the pirates, 335/334 B.C., on the ancient Street of the Tripods (present-day Plateia Lysikratous, Plan 1 eta—8, no. 77) IG II² 3042; Travlos, J. 1971, 348-352, figs. 450-452, 709-710; H. Bauer, “Lysikratesdenkmal, Baubestand und Rekonstruktion,” AM 92 (1977) 197-227, figs. 1-7, pls. 91-6, Beilagen 5-10; Wilson, P. 2000, 219-226, figs. 11-14; [possibly the temple of Dionysos mentioned by Pausanias Paus. 1.20.2] (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Lysimache: daughter of Drakontides, priestess of Athena Polias, statue base, ca. 360 B.C., Akropolis - - - IG II² 3453; : Plin. Nat. 34.76; Davies, J. K. 1971, 170; SEG_30 140 (1980) (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Lysimachos: of Macedon, successor of Alexander, statue in front of the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.9.4; Kotsidu, H. 2000, 31-32 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Makra Stoa: adjoining Kolonos Agoraios: schol. Ar. Av. 997; Agora_III, 21 No. 3; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Makrai: name for the Akropolis northwest slope cliffs: E. Ion 11-13; Judeich, W. 1931, 301 note 6 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Man in Armour: fighting, picture by Antidotos: Plin. Nat. 34.130 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Mantinea: picture by Euphranor of Epaminondas killed by Gryllos, son of Xenophon, in the cavalry engagement at Mantinea, in the Stoa of Zeus: Paus. 1.3.4, Paus. 8.9.8, Paus. 8.11.6, Paus. 9.15.5; Palagia, O. 1980, 1-2 no. 7, 2-3 no. 14, 3-4 no. 18, 50-54 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Marathonomachia: picture by Panainos in the Stoa Poikile: Paus. 1.15.3, Paus. 1.21.2, Paus. 5.11.6; the picture did not have inscribed names, Gauer, W. 1968b, 136-138; E. B. Harrison, “The South Frieze of the Nike Temple and the Marathon Painting in the Painted Stoa,” AJA 76 (1972) 370-378, testimonia; the picture had inscribed names, Palagia, O. 1980, 54 note 301; Kearns, E. 1989, 45-46; Di Cesare, R. 2002, 43-47 Noticed by Pausanias in the picture: Aischylos, Athena, Barbarians (3), Greeks, Herakles, Heros Echetlos, Heros Marathon, Kallimachos, men of Attica, Miltiades, Phoenician ships, Plataians, Theseus rising out of the ground. Not mentioned by Pausanias: Boutes; Datis and Artaphernes, Plin. Nat. 35.57; an Athenian and his brave dog, Ael. NA 7.38; Epizelos, Ael. NA 7.38; Kynegeiros, Ael. NA 7.38; Medes, Pers. 3.53; the ten archons with Miltiades foremost “numero prima,” Nepos, Milt. 6.3; cf. Agora_III, no. 96
see Attalid dedication on the Akropolis; Persian War Memorials (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Mardonios: dagger in the temple of the Polias: Paus. 1.27.1; Harris, D. 1995, 217 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Masistios: cuirass in the temple of the Polias: Paus. 1.27.1; D. Harris, 1995, 204-205 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Meizon: lawcourt: Poll. 8.121; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 165-6; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Meizon (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Melanippos: son of Theseus, heroon in Melite: Harp. s.v. Μελανιππειον; FGRHIST III B, 52, Kleidemos 323 F 2 with suppl. vol. I, 63, 314; Kearns, E. 1989, 123, 184 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Melanopos and Makartatos: state burial monument with horsemen relief, 458/7 B.C., battle of Tanagra; Paus. 1.29.6; [mistakenly] linked to Agora_I 1898 = IG I³ 1288 (ca. 410? B.C.); Agora_XVII, 89 no. 375; Bugh, G. R. 1988, 43-44; Pritchett, W. K. 1985, 148 note 161; SEG_38 30 (1988) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Melanthios: philosopher of the Academy, garden on the Road to the Academy; Plu. Moralia 842 E (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Melesandros: Athenian strategos killed in Lycia, 430/429 B.C., state burial mon. on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.7; Develin, R. 1989, 119; Pritchett, W. K. 1985, 148, Table 3 s.v. Coast of Caria (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Melite: Melitides Gate: Paus. 1.23.9; gate in the Themistoklean City Wall, west of the peak of Philopappos, north of the intersection of Miniak and Arakynthou Sts., Judeich, W. 1931, 140, Plan I C-7, Plan IV; [mistakenly] identified with the gate in the Diateichisma in the saddle between the Pnyx and the Hill of the Nymphs, Travlos, J., 1971, 161, Gate XV Melitides Gate, figs. 28, 219 which shows a road heading south connecting Travlosʼ Melitides Gate with Judeichʼs Melitides Gate in the Themistoklean City Wall; Conwell, D. H. 1993, 220-221 cf. Diateichisma; Themistoklean City Wall Wal29*; Part II no. 586 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Memmius, C. M., L.F.: house with sacrarium rented by the sculptor C. Avianus Evander, 51 B.C.: Cic. Fam. 13.2; F. Marx, “Der Bildhauer C. Evianus Euander und Ciceros Briefe,” in Festschrift fur Otto Benndorf zu seinem 60. Geburtstage, K. Masner ed., Vienna, 1898, 37-45 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Menander: Grave on the road from Peiraeus: Paus. 1.2.2; Conwell, D. H. 1993, 228 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Menander: Statue in the Theatre - - - IG II² 3777; Paus. 1.21.1; set up in the east parodos of the Theatre of Dionysos soon after 293/292 B.C., K. Fittschen, op. cit., 268 - 275, fig. 1, pls. 76-77 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Meson: lawcourt: Poll. 8.121; FGRHIST III B, 74, Androtion 324 F 59 with suppl. vol. I, 164-7; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Meson (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Meton: House, adjacent to the Stoa Poikile: Ael. VH 13.12; Agora_III, no. 48 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Meton: Astronomical device run by water (?), on Kolonos Agoraios: schol. Ar. Av. 997; FGRHIST III B, 135, Philochoros 328 F 122 with suppl. vol. I, 496-8 and vol. II, 401 note 2; Camp, J. McK. II 1980, 324-325; W. Kendrick Pritchett, Athenian Calendars and Ekklesias, Amsterdam, 2001, 98-99 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Meton: Sundial on the Pnyx by the wall at the Assembly Place: schol. Ar. Av. 997; rock-cut beddings tentatively assigned, Kourouniotis, K. and H. A. Thompson 1932, 207-11, figs. 66-67, pl. 1; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Metragyrtes: Phrygian mendicant priest, statue and grave in a Bouleuterion consecrated to the Mother of the Gods which the plague-stricken Athenians built to atone for his murder: Phot. s.v. μητραγύρτης; Agora_III, nos. 487, 492; Shear Jr., T. L. 1995, 173-174, 175-176, 177-178 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Miltiades: House still existing in Demosthenesʼ time: D. 3.26 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Miltiades: Statues of Miltiades and Themistokles in the Prytaneion relabelled as a Roman and a Thracian: Paus. 1.18.3; Gauer, W. 1968b, 128-132, 144; accepting Louis Robertʼs suggestion that they were relabelled as the Thracian king Rhoimetalkes and Gaius Julius Nicanor, H. Whittaker, “Pausanias and his Use of Inscriptions,” Symbolae Osloensis 66 (1991) 178 with note 9 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Miltiades: Miltiades with a Persian captive and Themistokles with a Persian captive, a pair of statue groups in the Theatre: Aristid. 46.161 with schol.; Richter, G. M. A. 1965, I, 95 no. 4, 96 with figs. 393-401 (the coins), 98b; cf. Agora_XXVI, 123 note 52 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Mnemosyne: Statue in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; according to a suggestion of Giorgos Despinis, the head wrongly associated with the statue NM 233 could belong to Mnemosyne in the group associated with the Euboulides Monument, Despinis, G. 1995, 331-334, pls. 62-64; Kaltsas, N. 2002, 282 no. 593, ph. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Mnesimache: and her son, statues at the Kephisos: Paus. 1.37.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Molottos: (Molossos) the strategos, died in 374 B.C., stele and grave on the Sacred Way after Anthemokritos: Paus. 1.36.4; [probably a state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Molpadia: Amazon slain by Theseus, grave mon.: Paus. 1.2.1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Morychos: tragic poet, house near the Olympieion: Pl. Phdr. 227 B; Travlos, J. 1971, 289 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Mother of the Gods: Metroon in the Agora: Paus. 1.3.5; Agora_III, 150-160; Agora_XIV, General Index s.v. Metroon; Shear Jr., T. L. 1995, 157-190
The classical Metroon, the sanctuary of Rhea, was a part of the Bouleuterion; schol. Aischin. 3.187 (Ktesiphon); Agora_III, no. 467; see Bouleuterion 3) Old Bouleuterion (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Mother of the Gods: Hellenistic Metroon, ca. 140 B.C., between the Tholos and Apollo Patroos: Paus. 1.3.5; Agora_XIV, General Index s.v. Metroon, Hellenistic; P. Valavanis, “Thoughts on the Public Archive in the Hellenistic Metroon of the Athenian Agora,” AM 117 (2002) 221-255, figs. 1-3 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

properties.title: Mother of the Gods statue (Paus. 1.3.5, Paus. 8.37.3)

descriptions.value: Mother of the Gods: Statue of the Mother of the Gods by Pheidias or Agorakritos: Paus. 1.3.5, Paus. 8.37.3; Agora_III, nos. 402, 489; Naumann, F.1983, 159 -180; Shear Jr., T. L. 1995, 168, 189; [the statue originally stood in the “Old Bouleuterion” ] (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Mousaios: FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 574-577; Kearns, E. 1989, 187 Picture in the Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.7 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Mousaios: Tomb: on Mouseion Hill where Mousaios sang according to Pausanias Paus. 1.25.8; in Phaleron according to D.L. 1.3 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Mouseion Hill: inside the ancient circuit wall across from the Akropolis, Paus. 1.25.8; now called Philopappos Hill or Hill of the Muses (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Mouseion Hill: Mouseion Fort built between 307 and 294 B.C. on Mouseion Hill: Paus. 1.25.8 + Paus. 1.26.1-2, Paus. 3.6.6; Thompson, H. A. and R. L. Scranton 1943, 331, 337-338, 357-358, fig. 40, pl. 14; Travlos, J. 1971, 462, figs. 219 no. 220, 232-233; for D. H. Conwellʼs view that, pace R. L. Scranton, the Diateichisma was later than the Mouseion Fort, see Diateichisma (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Mouseion: in the Academy, founded by Plato: D.L. 4.1; Riginos, A. S. 1976, 119-121; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 743-744, 781-782, 785-786 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Mouseion: Altar of the Muses: Paus. 1.30.2; Delorme, J. 1960, 53 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Mouseion: rebuilt by Theophrastos with statues of the goddesses: D.L. 5.51; Lynch, J. P. 1972, 114-116 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Mouseion: Small stoa: D.L. 5.51 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Mouseion: Lower stoa containing maps: D.L. 5.51-52 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Mouseion: Altar: D.L. 5.52 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Muses: Altar of the Ιlissian Muses: Paus. 1.19.5; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1989, 259-260; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Muses: Statues in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; according to Giorgos I. Despinis, NM 233 formerly identified as a Nike may be one of these Muses; see Nike, statue found with the Euboulides base (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Myrmex Lane: in Skambonidai, named after the Hero Myrmex, son of Melite: Hsch. s.v. Μύρμηκος Άτραπούς; Judeich, W. 1931, 168 note 3, 183 note 8; Miller, S. G. 1972, 83 with note 32, commentary on IG II² 2776 line 62; Siewert, P. 1982, 29 note 140 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Neoptolemos: son of Antikles, statue: Plu. Moralia 843 F; Further Greek Epigrams, 1981, 280-281 no. 55 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Nike: The Golden Nikai: IG I³ 467-471; SEG_50 68 (2000); Paus. 1.29.16; D. B. Thompson, “The Golden Nikai Reconsidered,” Hesperia 13 (1944) 173-209, testimonia 173-177; Mark, I. S. 1988, 134-156, 216-221; Harris, D. 1995, 272-275 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Nike: Bronze statue commemorating the capture of 292 Spartans on Sphakteria, 425 B.C., Akropolis: Paus. 4.36.6; Mark, I. S. 1988, 187-188 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Nikias: son of Nikeratos, and his brothers, choregic tripods in the Dionysion: Pl. Grg. 472A; Davies, J. K. 1971, 403-404; Wilson, P. 2000, 203, 228-229 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Nikias: son of Nikomedes, artist, grave on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.15; O. Gengler, “Le peintre Nikias chez Pausanias et IG II² 3055,” ZPE 130 (2000) 143-146; SEG_50 193 (2000); [may be a state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Nikokles: Grave on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Nikomachos: Aristotleʼs son, statue provided for in Theophrastosʼ will: D.L. 5.52 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Nisos: king of Megara, brother of Lykos, grave mon. behind the Lykeion: Paus. 1.19.4; Delorme, J. 1960, 44; Kearns, E. 1989, 115-116, 188; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Nomophylakes: Nomophylakion, office of the nomophylakes: Poll. 8.102; H.-J. Gehrke, “Politik und Philosophie bei Demetrios von Phaleron,” Chiron 8 (1978) 188-189 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Nymphs: Nymphs who reared Dionysos, altar founded by Amphiktyon: Ath. 2.38 C-D; FGRHIST III B, Philochoros 328 F 5 with suppl. vol. I, 270; cf. Amphiktyon, terracotta sculpture; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Nymphs: Nymphs, Acheloos, Pan and The Other Gods, sanctuary with a spring by the Ilissos, visited by Sokrates: Pl. Phdr. 229 B, 230 B, 279 B; Str. 9.1.24; [mistakenly] located southwest of the Panathenaic Stadium at the findspot of the Washermen Relief (Nymphs), Travlos, J. 1971, 289, fig. 379 no. 196; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Odysseus: Odysseus stealing Philoktetesʼ bow, Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.6; Brommer, F. 1983, 16, 49, 112, 123; cf. Diomedes (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Odysseus: Odysseus meeting Nausikaa, Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.6; Brommer, F. 1983, 127 s.v. Nausikaa (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Odysseus: Odysseus in the underworld, the Necyomantea Homeri by Nikias: Plin. Nat. 35.132; perhaps displayed in the Nikias Mon., Townsend, R. F. 1982, 216 with note 115; Brommer, F. 1983, 113 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Oidipous: Altar between the Areopagus and the Akropolis: V. Max. 5.3, ext. 3 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Oidipous: Sacred grave not far from the Covenant Place of Theseus and Peirithoos: S. OC 1545, 1593-1594, 1756-1763; two sites are attested:
1) the grave was at Kolonos Hippios according to Aristid. 46.172; R. C. Jebb, The Oedipus Coloneus, 1885, XXIX; cf. Kearns, E. 1989, 50-52, 106, 129, 189, 208-209; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Oineus: bastard son of Pandion, Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.2; Kron, U. 1976, 188-9; Kearns, E. 1989, 89, 190; LIMC VIII, 1997, 919-920 s.v. Oineus II (E. Stasinopoulou-Kakarouga) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Oinobios: proposer of the decree recalling Thucydides, statue (?) on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.23,9; “Pausanias implies, though he does not expressly state, that there were statues of Oenobius, Hermolycus and Phormio on the Acropolis,” Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 287 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Oinoe: picture of the battle, in the Stoa Poikile: Paus. 1.15.1, cf. Paus. 10.10.3-4; Meiggs, R. 1972, 96-97, 469-472; B. Develin, “The Battle of Oinoe Meets Ockhamʼs Razor?”, ZPE 99 (1993) 235-240 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Olive Tree in Pandroseion (Paus. 1.27.2, Paus. 1.30.2, Paus. 8.23.5)

descriptions.value: Olive Tree: Tree in the Pandroseion by the altar of Zeus Herkeios, evidence of Athenaʼs victory: D.H. Din. 3; Paus. 1.27.2 (martyrion, evidence that the contest took place) and Paus. 1.30.2 (implied), Paus. 8.23.5; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, General Index s.v. Olive (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Olive Tree: Moriai, sacred olive trees at the Academy: schol. S. OC 701; the second olive tree to appear, at the Academy, Paus. 1.30.2; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 736-739, 740; J. L. Shear, “Prizes from Athens: The List of Panathenaic Prizes and the Sacred Oil,” ZPE 142 (2003) 98-100 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Oloros: father of Thucydides, grave in Kimonʼs family plot: Marcellin. Vit. Thuc. 17; O. Luschnat, RE Suppl. XII, 1970, col. 1105-1106 (Thukydides) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Olympiodoros: Statue on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.25.2 + Paus. 1.26.3 + Paus. 1.26.4; Richter, G. M. A. 1972, II, 170; R. von den Hoff, op. cit. (under Demetrios of Phaleron), 176-178 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Olympiodoros: Statue (?) in the Prytaneion: Paus. 1.26.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Orestes: killing Aigisthos and Pylades killing the sons of Nauplios who had come to rescue Aigisthos, picture in the Propylaia: Paus. 1.22.6; S. Woodford, “Palamedes seeks revenge,” JHS 114 (1994) 168 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Pairisades I: Bosporan ruler, and two of his sons, Satyros and Gorgippos, bronze statues set up in the Agora ca. 330-324 B.C.: IG II² 653 lines 14-15, 41; Din. 1.43; S. M. Burstein, “I.G.II2 653, Demosthenes and Athenian Relations with Bosporus in the Fourth Century B.C.,” Historia 27 (1978) 428-436; see Spartokos II and Pairisades I (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Palladia: images of the Palladion Statue brought from Troy, the Palladion seized by Demophon, son of Theseus: Paus. 1.28.9, cf. Paus. 1.22.6; Kron, U. 1976, 149-151; Kearns, E. 1989, 155-156; SEG_42 108 (1992); cf. Diomedes (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Palladia: Pallas: a second statue (hedos) of Pallas dedicated to the gods and the city by the priest of Zeus at the Palladion in obedience to an oracle of Pythian Apollo: IG II² 3177; L. Ziehen, RE XVIII, 1949, col. 176 (Palladion); Nagy, B. 1991, 296-299 Palladion on the Akropolis dedicated by Nikias: Plu. Nic. 3.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Palladion: law court where cases of involuntary homicide were tried: Paus. 1. 28.8-9; founded at the site where the slain Argives were buried, Pollux 8.118; the testimonia indicate that the Palladion lawcourt was in Phaleron, L. Ziehen, RE XVIII, 1949, col. 177 (Palladion); Agora_XXVIII, testimonia nos. 1-8, 40-53 and Index s.v. Palladion; 'two quite separate sanctuaries called Palladion' [implausibly] conjectured, ibid., 47-48; [since the slain Argives were likely buried where they fell, the Palladion was probably at Phaleron]; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Pan: Cave of Pan on the Akropolis North Slope (Cave complex Delta), cult inaugurated after the Battle of Marathon: Paus. 1.28.4; Travlos, J. 1971, 417-421; Bourgeaud, P. 1979, 195-239, 259, 261; represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins, 2nd c. A.C., Agora_XXVI, 145 no. 280a, pl. 19 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Panathenaic Ship: Paus. 1.29.1 (seen near the Areopagus); Shear Jr., Leslie T. 1978, 39-44, testimonia in note 101; Mansfield, J. M. 1989, 2-6, 12-18, 46-50, 68-78; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Panathenaic Stadium: Ilissos left bank: Paus. 1.19.6; founded by Lykourgos, Plu. Moralia 841 D; Travlos, J. 1971, 498-503, figs. 379, 628-633; Gasparri, C. 1974/75, 313-392; [in the teeth of the evidence] located on the Pnyx, D. G. Romano, “Lykourgos, the Panathenaia and the Great Altar of Athena,” in Pnyx 1996, 71-85, fig. 57 = SEG_44 41 (1994); (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Panathenaic Stadium: Rebuilt in marble by Herodes Atticus 139/140 - 143/44 A.D.: Paus. 1. 19.6; Welch, K. 1998, 133-138, figs. 16-20 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Pandion: Statue on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.5.4; U. Kron, “Eine Pandion-Statue in Rom, Jahrbuch 92 (1977) 162-164 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Pandion: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Pandrosos: Temple of Pandrosos adjoining the temple of Athena: Paus. 1.22.7; Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 281 P, presents a conjectural restored plan of the temple with a statue base, both [deceptively] shown in solid black [as if guaranteed by the remains] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Temple of Hera and Zeus Panhellenios (Paus. 1.18.9)

names.toponym: Temple of Hera and Zeus Panhellenios

descriptions.value: Panhellenion: Temple of (Hera? and) Zeus Panhellenios: Paus. 1.18.9 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Panops: Spring house at a postern gate in the City Wall, on Sokratesʼ way from the Academy to the Lykeion: Pl. Ly. 203 A; Camp, J. McK. 1980, 294, 320-321 (testimonia); Billot, M.-F. 1989, 702 no. 6; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1980, 251-252 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Parabyston: lawcourt where the Eleven supervised trials : FGRHIST III B, 74, Androtion 324 F 59 with suppl. vol. I, 164-166; Paus. 1.28.8; Agora XXVIII Index s.v. Parabyston (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Paralos: and Ammonias, Sacred Ships, picture by Protogenes of Kaunos in the Propylaia: Plin. Nat. 35.101; Beschi, L. 1969/1970, 130-131 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Parasition: office of the parasitai: Poll. 6.35 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Parthenon: the “Kleisthenic Parthenon” project, ca. 508 - ca. 490 B.C., designed as a poros limestone temple for which only the foundations were built, M. Korres, “The Architecture of the Parthenon,” in Parthenon 1994, 56, fig. 3; blocks quarried in Peiraeus for the abandoned project of the Peisistratid Olympieion used for the foundations, Korres M. 1997, 236-240, 242 “Plan (nach Einstellung der Arbeiten am Olympieion)”; M. Korres, «Όλυμπιείον,» Anthemio, January 1999, 27 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

properties.title: Parthenon Athena T. (Athens) (Paus. 1.1.2, Paus. 1.24.5, Paus. 1.24.8, Paus. 1.37.1, Paus. 5.11.10, Paus. 8.41.9)

descriptions.value: Parthenon: Temple completed in 432 B.C.: IG I³ 436-451; SEG_40 19 (1990); Paus. 1.1.2, Paus. 1.24.5, Paus. 1.24.8, Paus. 1.37.1, Paus. 5.11.10, Paus. 8.41.9; represented on imperial bronze coins, 3rd c. A.C., Price, J. M. and B L. Trell 1977, 68 fig. 133, 78 with fig. 133; Orlandos, A. K. 1977, 3 vols.; Korres, M. and C. Bouras 1983, 171-197 (bibliography); The Parthenon and Its Impact in Modern Times, P. Tournikiotis ed., Athens, 1994, 1-365; see Chr. Mon. CM11*; Part II no. 357 (original cella colonnade fragments found in foundations of the 5th c. A.C. in the Agora Excavations) (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Pegasos of Eleutherai: who brought Dionysos to Athens in accordance with the Delphic oracle, statue in a building near the sanctuary of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5; Connor, W. R. 1990, 8-9 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Peiraic Gate: in the Themistoklean City Wall: Plu. Thes. 27.4, Sull. 14.3; Judeich, W. 1931, 139-140, Plan I C-4; Stroud, R S. 1998, 105 note 45; see Themistoklean City Wall Wal32* (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Peirithoos: Peirithoos, Theseus, Oidipous and Adrastos, heroon at Kolonos Hippios: Paus. 1.30.4, cf. Paus. 1.39.2; for the story of Adrastos, FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 442-448; Kearns, E. 1989, 140-141 s.v. Adrastos and 193-194 s.v. Peirithoos (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Peirithoos: Lamplight picture of Peirithoosʼ wedding by Hippys: Ath. 11.48 (474 C-D) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Peitho: Earlier and later statues in sanctuary of Aphrodite Pandemos: Paus. 1. 22.3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Pelargikon (Or Pelasgikon): 2) Fortification wall on the Akropolis slopes often called the Outer Pelargikon: Iakovides, S. 1962, 28, 177-199; J. McK. Camp, loc. cit., [doubtably] called the Enneapylon, Travlos, J. 1971, 52; [this wall must have enclosed a much more extensive area than has hitherto been supposed as Angelos P. Matthaiou observed in 1988]; cf. Nulton, P. E. 2000, 14 note 20; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Pelasgian Settlement: settlement at the foot of the Akropolis: Paus. 1.28.3; J. H. Oliver, “Horoi as Reserved Areas”, GRBS 4 (1963) 143 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Perdix: Daidalosʼ sister, sanctuary, Akropolis South Slope, Suid. s.v. Πέρδικος ιερόν; Beschi, L. 1967/68a, 395; Kearns, E. 1989, 194 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Perikles: Grave on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.3; Cic. Fin. 5.2.5; Stupperich, R. 1977, 25 with note 3; [as may be inferred from Ath. 13.67 (595a), probably a state burial monument which Pausanias saw after he saw the grave of Thrasyboulos and before he saw the graves of Chabrias and Phormio] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Odeion of Pericles

descriptions.value: Perikles: Odeion of Perikles, next to the Theater (Plan 1 no. 31): structure imitating Xerxesʼ tent, rebuilt after Sullan destruction, Paus. 1.20.4 (Perikles not mentioned); Travlos, J. 1971, 387-391, figs. 91 no. 139, 501-504; Meinel, R. 1980, 135-154, figs. 35-38; testimonia on the Odeion functioning as a law court, Agora XXVIII 185-186 nos. 168-170; Thanos G. Papathanasopoulos, To Τρόπαιό, Athens, 2003, 1-167, the revised version of a dissertation, «To Ωδείο του Περικλή: νέα θεώρησι του μνημείου,» (University of Rethymno, 1999) reviews and analyzes the testimonia at length, concluding [convincingly] that Themistokles was the builder (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Perikles: Picture of Perikles by Aristolaus, son of Pausias: Plin. Nat. 35.137 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Perikles: Portrait by Kresilas on the Akropolis: the sculptor but not the site recorded, Plin. Nat. 34.74; the site but not the sculptor recorded, Paus. 1.25.1 (twice), Paus. 1.28.2; Holscher, T. 1975, 187-199 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Peripatos: Walk around the Akropolis slopes with a 4th c. B.C. inscription cut “on the face of a rock which had become detached and fallen from the north slope” - - - IG II² 2639; cf. Paus. 1.22.1; Broneer, O. 1933, 347-349, fig. 19, pl. XI; Travlos, J. 1971, 54, 228, 523, 562, figs. 67, 71, 91, 293-294; Dontas, G. S. 1983, 48; Threatte, L. 1980, 108; “may be the earliest appearance of a lunate sigma in an Athenian inscription,” Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1985, 430-435; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Perischoinisma: roped off place in the Agora: Plu. Moralia 837 A; Agora_III, nos. 529-536; at the orchestra site, Kolb, F. 1981, 53-54 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Perseus: Perseus with Medusaʼs head, picture in the Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.7 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Perseus: Statue by Myron on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.23.7 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Perseus: Temenos in Athens (?): Paus. 2.18.1; J. H. Croon, “The Mask of the Underworld Daemon - Some Remarks on the Perseus-Gorgon Story,” JHS 75 (1955) 10 note 15; Kearns, E. 1989, 194 s.v. Perrheus (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Persians: supporting a bronze tripod, sculpture in the Olympieion precinct: Paus. 1.18.8; victory monument perhaps dedicated by Augustus in 19 B.C., Rolf Michael Schneider, Bunte Barbaren, Worms,1986, 82-91 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Phaleric Road: Paus. 1.1.5, 10.35.2 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Pheidias: the politician, statue: Nep. Att. 3.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Pheidostratos: school (didaskalelon): Pl. Hp. Ma. 286 B (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Pheme: altar: Paus. 1.17.1; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 144; F. Voigt, RE XIX, 1938, col. 1955 (Pheme) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Pherephattion: sanctuary in the Agora: D. 54.8; Agora_III, 85 and no. 323  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Philip II of Macedon: Statue in front of the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.9.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Philip V of Macedon: damnatio memoriae decreed by the Athenians, statues and representations of Philip together with his name on inscriptions to be destroyed: Liv. 31.44; H. A. Thompson, “Athens faces Adversity,” Hesperia 50 (1981) 354; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Philiskos: of Thessaly, sophist, grave in the Academy where the Polemarch institutes the games for the war dead: Philostr. VS 2.30; Pritchett, W. K. 1998,19-20; [state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Philopappos: Grave mon.,114-116 A.D., on the summit of Mouseion Hill: — CIL_III 552, IG II² 3451; a Syrian man, Paus. 1.25.8; Travlos, J. 1971, 462-465, figs. 233, 585-587; Diana E. E. Kleiner, The Monument of Philopappos in Athens, Rome, 1983; SEG 48 (1998) nos. 236, 2030; [probably paid for privately but a state burial monument in the sense that permission for burial inside the City Wall must have been granted by the State] (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Phlius: battle-scene, picture by Pamphilos: Plin. Nat. 35.76; Palagia, O. 1980, 52 no. 3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Phobos: recipient of sacrifices from Theseus: Plu. Thes. 27.2 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Phoinikioun: lawcourt: FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 165; Paus. 1.28.8; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Phoinikioun (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Phoinix of Thessaly: sophist, grave mon. on the right side of the Road to the Academy near the graves of the war dead: Philostr. VS 2.22; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 777-778; Pritchett, W. K. 1998, 19-20; [probably a state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Phokion: son of Phokos: Grave monument at state expense after a secret private burial: Plu. Phoc. 37.3-38.1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Phokion: House in Melite where Phokionʼs wife secretly buried the cremated remains of Phokion by the hearth: Plu. Phoc. 18.5, 37.2-3 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Phokion: Bronze statue set up by people of Athens after Phokionʼs execution: Plu. Phoc. 38.1; Richter, G. M. A. 1965, II, 158 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Phormion: son of Asopios
Grave monument, ca. 428 B.C., on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.3; [probably a state burial monument] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Phormion: Statue on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.23.10 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Phrixos: sacrificing the ram (with the golden fleece) to Zeus Laphystios, sculpture on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.2; IG II² 4272, a base with Naukydesʼ signature possibly belongs to this group, G. Despinis, “Zum Hermes von Troizen,” AM 96 (1981) 242-243 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Phytalos: Grave with epigram naming Phytalos as a hero at the sanctuary of Demeter and Kore on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Phytalos: House (oikos) at the sanctuary of Demeter and Kore on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Pindar: statue at Ares temple: Paus. 1.8.4; Agora_III, 215; Richter, G. M. A. 1972, II, 176-180 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Plato: Garden: adjoining the Academy, Apul. Pl. 1.4; beside Kolonos Hippios, D.L. 3.5; Lynch, J. P: 1972, 61; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 780-786; see Eurymedon of Myrrhinos (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Plato: Grave: not far from the Academy, Paus. 1.30.3; in the Academy, D.L. 3.41; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 786-787 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Plato: Statue by Silanion in the Academy, dedicated by the Persian Mithradates, son of Orontobates, to the Muses: D.L. 3.25; Richter, G. M. A. 1965, II, 165, 169-70; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 781-782; Els Theys in FGRHIST CONTINUED, Part IV A, Fascicle 1, 260-262; Trianti, I. 2002, 163-164 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Ploutarchos: House handed down to Syrianos and then to Proklos, Akropolis South Slope near the Asklepieion and the Dionysion at the Theatre: Marin. Procl. 29; P. Castren, “General Aspects of Life in Post-Herulian Athens,” in Castren, P., ed. 1994, 6-7; see above: Plato, portrait head found on the Akropolis lower south slope; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Plouton: Statue at the sanctuary of the Semnai: Paus. 1.28.6; Clinton, K. 1974, 20-21 with note 67; Eschbach, N. 1986, 18-26, esp. 26 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Pnyx: Place-name: Plu. Thes. 27.1 and 3; E. Meyer, RE XXI, 1951, col 1106-1110 (Pnyx) Assembly Place: the bibliography, Thompson, H. A. 1982, 133 note 1; The Pnyx in the History of Athens. Proceedings of an International Colloquium Organized by the Finnish Institute at Athens, 7-9, October, 1994 (Papers and Monographs of the Finnish Institute at Athens II), B. Forsen and G. R. Stanton edd., Helsinki, 1996 (abbreviated: Pnyx 1996) (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Pnyx: First Period of the Assembly Place, 5th c. B.C.: Ar. Ach. 19-33; Kourouniotis K. and H. A. Thompson 1932, 96-113, 215-216, figs. 3-6, pls. 2-4 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Pnyx: Second Period of the Assembly Place, 404/3 B.C.: Plu. Them. 19.4; Kourouniotis, K. and H. A. Thompson 1932, 113-138, 178-180, 216-7, figs. 8-20, pls. 2-4; G. R. Stanton, “The Shape and Size of the Athenian Assembly Place in its Second Phase,” in Pnyx 1996, 7-21, figs. 1-5 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Polemon: the philosopher, place where he customarily sat (sessio) in the Academy: Cic. Fin. 5.1.2; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 787 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Poleterion: meeting place of the poletai: Harp. s.v. πωληταί; Agora_III, 165 nos. 537-540; perhaps south of the Tholos, Μ. K. Langdon in Agora_XIX, 66-67 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Polyxena: “about to be slaughtered near the grave of Achilles”, picture in the Propylaia western chamber: Paus. 1.22.6, 10.25.10; [the comment that “Homer did well to omit so savage a deed” is one more indication that Pausanias knew his Homer by heart] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Pompeion: between the the Sacred Gate and the Dipylon Gate: Kerameikos X, 1-248, figs. 1-261, pls. 1-30; cf. Technitai of Dionysos, bouleuterion [Imaginary] early Pompeion after 566 B.C.: Travlos, J. 1971, 477
Pompeion: Pompeion (I) early 4th c. - 87 B.C.: D. 34.39 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Pompeion: Pompeion (II) ca. 144 -267 A.D.: Paus. 1.2.4; perhaps donated by Herodes Atticus, Kerameikos X, 169 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Poseidon on the Akropolis: Altar of Poseidon on which sacrifices to Erechtheus are made in obedience to an oracle, in the Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.5; conjecturally [rightly] located in the Erechtheion eastern chamber, Travlos, J. 1971, 213, fig. 281 B; Kron, U. 1976, 50-52 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Poseidon spring on the Akropolis (Paus. 1.26.5, Paus. 4.35.11, Paus. 8.10.4)

descriptions.value: Poseidon on the Akropolis: Spring in the Erechtheion, Poseidonʼs martyrion [i.e. evidence of Poseidonʼs participation in the contest]: Paus. 1.26.5, Paus. 4.35.11, Paus. 8.10.4; called Erechtheis, Apollod. 3.14.1; Kron, U. 1976, 43-44, 49 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Poseidon on the Akropolis: Marks of the trident in the rock at the Erechtheion, Poseidonʼs martyrion: Paus. 1.26.5; Kron, U. 1976, 43-44 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Poseidon Elates: cult: Hsch. s.v. Έλάτη; E. Wust, RE XXII, 1953, col. 496 lines 63-67 (Poseidon) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Poseidon Hippios: Temple and grove: Paus. 1.30.4; Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 395-397 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Poseidon Hippios: Poseidon Hippios and Athena Hippia, altar: Paus. 1.30.4; Johrens, G. 1981,140-143 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Poseidon and Polybotes: Poseidon on horseback attacking the giant Polybotes with later inscr. renaming the sculpture: Paus. 1.2.4; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 48-50 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Poulytion's House: where the Eleusinian mysteries were parodied, later dedicated to Dionysos Melpomenos, in a stoa on the Panathenaic Way: Paus. 1.2.5; Agora_III, 20-21; Maass, M. 1972, 126; A. H. Sommerstein, “The Decree of Syrakosios,” CQ 36 (1986) 105-106; Aneziri, S. 2000, 259-279 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Prater Lithos: the Selling Stone: Poll. 3.126; Agora_III, no. 540  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Praxitelesʼ Atelier: (oikema) containing his works including the Satyr and the Eros: Paus. 1.20.1-2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Prohairesios: Christian sophist, one of Julian the Apostateʼs teachers, house with theater inherited from the sophist, Julian the Cappodocian: Eun. VS 483; Agora_XXIV, 45 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Proklos: of Naukratis, sophist, house with private library, late 2nd-early 3rd A.C.: Philostr. VS 11.21 (604); Agora_XXIV, 46 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Proklos: Proklos and Syrianos, grave monument with epigram by Proklos, after 485 A.D., near Lykabettos: Marin. Procl. 36; PLRE II, 1980, Syrianos 3: Sironen, E. 1997, 156 no. 82; cf. SEG_51 298 (2001) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Prokne: daughter of Pandion, contemplating the murder of Itys, sculpture dedicated by Alkamenes, 430-420 B.C., found 1836 in the rampart west of the Propylaia Acr. 1358; Paus. 1.24.3, cf. Paus. 1.5.4; the head does not belong, H. Knell, “Die Gruppe von Prokne und Itys” Antike Plastik XVII, 1978, 9-19, figs. 1-3, pls. 1-9; perhaps stood at the Parthenon north side, opposite to the 3rd column from the east, Stevens, G. P. 1946a, 10-11, figs. 1, 3 no. 3, 12 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Prometheus: Prometheus and Hephaistos, ancient base with a relief of an old Prometheus and youthful Hephaistos with a joint altar, at the entrance to the Academy: schol. S. OC line 56; altar of Prometheus where the torch races start, Paus. 1.30.2; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 745-746, 764-766, 767, 768-773; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Prometheus: Picture of Prometheus by Parrhasios: Sen. Con. 10.5.3-4 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Prytaneion: Akropolis north slope below the Aglaurion and at the start of the street of the Tripodes: Paus. 1.18.3 + Paus. 1.20.1 + Paus. 1.26.3, Paus. 9.32.8; Agora_III, 166-174; conjectural location southeast of the Eleusinion, Travlos, J. 1971, 1,2, fig. 5 no. 15, fig. 540 no. 15, fig. 722 O; S. G. Miller, The Prytaneion, Berkeley, 1978, 38-66, 136-183; for a [mistaken] location on the Akropolis East Slope, see Aglaurion and Part II nos. 188,189; the Prytaneion site may be at the fork of the ancient Street of the Tripods, i.e. Tripodes q.v. (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Prytaneion: Lawcourt at the Prytaneion: Paus. 1.28.10; categorically [mistakenly] located on the eastern side of the Akropolis, Agora_XXVIII, 50 and Index s.v. Prytaneion (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Prytanikon: Th. 2.15; name of the Tholos precinct, E. Vanderpool, “Tholos and Prytanikon,” Hesperia 4 (1935) 470-475; Shear Jr., T. L. “Ίσονομους . . The Agora and the Democracy,” in Coulson et al. 1994, 241, 247 note 70; SEG_46 22 (1996); (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Psithyros: hero cult: Hsch. s.v. ψιθύρα; G. Radke, RE XXIII,1959, col. 1415-1417 (Psithyros); see Aphrodite Aph50* (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
