descriptions.value: Ptolemies: Statues of the Ptolemies in front of the entrance to the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.8.6, Paus. 1.9.4 (the Egyptians) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Ptolemies: Ptolemy I Soter: statue in front of the entrance to the Odeion of Agrippa: Paus. 1.8.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Ptolemies: Ptolemy II Philadelphos: Statue in front of the entrance to the Odeion of Agrippa: Paus. 1.8.6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Ptolemies: Eponymous Hero statue: Paus. 1.5.5 + Paus. 1.8.6, cf. Paus. 1.6.8; Pausanias erred, Ptolemy III is the eponymous of Ptolemais, Habicht, Chr. 1985, 96-97 with note 12 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Ptolemies: Ptolemaion, gymnasium founded by Ptolemy III in 224/223 B.C.: not far from the Agora and near the sanctuary of Theseus according to Paus. 1.17.2 (Pausanias does not specify which Ptolemy); Agora_III, 142-144; Habicht, Chr. 1982, 112-117; Wycherley, R. E. 1978, 232, 233-234; [mistaken] location in the Agora South Square, Travlos, J. 1971, 233-241, figs. 301-311; [unsubstantiated] location on the Akropolis north slope east of the Roman Agora, Travlos, J. 1971, 578-579 with fig. 722 T; [unsubstantiated] location on the Akropolis north slope east of the Roman Agora with the xystos located on Kyrrhestou St., Miller, S. G. 1994, 202-209, fig. 1 GP; SEG 46 (1996) nos. 62, 311; cf. Post-Herulian Wall, east flank; Ptolemaios, son of Juba II;  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Ptolemies: Lecture hall in the Ptolemaion where Cicero heard the head of the Academy, Antiochos of Askalon, in 79 B.C.: Cic. Fin. V.1; Agora_III, no. 457 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Ptolemies: Bronze statue of Ptolemy in the Ptolemaion: Paus. 1.17.2; Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 45-46 and Part II, vol. 1, 145-146 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Ptolemies: Ptolemy VI Philometor and his daughter (Kleopatra Berenike III, called Berenike by Pausanias), bronze statues set up by the Athenians grateful for his many benefactions, in front of the entrance to the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.8.6 + Paus. 1.9.3; Pausanias Paus. 1.9.3 in fact refers to Ptolemy IX, Habicht, Chr. 1992, 85-86 with note 108; cf. Ptolemaios son of Ptolemaios; Ptolemy IX (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Ptolemies: Ptolemy IX Philometor Soter II and his daughter Kleopatra Berenike, bronze statues set up by the Athenians grateful for his many benefactions, in front of the entrance to the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.8.6 and Paus. 1.9.3; Habicht, Chr. 1992, 85-86 with note 108 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Pyrrhos: king of Epiros, statue at the Odeion [of Agrippa], 276-272 B.C.: Paus. 1.11.1; Kotsidu, H. 2000, 32-33 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Pythodoros: son of Isolochos, house in the Kerameikos outside the walls where Sokrates met Zeno and Parmenides: Pl. Prm. 127b-c (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Ram: bronze sculpture on the Akropolis, mid-5th c. B.C. or earlier: Hsch. s.v. κριός ἀσελγόκερων; FAC I, 1957, 556 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sabazios: cult: Cic. Leg. 2.37; H. Schaefer, RE I A2, 1920, col 1545 (Sabazios no. 12); Shear Jr., T. L. 1995, 175; see Zeus Zeu101* (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Sacred Hollows: ιεροί αύλώνες: Ath. 5.189 C (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Sacred Way: from the Eleusinion on the Akropolis northwest slope to Eleusis: Paus. 1.36.3. This road had different names depending on the function; three other names for the same route are listed below. Inside the City Wall the Sacred Way is wholly or partly coterminous with the Panathenaic Way q.v.; Travlos, J. 1971,159, 299, 302 (bibliography), 439, figs. 213 no. 237, 219 no. 237, 391 no. 175, 417 no. 175. No monograph on the Sacred Way has been published presenting the testimonia, the travellersʼ accounts and the excavations, although the Greek Archaeological Service has excavated the Sacred Way outside the City Wall at many different places and published highly informative reports, a representative one of which is cited here, O. Alexandri, «10. Ἱερὰ ὁδός,» Deltion 28 (1973) B1 Chr., 31 no. 10; Siewert, P. 1982, 39-41. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Sacred Way: Sacred Way for the Pythais procession to Delphi, boundary stone, 4th c. B.C., reused as a threshold block west of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos  Agora_I 5476; defining a section of the Sacred Way, Agora_XIV, 118 note 5, pl. 64:d; Agora_XIX, 29 H34, pl. 3; cf. Paus. 10.4.3, road from Athens to Delphi; J. McK. Camp et al., “An Athenian Dedication to Herakles at Panopeus,” Hesperia 66 (1997) 265-266 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Salamis: picture of the battle [supposedly] in the Stoa Poikile: schol. Gregory of Nazianos, Contra Iulianum I; Agora_XIV, 92 with note 49 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Sarapis: Sanctuary: Paus. 1.18.4 (Pausanias has just seen the Prytaneion on the Akropolis north slope and descended to lower Athens); no evidence that the state cult of Sarapis in Athens existed before the 2nd c. B.C., Chr. Habicht, “Bemerkungen zum P. Haun.6,” ZPE 39 (1980) 4 with note 17; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Sarmatian: cuirass made of maresʼ hooves, Asklepieion: Paus. 1.21.5-6 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Satyrs: Statue by Lysippos: Plin. Nat. 34.64 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Satyrs: Statue by Praxiteles on ancient Tripodes Street: Paus. 1.20.1-2; Ath. 13 591b; A. H. Borbein, “Die griechische Statue des 4. Jahrhunderts v. Chr.,” Jahrbuch 88 (1973) 194-197, 199 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Satyrs: Statue of a satyr boy in the temple of Dionysos on ancient Tripodes Street: Paus. 1.20.2; A. H. Borbein, op. cit, 196-197, 199 note 674 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Scythian (?) Archer-Police: places where they lived in the Agora and on the Areopagus: schol. Ar. Ach. 54; cf. L. Robert, Hellenica XI-XII, 1960, 271 note 2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Selene: Cult: schol. S. OC 100; FGRHIST III B, 101, Philochoros 328 F 12 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Seleukos I Nikator: bronze statue near the Stoa Poikile, 281 B.C. (or earlier): Paus. 1.16.1; Habicht, Chr. 1989, 9; Kotsidu, H. 2000, 73 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Semnai: Walled sanctuary on the Areopagus: Paus. 1.28.6-7; E. Wust, RE Suppl. VIII, 1956, col. 128-129 (Erinys) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Semnai: Altars (escharai): Paus. 1.28.6, Paus. 7.25.1 + 2 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Semnai: Statues, two by Skopas, the one in the middle by Kalamis: Paus. 1.28.6 (sculptors not mentioned); A. F. Stewart, Skopas of Paros, Park Ridge, 1977, 111, 129-130 testimonia nos. 22-25; LIMC III, 1986, 827 no. 2, 839-840 commentary 1b, s.v. Erinys (H. Sarian) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sibyrtios: palaestra, visited by Alkibiades: Plu. Alc. 3; Delorme, J. 1960, 59, 261 note 1 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Sikelia Hill: Paus. 8.11.12; FGRHIST III B, 230-231, Anonymer Perieget 369 F 1; very probably the present-day Sikelia Hill, south of the Ilissos, Judeich, W. 1931, 45 note 3 testimonia, 159 with note 3, 458 addendum to 158, Plan IV on the restored line of the Phaleric Wall south of the Hill of the Nymphs = site of the present-day Kallithea stadium; Conwell, D. A. 1933, 107, 202, 238-239, 247-269 passim; for traces of fortifications on present-day Sikelia Hill, see Curtius E. and J. A. Kaupert, 11 with plans I-II (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Silen: limestone statue opposite Andokidesʼ choregic tripod: Plu. Moralia 835 B (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Simon the Cobbler's Shop: ca. 450-400 B.C., southeast of the Tholos: D.L. 2.122; D. B. Thompson, “The House of Simon the Shoemaker,” Archaeology 13 (1960) 234-240 with plan and photos (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Skionians: and their allies, captured shields in the Stoa Poikile: Paus. 1.15.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Skiron and Skiros: Skiron, place along the Sacred Way named after Skiros: Paus. 1.36.4; Agora_III, 222 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Skiron and Skiros: Skiron, brook named after Skiros: Paus. 1.36.4 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Skiron and Skiros: Skiros, seer-hero from Dodona, grave on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.36.4; FGRHIST III B, suppl. vol. I, 285-305 especially 289-291 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Snake: Snake cult in the Erechtheion, celebrated with the Epimenia on the Noumenia: Hdt. 8.41; J. D. Mikalson, “The Noumena and Epimenia in Athens,” HThR 65 (1972) 291-296 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sokrates: son of Sophroniskos: House: Him. Or. 64.3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Sokrates: Altar for Sokratesʼ sacrifices at home: X. Mem. 1.1.2 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Sokrates: Sokrateion, Sokratesʼ grave stele near a spring on the road from Peiraeus to Athens: Marin. Procl. 10; K. Giannoulidou, «Πού εκειτο το Σωκρατειον;» PlatonP 31 (1979) 123-127; Camp, J. McK. II 1980, 326-327 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Sokrates: Bronze statue by Lysippos in the Pompeion: D.L. 2.43; E. Voutiras, op. cit, 137-146 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Solon: State grave mon. at the City Wall Gate: Ael. VH 8.16; perhaps a cenotaph, Clairmont, C. 1983, 8 with notes 2-3; Kerameikos IX, 11 note 26 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Solon: Solonʼs laws inscribed on axones, on kyrbeis, and on marble: Stroud, R. S. 1979, passim; SEG_51 2 (2001)
On axones, kept first on the Akropolis, then in the prytaneion: Poll. 8.128; Plu. Sol. 25.1; Paus. 1.18.3; Stroud, R. S. 1979, passim especially 12-13, 16-17, 19-20, 22, 33-34, 35, 41-44
On kyrbeis: Plu. Sol. 25.1; Stroud, R. S. 1979, passim especially 19-20, 41-44, 47-60
On marble: ibid., 8, 10, 42, 44 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Solon: Bronze statue in front of the Stoa Poikile: Paus. 1.16.1; Agora_III, 216; Richter, G. M. A. 1972, II, 204-205 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sophokles: Grave monument with siren or bronze swallow on the road to Dekeleia, 11 stades from the City Wall: Vita Soph. 15; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 229 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Sophokles: House in which Sophokles received Asklepios, probably where he set up an altar to him: EM s.v. Δεξίον; Ferguson, W. S. 1944, 90-91; Kearns, E. 1989, 154-155 s.v. Dexion; Beschi, L. 2002, 25; f. SEG_47 213 (1997) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Sophokles: Picture in the Stoa Poikile, Sophokles playing the kithara: Vita Soph. 5; Agora ill, 42-43 no. 90; Beschi, L. 1967/68a, 425-426 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sophokles: Statue set up by Iophon: Vita Soph. 11; Richter, G. M. A. 1972, II, 205 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Sophokles: Bronze statue in the Theatre: Paus. 1.21.1; Gauer, W. 1968b, 133, 135 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Sosandra: statue by Kalamis on the Akropolis: Lucian, Im. 4+6, DMeretr. 3.2; LIMC II, 1986, 23 no. 147, s.v. Aphrodite (A. Delivorrias et. al.) (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Spoudaios (?) Daimon: on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.3; Frazer, J. G. 1913, I, 564; Pritchett, W. K. 1998, 58-59 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Stoa Alphitopolis: Ar. Ec. 686; Agora_III, Index s.v. Stoas: Alphitopolis; Agora_XIV, 76 note 216, 82 note 3, 172 note 20; Stroud, R. S. 1998, 93 note 19 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Stoa Basileios: (Royal Stoa) 5th c. B.C.; 'first on the right in the Kerameikos': Paus. 1.3.1 + Paus. 1.3.2 + Paus. 1.14.6; Agora_III, 21-25 and Index s.v. Stoas: Basileios; Kuhn, G. 1985, 200-226, figs. 7-26; Camp. J. McK. 1986, 53-55, 57, fig. 5 no. 39, figs. 21, 32-36, 40-41, 55, 66, 71, 75-76, 129, 139, 152-153; T. L. Shear, Jr., “The Persian Destruction of Athens: Evidence from Agora Deposits,” Hesperia 62 (1993) 402, 418, 427-429, fig. 1; [doubtably] supposed to have been renamed the Stoa of the Herms, “N. Robertson,” The Stoa of the Herms,” ZPE 127 (1999) 167-174; [the Stoa was constructed after 480 B.C., probably in the second half of the century] (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Stoa Basileios: Terracotta acroteria groups, Theseus and Skiron, Hemera and Kephalos - - - Agora_T 1261+; Paus. 1.3.1; [with healthy skepticism] questioning the identification of the terracotta fragments with the acroteria seen by Pausanias on the roof of the Stoa Basileios, R. Nicholls, “Architectural Terracotta Sculpture from the Athenian Agora,” Hesperia 39 (1970) 120-123, C1-C3, pl. 25; Agora_XIV, 85 with note 10; Brommer, F. 1982, 17-18, 147; Danner, P. 1989, 22 nos. 140-141 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Stoa Poikile: also called Peisianakteios Stoa, 475-460 B.C.: Paus. 1.15-16.1, Paus. 5.11.6; Agora_III, 31-45 and Index s.v. Stoas: Poikile; Di Cesare, R. 2002, 43-47; the site is still uncertain; (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Stoa Poikile: Altar surrounded by a circular wooden enclosure in the stoa: D.L. 7.14; Agora_III, no. 64 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Strategos: theater throne - - - IG II² 5030; Maass, M. 1972, 113-114, pl. VIII; IG II² 5031 on the backrest refers to a curial meeting of the Assembly, Arist.Ath. 43.4 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Sueris: servant of the priestess Lysimache, statue base, 275-250 B.C., near the temple of Athena on the Akropolis: - - - IG II² 3464; Paus. 1.27.4; Lewis, D. M. 1955, 8 no. 3; SEG_51 216 (2001) (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Symbolon: name of a place near Andokidesʼ house: Plu. Moralia 580 D; Agora_III, no. 682; [the Symbolon is Theseus and Peirithoosʼ Covenant Place on the Akropolis north slope, Paus. 1.18.4]; see Theseus and Peirithoos (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Syngenicon: picture of a large family group in Athens by Athenion: Plin. Nat. 35.134 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Synhedrion: name of bldgs. or places where officials met: Pl. Tht. 173C-D; Agora_III, 126-128; Agora_XIV, 72 note 194; Agora_XVI, commentaries on no. 175 lines 3-4, no. 181 lines 39-40 and no. 194 line 12 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Taureas: (Davies, J. K. 1971, 29), palaestra of Taureas visited by Sokrates, across from the sanctuary of Basile: Pl. Chrm. 153 A; Wheeler, J. R. 1887, 45 with note 17; (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Technitai of Dionysos: Bouleuterion by the gate of the Kerameikos not far from the horsemen: Philostr. VS 2.8.2; Agora_III, 21 under no. 2; Aneziri, S. 2000, 268-269; [ the Pompeion may have been the Bouleuterion of the Technitai of Dionysos at one time] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Themis: Temple, Akropolis South Slope: seen by Pausanias (Paus. 1.22.1) on his way to the Akropolis after leaving the Asklepieion; temple facing southeast, west of the Asklepieion, 4th c. B.C., Walker, S. 1979a, 247 no. 8, 248, fig. 1 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Themistoklean City Wall: IG II² 463; Paus. 1.2.3 and 4, Paus. 1.20.6, Paus. 1.25.7 and 8; Milchhöfer, A. 1891, 78-81; Maier, F. G. 1959, 15-17, 48-67; idem 1961, passim; Judeich, W. 1931, 124-144, Plan I, Plan IV; Travlos, J. 1971, 158-161, figs. 28, 53, 130, 154, 213, 219, 221-226, 228, 230-231, 379-380, 391, 393, 417, 435, 438; Agora_XVI, no. 109, 171-174
Plans of the whole circuit: B1 Chr., Plan Alpha; Travlos, J. 1988, fig. 29;
Plan of the eastern and southeastern section in detail: Deltion 27 (1972) B1 Chr., 46 fig. 16
Plan of the southeastern section in detail: Deltion 23 (1968) B1 Chr., fig. 16 Plan of the northern section in detail: Deltion 24 (1969) B1 Chr., 42 fig. 12 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Themistoklean City Wall Gates: Sacred Gate: Plu. Sull. 14.3; perhaps the gate mentioned by Pausanias Paus. 1.2.4; Travlos, J. 1971, 159 (Sacred Gate), fig. 219 Gate III, figs. 223-224, 391, 393; Knigge, U. 1991, 56-67, figs. 1, 48, 53-56, 163-165; (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Themistoklean City Wall Gates: Gate between the Phaleric Wall and the South Long Wall: Judeich, W. 1931, 140, Plan I C 7-8 'Melitisches Tor,” Plan IV; Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 219 (the unlabelled gate almost due west of the peak of Philopappos Hill] (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Themistoklean City Wall: Hadrianic extension: schol. Aristid. Panath. III p. 201, 32 ff. (Dindorf) cited by Zahrnt, M. 1979, 393-394 with note 3; [the Post-Herulian extension of the Themistoklean City Wall (no. Wal35* below) was often thought to be Hadrianic] (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Themistoklean City Wall: Reconstruction of the Themistoklean circuit, mid-3rd c. A.C., during the reign of Valerian: Zos. 1.29; a [Post-Herulian] repair of the City Wall at Dipylou and Leokoriou Sts. using many inscribed gravestones, [mistakenly] assigned to the reign of Valerian., N. Kyparissis, «Άνασκαφή όδού Διπύλου,» Deltion 11 (1927/28) Parart. 56-58, figs. 14-15; Travlos, J. 1971, Index, 587 s.v. Valerian Wall (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Themistoklean City Wall: Towers added to the City Wall in latest 4th-6th c. A.C., usually ascribed to Justinianic restoration: Procop. Aed. 4.2.23; Parsons, A. W. 1943, 250 note 159; Thomson, H. A. and R. L. Scranton 1943, 373-376 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Themistokles: son of Neokles: House in Melite, near the sanctuary of Artemis Aristoboule: Plu. Them. 22.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Themistokles: Inscribed plaque set up by Themistokles for a choregic victory with a drama by Phrynichos, 477/6 B.C.: Plu. Them. 5.4; Ghiron-Bastagne, P. 1976, 94-95 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Themistokles: Picture with a portrait of Themistokles dedicated by his sons in the Parthenon: Paus. 1.1.2; P. Amandry, “Themistocle a Melite,” in Orlandos Charisterion 1965-1968, IV, 277 note 27; [During his tour of the Peiraeus Pausanias mentions this portrait but when he reached the Parthenon which had recently been repaired after a fire he did not see it] (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Themistokles: Statuette (eikonion) in the temple of Artemis Aristoboule: Plu. Them. 22.1; Threpsiades, J. and E. Vanderpool 1964, 35-36; Gauer, W. 1968b, 140 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Themistokles: son of Poliarchos, grandson of Themistokles, grave on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.1; Davies, J. K. 1971, 218 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Theodektes of Phaselis: the tragedian, grave with statue of Homer and other great poets, on the Sacred Way at the Kephisos crossing near the altar of Zeus Meilichios: Plu. Moralia 837 D; Paus. 1.37.4; Further Greek Epigrams, 1981, 431-2 no. 125; Scholl, A. 1994, 252-254, fig. 9 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Theodoros: the tragic actor, grave on the Sacred Way before the Kephisos crossing: Paus. 1.37.3 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Theodoros: father of Isokrates, statue on the Akropolis: Plu. Moralia 839 D (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Theophrastosʼ Garden: near or adjoining the Lykeion: D.L. 5.52-54, 55; Lynch, J. P. 1972, 22, 28-29, 98-102, 125-6 note 27, 209-211; Ritchie Jr., C. E. 1989, 250-251, 258, 260; (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theophrastosʼ Garden: Peripatos: D.L. 5.52 + D.L. 5.54 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Theophrastosʼ Garden: Houses adjoining the garden: D.L. 5.52 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Theophrastosʼ Garden: Theophrastosʼ grave in his Garden: D.L. 5.53 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Thesauros: with paintings by Polygnotos: Harp. s.v. Πολυγνώτου; Dinsmoor, W. B. 1932, 317-18 with note 3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Theseus: Sanctuary, the Theseion, next to the Gymnasium of Ptolemy on the Akropolis north slope: Paus. 1.17.2 + Paus. 1.17.6; Agora_III, 113-119, nos. 339-362; E. Vanderpool, “The 'Agora' of Pausanias 1.17, 1-2.” Hesperia 43 (1974) 308-310; Koumanoudes, S. N. 1976 [1977], 194-216 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Theseus: Theseusʼ bones brought from Skyros by Kimon in 476/5 B.C. and buried in the Theseion: Paus. 1.17.6, Paus. 3.3.7; Develin, R. 1989, 68 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theseus: Temenos of Theseus founded by himself: Plu. Thes. 13.3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Theseus: Picture by Aristolaus, son of Pausias: Plin. Nat. 35.137; LIMC III, 1986, 379 no. 49, s.v. Demos (O. Alexandri-Tzahou) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Theseus: Picture by Parrhasios: Plu. Thes. 4, Moralia 346 A; according to Plin. Nat. 35.69, the picture was in the Capitoline (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

descriptions.value: Theseus: Theseus, Demokratia and Demos, picture by Euphranor, in the Stoa of Zeus: Paus. 1.3.3; Palagia, O. 1980, 1-2 no. 7, 2-3 no. 14, 3-4 no. 18, 50-51, 57-60 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theseus: Theseus fetching Minosʼ seal ring from the sea, picture by Mikon in the Theseion: Paus. 1.17.3; Brommer, F. 1982, 77-83; Neils, J. 1994, 939 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theseus: Statue by Silanion, late 4th c. B.C.: Plu. Thes. 4; F. Brommer, “Theseus-Statuen,” AM 97 (1982) 145-146, 147-148 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theseus: Statue in the Ares precinct: Paus. 1.8.4; F. Brommer, op. cit.,145, 151 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Theseus: Statue, Akropolis: Paus. 1.27.8; cf. C. Sourvinou-lnwood, “Theseus Lifting the Rock and a Cup Near the Pithos Painter,” JHS 91 (1971) 94-109; represented on imperial bronze coins, Thompson, M. 1982, 166, 169 with note 23, pl. 28 no. 14; Neils, J. 1994, 925 no. 29, ph. and cf. no. 28, ph., coins of Troezen (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Theseus: Theseus and the Marathonian Bull, dedicated by the people of Marathon, Akropolis: Paus. 1.27.9-10; Brommer, F. 1982, 33-4; represented on bronze imperial coins, Thompson, M. 1982, 166, 169-170, pl. 28 nos. 15-16; cf. Bulls: Fragments (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Theseus: Theseus and the Minotaur, group on the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.1; Brommer, F. 1982, 49-55, 57 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Theseus and Peirithoos: Krater-shaped hollow in the rock marking the place where Theseus and Peirithoos made their pact: S. OC, 1593; the site (but not the hollow in the rock) seen by Pausanias, Paus. 1.18.4, not far from the sanctuary of Sarapis; probably in the area around the Roman Agora, Travlos, J. 1971, 28; see Symbolon; (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Thesmophorion, precinct: Ar. Th. lines 278, 880; Agora_III, no. 224; for summaries of K. Clintonʼs arguments that the deme of Melite celebrated its local festival of the Thesmophoria in the Eleusinion, see SEG 46 (1996) nos. 20, 152, 160; (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Thesmothetai: Thesmotheteion where the Thesmothetai met and dined: Arist.Ath. 3.5; Agora_III, 177-179; Rhodes, P. J. 1981, 106; conjectural location on the Akropolis north slope east of the Eleusinion, Travlos, J. 1971, 2, fig. 5 no. 18; for a public dining room, perhaps the Thesmothetion, located somewhere around the northwest corner of the Agora, see Rotroff, S. I. and J. H. Oakley 1992, 38-40, 59 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Thesmothetai: Picture of the Thesmothetai by Protogenes of Kaunos in the Bouleuterion: Paus. 1.3.5; Thompson, H. A. 1937, 214 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Tholos: near the Bouleuterion: Paus. 1.5.1; Agora_III, 179-184; Agora_XIV, 41-46, figs. 1, 12, 13 and pls. 3, 5-9, 11-13, 28, 33:A; Camp, J. McK. 1986, 231 (Index), figs. 5 no. 46, figs. 51-53, 66, 68, 71, 91, 129, 139, 151-153, 166 and pl. I (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Thrasyboulos: son of Lykos
The first grave seen by Pausanias on the Road to the Academy: Paus. 1.29.3. Just before Pausanias starts to report the Demosion Sema monuments, he mentions four monuments for individuals buried at state expense: Thrasyboulos, Perikles, Chabrias, and Phormion; hypothetical [and O so doubtable] location of Thrasyboulosʼ grave on Salaminos St. approximately opposite Kerameikos Horoi 2 and 3, Stichel, R. H. W. 1998, 153-154, 156. [Because Cicero and Livy mention the Dipylon Gate as the starting point for the Road to the Academy, scholars assume that Pausanias also started there, it ain't necessarily so. Pausanias does not say that he started at a gate and indeed he does not mention the Dipylon Gate throughout his narrative. He may have started his walk along the Road to the Academy at some distance from the Dipylon Gate.] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Thrasyllos: choregic monument above the Theater of Dionysos at the cave of Panagia Spiliaiotissa (Chr. Mon. CM78*): Paus. 1.21.3 (Thrasyllos not mentioned); Travlos, J. 1971, 562-565, fig. 71 no. 142, figs. 704-708; Townsend, R. F. 1982, 181-198, 219-222 (notes 27-61), figs. 105-116; Wilson, P. 2000, 229-234, figs. 17-20 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Thrasyllos: Apollo and Artemis slaying Niobeʼs children: Paus. 1.21.3; [implausibly] called a wall-painting, Travlos, J. 1971, 562; A. H. Borbein, op. cit under Thrasykles, 58, 59, 198-199; [plausibly] a sculpture group inside the cave, Townsend, R. F. 1982, 195-198 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Thrasylos: bath: Alciphr. 3.40; Camp, J. McK. 1980, 346-347 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Thriasian Gate: earlier name for the Dipylon Gate: Plu. Per. 30.3; Stroszeck, J. 2003, 74 with notes 97-99; see Themistoklean City Wall Wal6* (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Thucydides: son of Oloros
Grave mon. with epitaph, in Kimonʼs family plot in Koile not far from the Melitides Gate: Marcellin. Vit. Thuc. 16-17; Paus. 1.23.9; O. Luschat, RE Suppl. XII, 1970, col. 1105-1106 (Thukydides) (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Thucydides: Statue (?) on the Akropolis (?), conjecture arising from an interpretation of Paus. 1.23.9; K. Deichgraber, RE XXI, 1952, col. 1293 line 58 - col. 1294 line 7 (Polemon); Richter, G. M. A. 1965, I, 148 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Timon: tower near Platoʼs grave and Kolonos Hippios: Paus. 1.30.4; Svoronos, J. N. 1911, 400 with note 2; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 780 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Timotheos: Tyche and Timotheos, picture: Piu. Sull. 6.3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Tolmides: son of Tolmaios: Tolmides and his seer Theainetos, statue group (andriantes) on the Akropolis near the Temple of Athena: Paus. 1.27.5; cf. Th. 3.20.1; Stupperich, R. 1977, 1.12; [doubtably thought to be part of a four-figure group with Erechtheus fighting Eumolpos q.v. ] (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Toxaris: 6th c. B.C., heroized as Xenos Iatros in 429 B.C., inscribed grave stele with relief of a Scythian holding a bow and a book, not far from the Dipylon, on the left going to the Academy: Lucian, Scyth. 1-2; Pantazopoulos, N. I. 1947/48, 106, 109-111; Pritchett, W. K. 1998, 18 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Trigla: the place where Hekate Triglanthine stood: Ath. 7.323 (325 D); Judeich, W. 1931, 178 note 3 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Trigonon: lawcourt: Paus. 1.28.8; Agora_XXVIII, Index s.v. Trigonon  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Tripodes: place-name derived from the name of the street, 6-6.50 m. wide, starting at the Prytaneion [on the Akropolis upper north slope], going clockwise around the Akropolis slopes to the precinct of Dionysos Eleuthereus: Paus. 1.20.1; A. Choremi-Spetsieri, «Η οδός των Τρίποδων και τα χορηγικά μνημεία στην αρχαία Αθήνα» in Coulson et al. 1994, 31-42, figs. 1-10; Κ. N. Kazamiakis, «Η Οδός των Τριπόδων— τεχνικά και κατασκευαστικά στοιχεία,» ibid., 43-44; the ancient street forked at the intersection of Prytaneiou and Tholou Sts., just east of the Old University (Plan I no. 124), both branches leading to the Panathenaic Way, A. Choremi-Spetsieri, op. cit, 35, fig. 2; Travlos, J. 1971, 198, 566, figs. 540 no. 186, 710; Agora_XXXI, 1, 11 with note 3, 12 with note 5, fig. 2 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Tripods: of bronze enclosing memorable artworks, supported on temples, Street of the Tripods: Paus. 1.20.1, referring to choregic monuments; A. H. Borbein, “Die griechische statue des 4. Jahrhunderts v. Chr.,” Jahrbuch 88 (1973) 55, 194 -198, Anhang II (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Triptolemos: Temple facing north, early 5th c. B.C., in the forecourt of the Eleusinion: Paus. 1.14.1 + Paus. 1.14.4; Agora_XXXI, 35-57 and Index, s.v. Temple of Triptolemos (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Triptolemos: Temple statue: Paus. 1.14.1 + Paus. 1.14.4; Eschbach, N. 1986, 109-123, especially 117-118; Agora_XXXI, 52 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Trite Rhume: place-name or street name: Poll. 9.38; Judeich, W. 1931, 183 note 10 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Trojan Horse: with Menestheus, Teukros, and Theseusʼ sons, Akamas and Demophon, colossal bronze by Strongylion dedicated by Chairedemos on the Akropolis, ca. 415 B.C. - - - IG I³ 895 = IG I² 535; Acr. 13264; Paus. 1.23.8-9; Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 72; [mistakenly] located in the Brauronion [where no suitable bedding exists], G. P. Stevens, “The Periclean Entrance Court of the Acropolis of Athens,” Hesperia 5 (1936) 460-461, 483, fig. 14; Kron, U. 1976, 151-152; SEG_30 25 (1980); perhaps on the rock bedding north of the processional way (Kavvadias-Kawerau, 1906, plan Alpha no. 10), Μ. E. Caskey, rev. of R. E. Wycherley, The Stones of Athens in AJA 83 (1979) 359 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Twelve Gods: Inscribed altar dedicated by Peisistratos son of Hippias, stuccoed poros limestone, 522/521 B.C. Agora_A 1198-99+; Th. 6.54.6-7; Crosby, M. 1949, 82, 93-94, fig. 7, pl. 14 nos. 1-3; Gadbery, L. M. 1992, 448-450, 461-462 note 32, fig. 12, pl. 108: b,d; formerly [mistakenly] merged with the Altar of Pity, cf. Eleos (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Twelve Gods: Picture by Euphranor in Stoa of Zeus: Paus. 1.3.3; testimonia, Pollitt, J. J. 1990, 167-168; Palagia, O. 1980, 1-2 no. 7, 2 no. 10, 3-4 no. 18, 4 no. 25, 50-51, 54-57 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Tyche of the Polis: temple built by Herodes Atticus, overlooking the Panathenaic Stadium: Philostr. VS 11.18; Gasparri, C. 1974/75, 367-375, figs. 3-6, 12, 14, 65-77 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Tyche of the Polis: Temple statue of ivory: Philostr. VS 11.18; Tobin, J. 1997, 175 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Unknown God(s): Altars dedicated to anonymous local divinities, set up in the early 6th c. B.C. according to Epimenidesʼ instructions: D.L. 1.110; P. W. v. d. Horst, op. cit., 1430-1431 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Unknown God(s): Altar dedicated to unknown daimones: Philostr. VA 6.3; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 33-34; P. W. v. d. Horst, op. cit, 1432-1432 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Unknown God(s): Altar dedicated to The Unknown God, the Agnostos Theos mentioned by Paul, location not specified: Acts 17.23; the altar to The Unknown God was in the Parthenon according to Pope Innocent III in 1208: PL vol. 215, cols. 1559-1561, CCLVI; Travlos, J. and A. Frantz 1965, 194 testimonium no. 1; for the Parthenon as the temple of the Unknown God, see Vienna Anonymous 11, L. Ross, ed., Archaologische Aufsatze II (1855) 246-254; F. Mallouchou-Tufano, “The Parthenon from Cyriacus of Ancona to Frederic Boissonas,” in Parthenon 1994, 166, 196-197 note 9 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Unknown God(s): Altar dedicated to the gods of Asia, Europe and Libya, to the Unknown and Strange God: Oecumenius on Acts 17.23 (PG CXVIII.238); L. Ziehen, RE XVIII,1949, col. 718-719 note 1 (Pantheion); cf. Paus. 1.1.4 (altar of Unknown Gods in Phaleron) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Xanthippos: Periklesʼ father, statue on the Akropolis near the statue of Anakreon: Paus. 1.25.1 (twice); Holscher, T. 1975, i87, 191 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Xerxes: silver-footed stool in the Parthenon: D. 24.129; F. J. Frost, “A Note on Xerxes at Salamis,” Historia 22 (1973) 118-119 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zarmaros: Indian gymnosophist from Bargosa, tomb: Str. 15.1.4 + Str. 15.1.73; K. Ziegler, RE IX A2,1967, col. 2329 (Zarmaros) (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Zeno of Kition: stoic philosopher
State burial monument: on the the Road to the Academy, Paus. 1.29.15; tomb in the Kerameikos to be constructed at state expense accorded by a decree, 262/1 B.C., to be inscribed on two stelai, set up in the Academy and in the Lykeion, D.L. 7.10-12 + D.L. 7.15 + D.L. 7.29; Stupperich, R. 1977, 26 with note 1, 264 with note 1; S. V. Tracy, “Antigonos Gonatas, King of Athens,” in Macedonians in Athens 2003, 57-58 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Zeno of Kition: Bronze statue accorded by decree: D.L. 7.6; K. Schefold, 'Ariston von Chios,” in Eikones, Studien zum griechischen und romischen Bildnis: Hans Jucker zum sechzigsten Geburtstag gewidmet (Antike Kunst, Suppl. 12), Bern, 1980,162-163 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Zephyros: altar on the Sacred Way: Paus. 1.37.2; Neuser, K. 1982, 191 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus: Garden of Zeus with well: Plin. Nat. 31.3.28 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Zeus: Bronze statue in the Olympieion precinct: Paus. 1.18.7 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus: Statue by Leochares on the the Akropolis: Paus. 1.24.4 (mentioned together with a statue of Zeus Polieus) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus: Statue in the precinct of Dionysos Melpomenos: Paus. 1.2.5 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus: Vote of Zeus, Διός ψήφος, place on the Akropolis where Zeus cast his vote for Athena: Hsch. s.v. Διὸς θᾶκοι; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 301-302 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus: Zeus Anchesmios, statue on Anchesmos hill: Paus. 1.32.2; Langdon, Μ. K. 1976, 101-102 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Zeus: Zeus Astrapaios, eschara on the wall between the Pythion and the Olympieion where the Pythaistai kept watch for the lightning sign over Harma: Str. 9.2.11; on the City Wall, E. Meyer, REXXIV, 1963, col. 556 line 67 - col. 558 (Pythion); Wycherley, R. E. 1959, 68-72; Nulton, P. E. 2000, 13, 19-23; cf. Pelargikon (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus: Zeus Basileios, cult: Poll. 8.122; A. L. Boegehold, “Philokleonʼs Court,” Hesperia 36 (1967) 116 note 24; Schwabl, H. 1978, cols. 1446-1447 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Zeus Boulaios: Xoanon in the Bouleuterion: Paus. 1.3.5; Agora_III, no. 402 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Stoa of Zeus Eleutherios (Athens Agora) (Paus. 1.3.3-4, Paus. 1.26.2, Paus. 10.21.6)

descriptions.value: Zeus Eleutherios: Stoa, last third of the 5th c. B.C., Agora west side: Paus. 1.3.3-4, Paus. 1.26.2, Paus. 10.21.6; Thompson, H. A. 1937, 5-59, figs. 2-35, pls. 1-2; Travlos, J. 1971, 527-533, figs. 29 no. 37, 655-672; Agora_Guide 1990, 77-79, 275 no. 77, figs. 4-8, 18-19, 37, 56; (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Zeus Eleutherios: Statue in front of the stoa: Paus. 1.3.2; Agora_III, nos. 16, 26-28, 35, 41; also called Zeus Soter, ibid., nos. 28-29, 42; perhaps the standing Zeus on Athenian bronze coins associated with Flamininusʼ victory over Philip V in 197 B.C., Agora_XXVI, 51,54,55, 57, 63 nos. 78-80 with pl. 8, 87, 106 no. 148 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Zeus Eleutherios: Shield of Kydias, killed fighting the Galatians at Thermopylai in 279 B.C., dedicated to Zeus Eleutherios, removed by Sulla: Paus. 10.21.5-6; Habicht, Chr. 1985, 83-84; the epigram preserved by Pausanias has the earliest mention of the Galatians, F. Chamoux, “1) Dedicace metrique pour le bouclier de l'Athenien Cydias,” REG 101 (1988) 498 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Stoa of Zeus

descriptions.value: Zeus Eleutherios: Leokritosʼ shield dedicated to Zeus Eleutherios by the Athenians with an inscription recording his name and successful accomplishments: Paus. 1.26.2 (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus Herkeios: Altar on the Akropolis under the olive tree in the Pandroseion: D.H. Din. 3; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 474-475 (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Zeus Hypatos: Altar in front of the Erechtheion: Paus. 1.26.5, Paus. 8.2.3; [wildly implausible] conjectural site in the Erechtheion east colonnade jammed up against the east cella wall in an unparalleled manner, Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 281 A; Kron, U. 1976, 44-46; cf. Thyechoos (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus Karios: Zeus Karios, cult practiced in Isagorasʼ family: Hdt. 5.66; Kron, U. 1976, 16 note 12; D. M. Lewis, “Cleisthenes and Attica,” Historia 12 (1963) 26 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)
Zeus Maimaktes: Zeus Maimaktes, cult: Plu. Moralia 458 B-C; Schwabl, H. 1978, col. 1069 (point accuracy ca. 1500m)

Zeus Meilichios: Altar at the far side of the Kephisos crossing where Theseus was purified: Paus. 1.37.4; M. Jameson, “The Sacrificial Calendar from Erchia,” BCH 89 (1965) 161, 164 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus Morios: Zeus Morios, altar of Kataibates Zeus also called Morios at the Academy, beside the sanctuary of Athena: schol. S.OC 705; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 736-740 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Zeus Olympios: Zeus Olympios, sanctuary founded by Deukalion: Paus. 1.18.6-8 + Paus. 1.19.1; founded 1528 B.C., Marmor Parium 7, IG XII,5 444; Travlos, J. 1971, 402-411, figs. 380-381, 521-531; Wycherley, R. E. 1978, 155-164; Willers, D. 1990, 26-53, figs. 9-14, pls. 2-3; Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1994, 117-120 (testimonia), 174-179 (bibliography) (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Zeus Olympios: The Peisistratid temple, uncompleted Doric temple of poros limestone built by the architects Antistates, Kallaischros, Antimachides and Porinos, before 510 B.C.: Vitr. 7.pr.15 Preface (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Zeus Olympios: The third temple (the first marble temple) had three phases:
1) The temple was designed and construction begun in the late classical period; M. Korres, «Ολυμπιείον,» Anthemio 5 (January 1999) 27-29
2) Temple built to the architrave level by the Roman architect, Decimus Cossutius, for Antiochos IV of Syria before 164 B.C.: Vitr. Preface to 7.15; Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1994, 117-119 (testimonia for the Hellenistic Olympieion); Schenkungen hellenistischer Herrscher, Part I, 1995, 54-56, and Part II, vol. 2, 2000, 268-270
3) Temple completed under Hadrian by 131/132 A.D.: Paus. 1.18.6, Paus. 1.19.1. (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Zeus Olympios: Gold and ivory temple statue: Paus. 1.18.6; Paus. 2.27.2; most likely a copy of Pheidiasʼ temple statue at Olympia as indicated by the inscriptions on the Theatre thrones Zeu81* and Zeu83* below (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus Olympios: Precinct wall: Paus. 1.18.6 + 7; Stuart, J. and N. Revett 1764, 14-15, 16, 17, 22, 23, Chapter 2 pls. 1-3, Chapter 3 pl. 1 (point accuracy ca. 50m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Zeus Olympios: Phaidyntesʼ theater throne for the cleaner of the statue of Zeus Olympios at Pisa (Olympia) - - - IG II² 5064; Maass, M. 1972, 131, pl. 17; cf. Paus. 5.14.5  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Zeus Polieus: Altar: Paus. 1.24.4, Paus. 1.28.10; Gill, G. 1991, 28 no. 5 (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Zeus Polieus: Statue: Paus. 1.24.4 (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Zeus Soter: Sanctuary: schol. Ar. Pl. 1175; Agora_III, nos. 24, 43 and cf. nos. 37, 40, 46 Statue: see Zeus Zeu22* (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Mycenaean Gateway: 13th c. B.C., probably in the southwest area of the Old Propylon: Arist.Ath. 15.4; Dinsmoor Jr., W. B. 1980, 1-4, pl. 1; demolition [arbitrarily] dated to [that magnetic year] 566 B.C. when the Mycenaean Gateway was [supposedly] replaced by a new monumental entrance, Travlos, J. 1971, 482  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Old Propylon: Hdt. 8.53; Dinsmoor Jr., W. B. 1980; Tanoulas, T. 1992, 159-160 with note 69, Beilage 10; the two phases of the Old Propylon according to Korres, M. 1997, 243 with note 99 are as follows:
Between 490-485 B.C. a new marble propylon (PP I) was designed and built as far as the orthostates when the project was interrupted.
After the Persian destruction in 479 B.C., a new propylon (PP II) was designed with smaller columns; between 438-431 B.C. some blocks of PP II were reused in the Erechtheion (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Propylaia: 437-432 B.C.: IG I³ 462-466; SEG_50 67 (2000); Paus. 1.22.4 + Paus. 1.22.6 + Paus. 1.28.4; represented on Athenian bronze coins, 3rd c. A.C., e.g. M. J. Price, “Architecture on ancient coins,” The British Museum Yearbook 1 (1976) 42 fig. 80 (BM 1922.3-17.82); Bundgaard, J. A. 1957, passim; Tanoulas, T. 1994a, 52-57; idem 1994b, 181-183, idem, 1997, 2 vols.; W. B. Dinsmoor and W. B. Dinsmoor Jr., The Propylaia to the Athenian Acropolis: Volume II. the Classical Building, Princeton, 2004 [a work ignoring the publications of T. Tanoulas to its detriment]
Cuttings for monument bases in niches in the west front: G. P. Stevens, “The Periclean Entrance Court of the Acropolis at Athens,” Hesperia 5 (1936) 446-447, fig. 2 G, H
Propylaia northwest chamber with paintings, the so-called Pinakotheke: Paus. 1.22.6 (oikema); Dinsmoor Jr. W. B. 1982,18-33, figs. 1-7; [implausibly] restored as a dining room, Travlos, J. 1971, 482, figs. 614, 618-619; [the modern name “Pinakotheke” having somehow acquired an ancient patina has become entrenched in the terminology] (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Frankish Dukes' Residence: in the Propylaia after 1204: Vienna Anonymous 10; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 519-520, 523, Tanoulas, T. 1994a, 60-62; idem, 1997, Vol. I, 291-300 and Vol II, drs. 60, 62-72  (point accuracy ca. 50m)

properties.title: Mycenaean circuit wall of the Acropolis (Paus. 1.28.3)

names.toponym: Mycenaean circuit wall of the Acropolis

descriptions.value:
Mycenaean Circuit Wall: Iakovides, S. E. 1962, 25-29, 179-199, 231-235, plans 17, 19-38, figs. 17-20, 23-24, 26-29
Built by the Pelasgians: Hdt. 6.137; Paus. 1.28.3 Called the Pelargikon: Hdt. 5.64-65; Iakovides, S. E. 1962, 231-232 (testimonia) (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Wooden Wall: Hdt. 7.141-143, Hdt. 8.51-52; Paus. 1.18.2; W. B. Dinsmoor, “The Correlation of Greek Archaeology with History,” Studies in The History of Culture (in honor of W. G. Leland), P. W. Long ed., Menasha, Wisconsin, 1942, 209-211  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

properties.title: Classical Circuit Wall on Akropolis (Paus. 1.21.3, Paus. 1.25.2, Paus. 1.28.3)

descriptions.value:
Classical Circuit Wall: Kavvadias, K. and G. Kawerau 1906, 26-27, 30, 70, 90-92, 96, 114-122, pls. alpha-kappa, mu, figs. 1-2; Boersma, J. S. 1970, Index, 284 s.v. Akropolis, Precinct Wall
South wall: Paus. 1.21.3 + 25.2 + 28.3; the demos constructed the Akropolis south wall with funds from the sale of booty from Kimonʼs victories, Plu. Cim. 13; represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins of the 3rd c. A.C., Price, J. M. and B. L. Drell 1977, 68 fig. 133, 78 with fig. 133; G. Beckel, “Akropolisfragen,” in Orlandos Charisterion IV, 331-4, 338-344, 351-3 with fig. 1 and pls. 102, 103:b; Mark, I. S. 1993, 58, 59 note 52, 130
North wall, begun during the 440s and finished during the 430s: represented on Athenian imperial bronze coins of the 3rd c. A.C., Price, J. M. and B. L. Drell 1977, 68 fig. 130, 76 figs. 130-131, 77; Tanoulas, T. 1992, 201-202, 203, 210, 214, pls. 46:2, 47,49, 52:2, 54:2, 55:2, 56:2, Beilage 11; [mistakenly] called Themistoklean Wall by Judeich, W. 1931, 72 note 1, 74, 209, and by Travlos, J. 1971, 143; [mistakenly] dated to 479 B.C., Korres, M. 1997, 243, 245; most of the wall [non-evidentially] assigned a Themistoklean date, idem, On the North Acropolis Wall,” in Stamatopoulou and Yerolanou 2000, 179-186, figs. 1-4
Rebuilding of an eastern section of the north wall, 3rd c. A.C.: H. R. Immerwahr, “Five Dedicatory Inscriptions from the North Wall of the Acropolis,” Hesperia 11 (1942) 338-341, fig. 1 [a Post-Herulian repair] Section of the circuit wall to be built (on the west front?) in 60 days, ca. 450-445 B.C.: IG I³ 45 lines 12-13; Mark, I. S. 1993, 64-65; SEG_44 3 (1994) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Cicero's Living Quarters: in October, 50 B.C.: Cic. Att. VI.9, in arce Athenis statio mea nunc placet  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Megaron Facing West: Hdt. 5.77, cf. Hdt. 8.53; Caskey, L. D. et al. 1927, 433, 436, 437, 438; Dinsmoor Jr., W. B. 1980, 5, 43 note 25; for a study of the word “megaron”, see Eurydice Condoleon Bolanacchi, «Μεγάρου Επίσκεψή I,» Horos 10-12 (1992-1998) 473-490 esp. 478 480  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

North Wall Building: (Bldg. Ill): 'an ein Wohngebaude ist der sehr starken Fundamente wegen wohl nicht zu denken,' Kavvadias-Kawerau, 1906, 32, 76-78, pi. gamma no. 15; [non-evidentially] identified as the House of Arrhephoroi, G. P. Stevens, “The Periclean Entrance Court of the Acropolis of Athens,” Hesperia 5 (1936) 489-491, figs. 1, 40, 44, 66; [non-evidentially] identified as the Erechtheion, Jeppesen, K. 1979, 386-394, figs, 1-3  (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Altar: on which Kylonʼs followers sat, 7th c. B.C.: Th. 1.26; normally taken to be the altar of Athena Polias, Milchhöfer, A. 1891, 20 lines 90-92  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Golden Shields: taken from the Akropolis by Lachares: Paus. 1.25.7; Frazer, J. G. 1913, II, 326, suggests that the shields sent by Alexander the Great may have been gilded; see Alexander, panoplies; Parthenon, shields  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Boy Carrying Hydrias: picture in the Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.7  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Wrestler: picture by Timainetos, in the Propylaia northwest chamber: Paus. 1.22.7  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Boy with Perirrhanterion: by Lykios the son of Myron: Paus. 1.23.7; Raubitschek, A. E. 1949, 155, 518-519; Pimpl, H. 1997, 115-116  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Man Wearing Helmet: statue with inlaid silver nails by Kleoitas: Paus. 1.24.3; inscribed base perhaps for this statue: Paus. 6.20.14; G. Lippold, REX I, 1921, col. 657-658 (Kleoitas)  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Youth By Praxiteles: Callistr. Stat. 11  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

relations.label: in or near Theater of Dionysos

descriptions.value: Sundials: Conical dial, in situ above the Theater east of the Thrasyllos Mon.: Vienna Anonymous 4; Gibbs, S. L. 1976, 227 no. 3008 G, pl. 28  (point accuracy ca. 50m)

House of Proklos: with mosaic floors, early 5th c. A.C. villa, below and to the south of Dion. Areopagitou Ave., west of Parthenonos St. (Plan 1 theta:—5): I. Meliades, «Άνασκαφαι νοτίως τής Άκροπόλεως (Πρώτη προσωρινή εκθεσις),» Praktika 1955, 46-50, fig. 1 Α (Νεοπλατωνική Σχολή), pls. 3:b, 4-8; Proklosʼ house tentatively suggested, [unsigned report], “Chronique des fouilles en 1955,” BCH 80 (1956) 232-234, figs. 1-2; Spiro, M. 1978, 5-10, pls. 6-8; Agora_XXIV, 42-44, pls. 27:b, 36:b; 44:a-b; [mistakenly] accepted as Proklosʼ house, P. Castren, “General Aspects of Life in Post-Herulian Athens,” in Castren, P. ed. 1994, 7, 12-13 ; [with flagrant distortions of the evidence, mistakenly] championed as Proklosʼ house, Karivieri, A. 1994b, 115-139, figs. 2a, 2b, 3, 11-15, 17-27, 31-33; for the “wisdom” inscription, actually a grave epigram, see SEG_19 234 (1963), SEG_44 215 (1994), and Sironen, E. 1997, 365 no. 369; the identification as Proklosʼ house supported with reservations, Baumer, L. E. 2001, 55-69; the identification wisely questioned by P. Castren cited by L. E. Baumer, op. cit, 62 note 50; cf. Plato, portrait head M 163; Ploutarchos, son of Nestorios, house
Niche-shrine (?) inside the house with reliefs of a much earlier date found in situ (2nd period of use) (point accuracy ca. 10m)

properties.title: Caves of Apollo, Pan, Zeus (Athens Acropolis)

names.toponym: Caves of Apollo, Pan, Zeus (Athens Acropolis)

descriptions.value:
Caves: Alpha, Beta, Gamma and Delta high up on the Akropolis northwest slope are mostly grottoes and ledges, caves is a courtesy title: Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 116 (caves labelled A,B,C,D)
CAVE ALPHA, the westernmost cave, with stepped rock-cut benches: Kavvadias, P. 1897, 3-4, pls. 1-2; Travlos, J. 1971, 417, fig. 116; [mistakenly] assigned to Pan, Edwards, C. M. 1985, 26; Nulton, P. E. 2000, 8-10, 12, 32 note 78, fig. 1
CAVE with the Klepsydra Springhouse: see Klepsydra
CAVE BETA: see Apollo
CAVE GAMMA directly below the northeast corner of the Northwest Bldg. on the Akropolis: [mistakenly] identified as the site of a [purely imaginary] second Shrine of Zeus Olympios on the Akropolis northwest Slope, Travlos, J. 1971, 91, 417, figs. 115-116, Cave C; cf. Wycherley, R. E. 1959, 68-73; Nulton, P. E. 2000, 11, 13-26; [the temenos of Aglauros was perhaps on the terrace in front of the cave]
CAVE DELTA: see Pan (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Hut: on the Areopagus Hill: Vitr. 11.1.5  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Bema: built by Roman generals in front of the Stoa of Attalos: Ath. 5.212 F; Agora_Guide 1990, 127-130, 276  (point accuracy ca. 10m)

relations.label: in or near Odeon of Agrippa

descriptions.value: Southeast Fountain House: 530-520 B.C., Pausaniasʼ Enneakrounos seen near the Odeion [of Agrippa]: Paus. 1.14.1 (twice); Camp, J. McK. 1986, 42-43, fig. 5 no. 21, figs. 21, 25-26, 29, 66, 107, 129, 139, 153 and pl. I; dated 510-500 B.C., Tolle-Kastenbein, R. 1986, 65; a date later than 500 B. C. plausibly suggested, Papadopoulos, J. K. 2003, 295 note 141  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Silver Statues: not big, in the Tholos: Paus. 1.5.1; cf. J. R. Fears, “Ο ΔΗΜΟΣ Ο ΡΩΜΑΙΩΝ GENIUS POPULI ROMANI,” Mnemosyne 31 (1978) 274-275  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Statue: at the Stoa Basileios thrown down by an evil spirit exorcised by Apollonius of Tyana, 1st c. A.D.: Philostr. VA 4.20  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Gate with Tropaion: marking the site of Pleistarchosʼ defeat in a cavalry battle, 304 B.C., near Hermes Agoraios: Paus. 1.15.1; Habicht, Chr. 1985, 78-80; SEG_39 293 (1989) and 49 (1999) no. 109; Di Cesare, R. 2001, 23-24; this gate was given a modern name 'Hippomachia Gate' by J. Travlos, who placed it on these two sites
1) conjectural location west of the church of Hag. Philippou, Travlos, J. 1971, figs. 30-31 (no caption), fig. 34 no. 60; 2) [erratically inexplicably chosen] location north-northwest of Hag. Philippou, north of Ephaistou St., Travlos, J. 1988, 25 and fig. 36 (two rectangles between the “Stoa of the Herms“ and the “Stoa Poikile” indicate the supposed location of the gate (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Bronze Portrait Sculpture: of famous men and women in front of the stoas on the way from the gates to the Kerameikos: Paus. 1.2.4; see Themistoklean City Wall Wal5*; [these stoas are on the Panathenaic Way from the Sacred Gate as far as the Stoa Basileios when Pausanias enters the Kerameikos]  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Statues of Horsemen: not far from the Kerameikos Gate: Philostr. VS 2.8.4; [perhaps in relation to the Hipparcheion]  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Stoas on the Panathenaic Way: between the Sacred Gate and the Stoa Basileios; Stoa with sanctuaries of the gods: Paus. 1.2.5  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
Stoas For Commerce: Him. Or. 47.12; Agora_III, 20 no. 1  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Round Bath: in front of the Dipylon Gate, 5th c. B.C.: Harp. s.v. Ανθεμόκριτος; Knigge, U. 1991, 159 no. 60, figs. 155, 165 no. 60  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Warrior and Horse: by Praxiteles, grave mon. not far from the gates: Paus. 1.2.3; G. Lippold, RE XXII 2, 1954, col. 1802 no. 62 (Praxiteles)  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Cavalry Inspection Ground: X. Eq. Mag. 3.14; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 725-726  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Didaskaleion: founded by Plato: Olympiodoros, Vita Plat. 6 (2.145) ; for a sceptical treatment of an [imaginary] grammatodidaskaleion conjured up by Ph. Stavropoullos on the basis of [supposedly] classical schist tablets, see Balatsos, P. 1991, 146, 149, 150 (3), 152 (3) (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Dining Rooms: Ath. 4.137-138  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Academy Entrance: Paus. 1.30.1; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 711  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Academy Gymnasium: Paus. 1.29.2; Delorme, J. 1960, 523 s.v. Athenes (Academie); Billot, M.-F. 1989, 703, 704-706; the classical gymnasium has not been found; (point accuracy ca. 500m)
Peripatos: away from which Plato was driven by Aristotle: Ael. VH 3.19; Wycherley, R. E. 1978, 220-221 (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Pit Burial: of at least 150 people, 430-426 B.C., northwest continuation of the Kerameikos Excavation area, in the angle between Iera Odos and Peiraios Sts.: Th. 2.47,3-54; victims of the Great Plague of 430/429 and 427/426 B.C., E. Baziotopoulou-Valavani in Metro Excavations 1992-1997, with figs. 1, 8-9, 351-356 nos. 383-390 with colour photos; eadem, “A mass burial from the cemetery of Kerameikos,” in Stamatopoulou and Yerolanou 2002, 187-201, figs. 1-3, pls. 41-44  (point accuracy ca. 50m)

Palaestra: just outside the City Wall near the spring house of Panops, the setting of Platoʼs Lysis, where Socrates spoke on the nature of friendship: Pl. Ly. 203 A, 204 A, 206 D-E; Delorme, J. 1960, 523 s.v. Athenes (Palestre de Platon); Kyle, D. G. 1987, 67-68  (point accuracy ca. 500m)

Roman Doric Temple: mid-2nd c. A.D. (?), south of the Olympieion terrace retaining wall, southeast of the so-called temple of Apollo Delphinios, no. U549 below: [doubtably] identified as the temple of Kronos and Rhea, with an [imaginary] 5th c. B.C. temple of Kronos and Rhea somewhere underneath according to Travlos, J. 1971, 290, 335, fig. 154 no. 159, fig. 380 no. 159, figs. 437-440; see Chr. Mon. CM19*
Altar foundations of rubble and lime mortar, Travlos, J. 1971, 335, figs. 380, 438 B
Precinct wall partly preserved on three sides: Travlos, J. 1971, 335, figs. 380, 438 (all four sides [deceptively] drawn as if extant)
Huge statue? base north of the temple: [idly] assigned to the statue of Zeus seen by Pausanias (Paus. 1.18.7), Travlos, J. 1971, 335, fig. 438 D (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Classical Doric Temple: south of the Olympieion precinct: [mistakenly] identified as the temple of Apollo Delphinios on the evidence of sherds with dipinti [whose findspots were neither at nor near the temple in question], Travlos, J. 1971, 83-90, figs. 379-380 no. 160, 381; according to M. Th. Mitsos, the sherds in question, found near Athan. Diakou St., attest the epithet Pythios (see Apollo Apo72* above); [the temple is here identified as the temple of Kronos and Rhea seen by Pausanias (Paus. 1.18.7)]  (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Street: To the Peiraeus from the Sacred Gate (the section of this road within the Kerameikos Exc. is called the “Graberstrasse”), branching southwest off the Sacred Way at the Tritopatreion and after 3+ km. running along the North Long Wall to the Peiraeus: Curtius, E., J. Kaupert and A. Milchhöfer 1881-1890, Blatt 1a Fahrweg (Hamaxitos) von Peiraeus; probably the road mentioned by Pausanias I. 2.2 (twice)   (point accuracy ca. 10m)

Dipylon Gate = Themistoklean City Wall Wal6*: Travlos, J. 1971, fig. 417
From the Akropolis to the Dipylon Gate: see Panathenaic Way
To the the Academy Gymnasium from the Dipylon Gate (the Second Road to the Academy, the Dipylon-Academy Road),laid out in the 5th c. B.C.: the Via Lata, Livy 31.24; “on the way to the Academy is a walled precinct of Artemis and xoana of Ariste and Kalliste,” Paus. 1.29.2; the sixteen levels of the road date from the early 5th c. B.C. to the late 5th c. A.D., B. von Freytag Loringhoff, “Ausgrabungen im Kerameikos 1970-72,” AA 1974, 197-198, fig. 27; Billot, M.-F. 1989, 700-701, 711; Stroszeck, J. 2003, 75-80; [since Pausanias does not mention the Dipylon Gate as the start of this road as Cicero and Livy do, he may have begun his tour two or three hundred metres further on] (point accuracy ca. 10m)
Walk: Inner walk, directly bordering the City Wall: taken by Sokrates on his way from the Academy to the Lykeion, Pl. Ly. 203 A  (point accuracy ca. 500m)
From the Prytaneion: northeastward to the lower town: Paus. 1.18.4  (point accuracy ca. 50m)
